, they say,	 The word in Congress is that all three bills will be haggled about in parallel, right up until the end of the year. The success or failure of Fox's presidency may hang on the outcome of that bargaining. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010831.0095 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-HEARST-FEATURE-BUDGET-HNS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Friday, Aug. 31, 2001  Editors:  The Hearst News Service will file the following for Saturday and Sunday and Monday. If you have questions, please call Tim Spence at 202-298-6920.  (``HNS'' appears in all sluglines.)  LIFESTYLE/FEATURES (``l'' category)  FIVEWAYS-PROCRASTINATION (UNDATED) - The final short list from the  Houston Chronicle. Five ways to stop procrastinating.  GARDEN-COLUMN (Undated) - The garden editor answers questions from  readers. By KATHY HUBER.  LEGION-MEMBERSHIP (San Antonio) _ Although World War II vets are dying at the rate of 1,200 a day, the American Legion says its membership is growing. By DAVID EGGERT.  MEXICO-WATER (San Antonio) _ South Texas farmers are upset at this week's disclosure by Mexican officials that drought conditions will prevent the country from delivering by the end of September millions of gallons of water it owes the United States. By KATE HUNGER.  NURSING-SHORTAGE-1 (Undated) _ Doctors call them the first line of defense and most people consider them the bedrock of health care. Nurses make us feel better. But these days there are not enough of them. A nursing shortage is plaguing New York state and the nation. This is a profile of the life of a nurse. By LYRYSA SMITH. (For release Sunday, Sept. 2.)  NURSING-SHORTAGE-2 (Undated) _ Another profile of a nurse. By LYRYSA SMITH. (For release Monday, Sept. 3.)  WHEELBARROWS (Undated) _ One of the best-ever labor-saving inventions is the wheelbarrow. The basic concept has remained the same through the centuries. It's a simple device that handles outdoor jobs such as moving dirt, compost, trash, leaves and potted flowers. But visit any hardware store, home and garden center or the Internet, and you will discover a wide variety of sizes and styles. By FRANCES INGRAHAM HEINS. (For release Sunday, Sept. 2.)  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  GERMAN-COLUMN (San Francisco) _ Let's begin with some new ``reader'' things you may somehow have missed. The online news audience is growing. People who tap into the large national news sites are staying tapped into the sites longer than they did a year ago. The biggest slice of this growing news audience is made up of people in their 30s. Most of the Web visitors check the news only two or four times a month. A lot of these people say they ``happen'' on the news as they are logging on or logging off. Also, many log on while they ``are doing something else.'' By WILLIAM GERMAN. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010831.0096 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-ECONOMIST-ADVISORY-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The following material from the August 31 issue of THE ECONOMIST magazine are for use by subscribers of the New York Times Syndicate's ECONOMIST news service. Nonsubscribers can use these articles only by special arrangement. For purchase information, call Debra Weydert at 732-390-4480. We regret that this material is NOT available to clients in Canada EXCEPT to The Hamilton (Ontario) Spectator.  COMMENTARY (moved in 'k' category code)  THE UN'S ANTI-RACISM CONFERENCE  UN-RACISM-CONFERENCE-ECONOMIST _ Durban, in South Africa, is a charming city, but delegates attending the U.N. World Conference Against Racism there this week are too angry to enjoy its beaches or curry houses. America is upset that the draft declaration is too hard on Israel. Western governments are annoyed by demands that they should pay reparations for slavery and colonialism, while many Africans and African-Americans are furious that these demands for reparations have been turned aside. Ethnic groups from all around the world have assembled to trumpet their grievances and demand ``remedial measures.''  SHADOWS OVER JAPAN  JAPAN-SHADOW-ECONOMIST _ Another week, another set of impressive-sounding, or painful-sounding, job cuts from one of Japan's finest high-tech exporters. Last week it was Fujitsu, the country's top computer firm, cutting 16,000 jobs. This week it was the turn of Toshiba, a maker of memory chips, laptops and much else, to declare its plan to cut 19,000 jobs. Other cuts have come from NEC, a big telecom and chips firm, and more are rumored to be on the way from Hitachi, one of the country's older conglomerates.  GEORGE BUSH'S BUDGET CHALLENGE  BUSH-BUDGET-ECONOMIST _ Next week, Congress reconvenes after the Labor Day holiday. September will be dominated by the budget for the next fiscal year, which begins on Oct.1. For George Bush, this involves two awkward situations. First, Congress, including the newly Democratic Senate, controls the timing of the various spending bills. And second, the whole numbers business has become rather tricky for Bush now that he stands accused of having wasted Bill Clinton's budget surplus on his tax cut. The Congressional Budget Office says the current year's budget will be balanced only after filching $9 billion from the ``untouchable'' Social Security trust fund.  TIME-SHARING MOVES TO THE STABLES  TIME-SHARE-ECONOMIST _ As a way of marketing property, time-sharing is a familiar idea. Now stable owners across America are adapting the concept to their business. Riders pay a monthly fee, choosing from plans that offer a given number of days a week of riding, or unlimited riding time.  MOBIL PHONES IN CHINA  CHINE-MOBIL-PHONES-ECONOMIST _ Which is the biggest mobile-phone market in the world? The answer, since July, is China. This is a country in which, until a few years ago, the only people who could afford mobile phones were mobsters. Now 121 million Chinese are users. BDA, a Beijing consultancy, forecasts that the number will rise to 370 million by 2005, enough to persuade many investors _ even after telecom shares have dived all over the world _ that China was, and would remain, a magic market. Over the past few weeks, however, much of that magic has vanished. China Mobile, the mainland's dominant operator, with 73 percent of the market, announced half-year results that were superb in every respect bar one: average revenues per user were down by 35 percent. The drop took analysts by surprise and sent China Mobile's shares into a tailspin. Shares in China Unicom, the smaller rival in the country's duopoly, followed.  ALCOHOL IN SWEDEN  ALCOHOL-SWEDEN-ECONOMIST _ Buying a bottle of liquor in Sweden is a notoriously disagreeable experience, thanks to years of practice by Systembolaget, the state-owned monopoly retailer of alcoholic drinks. Now this forbidding institution is undergoing a personality change and trying to reinvent itself as customer-friendly. Out go the clinical glass cases in which drink is displayed; in comes self-service. Since July, most stores have started opening on Saturdays.  A CAUTIOUS COMPETITOR TO CISCO SYSTEMS  CISCO-COMPETITOR-ECONOMIST _ For most of the American business press it is a simple upstart vs. incumbent tale: The nimble Juniper Networks is after Cisco, the juggernaut of networking systems. But ask Scott Kriens, Juniper's chief executive, about that casting and he rolls his eyes as if to say, ``Stop comparing apples with pears.'' In part, Kriens' reaction is a wise business tactic. Many a challenger has trumpeted too loudly, only to be crushed by the incumbent. Juniper is a serious competitive threat to Cisco in the strategic market of high-end routers, the traffic cops of the Internet backbone. But it is also true that the companies are quite different beasts.  SCANDINAVIAN REPUBLICANS ON THE RISE  SCANDINAVIAN-REPUBLICANS-ECONOMIST _ On the face of things, Scandinavians enjoy the paradox of being sturdy monarchists and relentless egalitarians all at once. Judging by the whoops and cheers in Oslo's streets last weekend, when Norway's crown prince married a commoner with a 4-year-old child born out of wedlock with a convicted drug offender, many still feel that way. Republican sentiment in Norway and Sweden, however, is far from dead. In the past week, two of Scandinavia's biggest newspapers have called for their countries' monarchies to go. Only Denmark's popular royals have been largely unscathed.  WORRIES ABOUT HOUSING BUST  HOUSING-BUST-ECONOMIST _ If America's economy avoids sliding from downturn into a full-blown recession, it will be because the consumer continues to spend freely. Some economists had feared that this week's revised gross domestic product figures would show that the economy had shrunk in the second quarter. Instead, consumer spending kept the figure positive _ albeit at just 0.2 percent compared with the previous quarter at an annual rate. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, has remained strong despite falling share prices and rising unemployment for one main reason: a housing boom. Average house prices rose 8.8 percent in the year to March. New government figures, due this weekend, should still show an upward trend.  GOV. GRAY DAVIS RECOVERS IN CALIFORNIA  GRAY-DAVIS-RECOVERS-ECONOMIST _ Presidents come and go, but campaigning is eternal. With a mere 1,159 days until the next election, it is time to start handicapping the Democrats who want to take on President George W. Bush in 2004. And suddenly Gray Davis, the governor of California, is back, slowly moving up the pack. This might strike anybody who has been out of the country for the past couple of months as ridiculous. Surely not the man who plunged the Golden State into obscurity? Who became the butt of a hundred light-bulb jokes? Who became known as the Prince of Darkness?  FOX'S MOMENT OF TRUTH  FOX-MEXICO-ECONOMIST _ There will be ``no surprises'' in Vicente Fox's first state-of-the-nation address on Sept. 1, say his spin doctors, bar the format: a shorter, more accessible kind of presidential speech, ``so that people don't turn off the television.'' That just about sums up Fox's presidency so far. If you picture the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which ruled for seven decades until Fox took over, as a software operating system, then Mexico is still running, at best, PRI 1.1: a more user-friendly version, perhaps, but not the redesign that is needed.  THE DISPUTE OVER CANADIAN LUMBER  CANADIAN-LUMBER-ECONOMIST _ No other country has more experience of the abrasive U.S. approach to trade disputes than Canada, and no Canadian industry knows more about such matters than its producers of softwood lumber. But familiarity does not ease the pain: Canadian wood producers have begun to shut mills and layoff thousands of workers in response to a decision in early August by America's Commerce Department to impose a 19 percent countervailing duty on timber imports.  PERU'S POST-FUJIMORI PURGE  POST-FUJIMORI-PURGE-ECONOMIST _ With his regime collapsing in scandal, last November Alberto Fujimori, Peru's authoritarian former president, sought asylum in Japan, whose nationality he claims by descent. Under Japanese law, its nationals cannot be extradited, so Fujimori may be safe from judicial pursuit. But Japan may not be protected from embarrassment over its guest. Hitherto, investigations into the abuses of Fujimori's regime have centered on Vladimiro Montesinos, his sleazy intelligence chief, who has been imprisoned since June on some 50 charges. Investigators say they have made little progress in their efforts to link Fujimori to the proceeds of Montesinos' corruption, partly, they say, because they have not received much international co-operation.  CHINA FACES UP TO ITS AIDS PROBLEM  CHINA-AIDS-ECONOMIST _ After failing for months, if not years, to come publicly to grips with a fast-growing problem of HIV and AIDS, Chinese health officials on Aug. 23 pulled their heads out of the sand, at least partially. Talking to reporters in Beijing, the vice minister of health, Yin Dakui, acknowledged that China is ``facing a very serious epidemic'' and admitted that negligence by provincial and local-level officials had contributed to the spread of the disease.  TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC OVERTURES  TAIWAN-ECONOMIC-ECONOMIST _ The Taiwanese have not seen a contraction of their economy since they began compiling records in 1952. Two generations have grown up taking 8 percent annual growth for granted and thinking recession was an ailment of the sclerotic West. So with even the usually optimistic government number-cruncher predicting growth of minus 0.3 percent this year, the mood is close to panic. That may help explain a new readiness to contemplate expanding economic ties with mainland China.  BUSINESS-WEEK-ECONOMIST - A review in brief from the world of business this week.  POLITICS-WEEK-ECONOMIST - A review in brief from the world of politics this week. September will be dominated by the budget for the next fiscal year, which begins on Oct.1. For George Bush, this involves two awkward situations. First, Congress, including the newly Democratic Senate, controls the timing of the various spending bills. And second, the whole numbers business has become rather tricky for Bush now that he stands accused of having wasted Bill Clinton's budget surplus on his tax cut. The Congressional Budget Office says the current year's budget will be balanced only after filching $9 billion from the ``untouchable'' Social Security trust fund.  TIME-SHARING MOVES TO THE STABLES  TIME-SHARE-ECONOMIST _ As a way of marketing property, time-sharing is a familiar idea. Now stable owners across America are adapting the concept to their business. Riders pay a monthly fee, choosing from plans that offer a given number of days a week of riding, or unlimited riding time.  MOBIL PHONES IN CHINA  CHINE-MOBIL-PHONES-ECONOMIST _ Which is the biggest mobile-phone market in the world? The answer, since July, is China. This is a country in which, until a few years ago, the only people who could afford mobile phones were mobsters. Now 121 million Chinese are users. BDA, a Beijing consultancy, forecasts that the number will rise to 370 million by 2005, enough to persuade many investors _ even after telecom shares have dived all over the world _ that China was, and would remain, a magic market. Over the past few weeks, however, much of that magic has vanished. China Mobile, the mainland's dominant operator, with 73 percent of the market, announced half-year results that were superb in every respect bar one: average revenues per user were down by 35 percent. The drop took analysts by surprise and sent China Mobile's shares into a tailspin. Shares in China Unicom, the smaller rival in the country's duopoly, followed.  ALCOHOL IN SWEDEN  ALCOHOL-SWEDEN-ECONOMIST _ Buying a bottle of liquor in Sweden is a notoriously disagreeable experience, thanks to years of practice by Systembolaget, the state-owned monopoly retailer of alcoholic drinks. Now this forbidding institution is undergoing a personality change and trying to reinvent itself as customer-friendly. Out go the clinical glass cases in which drink is displayed; in comes self-service. Since July, most stores have started opening on Saturdays.  A CAUTIOUS COMPETITOR TO CISCO SYSTEMS  CISCO-COMPETITOR-ECONOMIST _ For most of the American business press it is a simple upstart vs. incumbent tale: The nimble Juniper Networks is after Cisco, the juggernaut of networking systems. But ask Scott Kriens, Juniper's chief executive, about that casting and he rolls his eyes as if to say, ``Stop comparing apples with pears.'' In part, Kriens' reaction is a wise business tactic. Many a challenger has trumpeted too loudly, only to be crushed by the incumbent. Juniper is a serious competitive threat to Cisco in the strategic market of high-end routers, the traffic cops of the Internet backbone. But it is also true that the companies are quite different beasts.  SCANDINAVIAN REPUBLICANS ON THE RISE  SCANDINAVIAN-REPUBLICANS-ECONOMIST _ On the face of things, Scandinavians enjoy the paradox of being sturdy monarchists and relentless egalitarians all at once. Judging by the whoops and cheers in Oslo's streets last weekend, when Norway's crown prince married a commoner with a 4-year-old child born out of wedlock with a convicted drug offender, many still feel that way. Republican sentiment in Norway and Sweden, however, is far from dead. In the past week, two of Scandinavia's biggest newspapers have called for their countries' monarchies to go. Only Denmark's popular royals have been largely unscathed.  WORRIES ABOUT HOUSING BUST  HOUSING-BUST-ECONOMIST _ If America's economy avoids sliding from downturn into a full-blown recession, it will be because the consumer continues to spend freely. Some economists had feared that this week's revised gross domestic product figures would show that the economy had shrunk in the second quarter. Instead, consumer spending kept the figure positive _ albeit at just 0.2 percent compared with the previous quarter at an annual rate. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, has remained strong despite falling share prices and rising unemployment for one main reason: a housing boom. Average house prices rose 8.8 percent in the year to March. New government figures, due this weekend, should still show an upward trend.  GOV. GRAY DAVIS RECOVERS IN CALIFORNIA  GRAY-DAVIS-RECOVERS-ECONOMIST _ Presidents come and go, but campaigning is eternal. With a mere 1,159 days until the next election, it is time to start handicapping the Democrats who want to take on President George W. Bush in 2004. And suddenly Gray Davis, the governor of California, is back, slowly moving up the pack. This might strike anybody who has been out of the country for the past couple of months as ridiculous. Surely not the man who plunged the Golden State into obscurity? Who became the butt of a hundred light-bulb jokes? Who became known as the Prince of Darkness?  FOX'S MOMENT OF TRUTH  FOX-MEXICO-ECONOMIST _ There will be ``no surprises'' in Vicente Fox's first state-of-the-nation address on Sept. 1, say his spin doctors, bar the format: a shorter, more accessible kind of presidential speech, ``so that people don't turn off the television.'' That just about sums up Fox's presidency so far. If you picture the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which ruled for seven decades until Fox took over, as a software operating system, then Mexico is still running, at best, PRI 1.1: a more user-friendly version, perhaps, but not the redesign that is needed.  THE DISPUTE OVER CANADIAN LUMBER  CANADIAN-LUMBER-ECONOMIST _ No other country has more experience of the abrasive U.S. approach to trade disputes than Canada, and no Canadian industry knows more about such matters than its producers of softwood lumber. But familiarity does not ease the pain: Canadian wood producers have begun to shut mills and layoff thousands of workers in response to a decision in early August by America's Commerce Department to impose a 19 percent countervailing duty on timber imports.  PERU'S POST-FUJIMORI PURGE  POST-FUJIMORI-PURGE-ECONOMIST _ With his regime collapsing in scandal, last November Alberto Fujimori, Peru's authoritarian former president, sought asylum in Japan, whose nationality he claims by descent. Under Japanese law, its nationals cannot be extradited, so Fujimori may be safe from judicial pursuit. But Japan may not be protected from embarrassment over its guest. Hitherto, investigations into the abuses of Fujimori's regime have centered on Vladimiro Montesinos, his sleazy intelligence chief, who has been imprisoned since June on some 50 charges. Investigators say they have made little progress in their efforts to link Fujimori to the proceeds of Montesinos' corruption, partly, they say, because they have not received much international co-operation.  CHINA FACES UP TO ITS AIDS PROBLEM  CHINA-AIDS-ECONOMIST _ After failing for months, if not years, to come publicly to grips with a fast-growing problem of HIV and AIDS, Chinese health officials on Aug. 23 pulled their heads out of the sand, at least partially. Talking to reporters in Beijing, the vice minister of health, Yin Dakui, acknowledged that China is ``facing a very serious epidemic'' and admitted that negligence by provincial and local-level officials had contributed to the spread of the disease.  TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC OVERTURES  TAIWAN-ECONOMIC-ECONOMIST _ The Taiwanese have not seen a contraction of their economy since they began compiling records in 1952. Two generations have grown up taking 8 percent annual growth for granted and thinking recession was an ailment of the sclerotic West. So with even the usually optimistic government number-cruncher predicting growth of minus 0.3 percent this year, the mood is close to panic. That may help explain a new readiness to contemplate expanding economic ties with mainland China.  BUSINESS-WEEK-ECONOMIST - A review in brief from the world of business this week.  POLITICS-WEEK-ECONOMIST - A review in brief from the world of politics this week. , he argues,	 BREATHE IN, BREATHE OUT ...: A new book challenges us to think about a basic life-sustaining activity -- breathing. Take a minute and concentrate on the air going in and out of your lungs and you will feel refreshed, writes Lorin Roche in ``Breath Taking'' (Rodale; $14.95). The benefits of paying attention to our breathing are great, he argues, helping us relax, sleep better, feel energized and conquer stress. Try this one when you're stressed out: As you breathe in, lift your shoulders high, then slowly drop them as you exhale. Do this for one minute, five times a week. (I tried it and I have to admit he might be on the something.) And that's just one of Roche's breathing exercises in the book. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010831.0129 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-SPORTS-NYT-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Attn Sports Editors:  Sports stories from The New York Times News Service for SATURDAY, Sept. 1. , they say,	 On the other side, many conservatives contend that Social Security's flaws are so fundamental that the government has to destroy the program in order to save it. , they say,	 That is exactly the way it looks to an eclectic band of economists who don't fall into either political straitjacket. Social Security does have a fundamental flaw, they say, but it cannot be overcome by privatizing the system. </P> 	nyt_eng_200108.gz
, he says,	 If only it were that easy. Privatization, says Jeffrey A. Miron, an economist at Boston University, is a false promise. , they say,	 In a recent paper, he and Kevin M. Murphy, an economist at the University of Chicago, argue that the crucial point is that privatization will have no effect on the stream of Social Security benefits that the government has promised to pay. Claims that privatization solves the impending crisis are wrong, they say, just as claims that privatization harms Social Security are wrong. </P> 	nyt_eng_200108.gz

, he suggested,	 The photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson tried to dissolve the tense problem years before. , it seems,	 Adams had, it seems, an unusual relationship to time. His memory was bad, as he admitted. TOP  Lede story:  U.N.-RACISM (Durban, South Africa) _ Palestinian leaders raised hopes and dashed them within hours on the opening day of the U.N. racism conference, first announcing that they would not support proposed language that labels Israel a racist state and then backing away from their own overture. By Henri E. Cauvin. (We plan to move the story by 9:30 p.m. ET in ``i'' news file.)  Top center story:  BBO-LITTLE-LEAGUE (New York) _ The Rolando Paulino All-Stars must forfeit all their victories from the 2001 Little League season, including their third-place title in the World Series, Little League Baseball officials announce at a news conference in South Williamsport, Pa. By Edward Wong. (EDS: an early version and 1stLd-Writethru of this story, by Samuel D. King, have moved; the 2ndLd-Writethru is scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``s'' news file.)  The story runs under a 3-column photo; NYT photos 1, 2, 14, 15.  Off-lead story:  MEXICO-U.S.-IMMIG (Washington) _ After months of extensive negotiations, the White House is forced to acknowledge that it will not a reach a comprehensive new agreement with Mexico on immigration next week when President Bush meets with President Vicente Fox. By Eric Schmitt. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``i'' news file.) 1,400 words.  FOLD  JAPAN-EXPLOSION (Tokyo) _ Developing. An explosion and fire tore through a gambling parlor in a bustling Tokyo nightclub district early Saturday, killing at least 44 people, officials said. By Howard W. French. (Scheduled to move by 9:30 p.m. ET in ``i'' news file.)  3-column photo reefer to AALIYAH-FUNERAL; story inside.  BOTTOM  DENVER-AIR (Denver) _ Once known as one of the most polluted urban areas for its persistent brown haze, Denver is about to become the first major city to eliminate severe air pollution and achieve full compliance with the Clean Air Act. By Michael Janofsky. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``a'' news file.) 1,000 words.  BRITAIN-HEALTH (London) _ Britain's health minister, Alan Milburn, introduces a policy that will now permit Britons to travel in much larger numbers to continental Europe for operations performed in European hospitals, but largely paid for by the British public health service. By Alan Cowell. (Scheduled to move by 8:30 p.m. ET in ``i'' news file.) 1,600 words.  INSIDE STORIES PROMOTED ON PAGE 1:  BUSH-AIDE-LEAK (Austin, Texas) _ A federal judge sentences a woman accused of stealing practice materials for last fall's presidential debates to a year in prison, $3,000 in fines and three years on probation. By Ross E. Milloy. (The story has moved in ``a'' news file.) 600 words.  CONGRESS-FARMS (Washington) _ At least seven members of Congress receive thousands of dollars in farm subsidies each year and all but two sit on the agriculture committees that are writing the new farm policy. Comments from a sampling of the recipients. By Elizabeth Becker. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``w'' news file.) 900 words.  WORK-HOURS (Undated) _ A U.N. agency provided some discouraging news to Americans who believe they are overworked, finding that American workers have increased their substantial lead over Japan and all other industrial nations in the number of hours worked each year. By Steven Greenhouse. (The story has moved in ``a'' and ``f'' news files.) 900 words.  With a graphic.  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. , he says,	 In his book ``Guns, Germs and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies'' (W.W. Norton), Jared Diamond, a professor of physiology at the UCLA's medical school, contends that white dominance was a largely a product of geography, climate and other factors, not race. European habitats had a wide variety of plant and animal species that formed a reliable food base and encouraged farming, he says, and farming led to stable communities, stratified societies, governments and, eventually, armies and explorers who sought to extend their culture's reach. Other cultures with those advantages, he argues, faced different diseases or other constraints. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, she says,	 LEONE _ Behind the Census numbers showing growth among older Americans is Leone Good. The 88-year-old has worked all her life, and has no plans to quit. If she stopped, she says, she'd end up like the people at the nursing home where she works. Older faces are nothing new at places like Wal-Mart, known for its grandfatherly greeters. , he believed,	 Story Filed By Cox Newspapers </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010902.0056 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (AM-NYT-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> FOR MONDAY AMs  Here are today's top news stories from The New York Times News Service for AMs of Monday, Sept. 3:  INTERNATIONAL  (Will move in ``i'' news file)  MIDEAST-SCHOOLS (Jerusalem) _ One of the more familiar routines in any country, the first day of school, became another reason for Israelis and Palestinians to worry this past weekend what fate each might endure at the hands of the other. All weekend, newspapers and television broadcasts talked about how the police in Jerusalem were on high alert for a Palestinian terrorist attack, perhaps on a school building or a school bus. By Clyde Haberman.  PUTIN-BUSH (Moscow) _ Russian President Vladimir Putin said this weekend that he believed that President Bush was a creature of the powerful circle of aides that advise him on national security and foreign policy, and that this circle was still struggling over its priorities, especially those regarding ``strategic stability.'' By Patrick E. Tyler.  NKOREA-TALKS (Undated) _ North Korea on Sunday proposed resuming talks with South Korea. South Korea's unification ministry confirmed that it had monitored a broadcast over Radio Pyongyang in which Rim Tong-ok, vice chairman of the North's committee for peaceful reunification, responsible for dealings with the South, called for ``speedy resumption in talks between South and North Korean government officials.'' The message was greeted with relief by South Korean officials who saw it as rescuing President Kim Dae-jung's ``sunshine policy'' of rapprochement with the North. By Don Kirk.  GERMANY-PHOTO-FLAP (Berlin) _ The German defense minister, Rudolf Scharping, has been considered one of the more straight-laced and petit-bourgeois figures in a German government that features a much-married chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder, and foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, the former radical. But after an awkward, self-publicized set of Majorca vacation snaps of Scharping and his countess fiancee, he is now being called ``A defense minister in love,'' and his personal and professional judgment are being called in question. By Steven Erlanger.  CHANNEL-MIGRANTS (London) _ In one of the most audacious attempts by migrants to evade Britain's restrictions on asylum-seekers, security officials intercepted a group of about 100 people apparently attempting a mass dash through the channel tunnel from France on Saturday night, the French police said Sunday. The attempt to use the rail link underneath the English Channel was the third this week and showed the perils the migrants are prepared to face to seek sanctuary. By Alan Cowell.  INDONESIA-CIGARETTE (Kudus, Indonesia) _ The Indonesian clove cigarette is a great deal more than tobacco and cloves. It is a complex, infinitely variable symphony of scent and flavor. Usually about two-thirds tobacco and one-third clove, the Indonesian cigarette also contains one more, often secret, ingredient: its sauce, or ``saus'' in the Indonesian language. By Seth Mydans.  MACEDONIA-NATO (Tetovo, Macedonia) _ One week into NATO's mission in Macedonia, there is a yawning gap between the expectations of many Albanian and even some Macedonian civilians and the very limited mission that NATO troops have been assigned. By Michael R. Gordon.  RACE-CONFERENCE (Durban, South Africa) _ Coverage of the U.N. conference on intolerance. By Rachel L. Swarns.  BARNARD-OBIT (Undated) _ Dr. Christian Barnard, who did first human-to-human heart transplant in 1967, died Sunday in a resort in Cyprus. He was 78. By Lawrence K. Altman.  WASHINGTON:  (Will move in ``w'' news file)  CONGRESS-SPENDING (Washington) _ As Congress returns to face President Bush's requests for increased spending on defense and education, it faces a decision, now that the surplus has vanished and the economy is so soft, on whether to cut spending elsewhere, roll back the tax cut _ or reject the President's priorities. By Lizette Alvarez.  STEMCELL-SHIFT (Washington) _ In the weeks since President Bush decided to permit federal financing for certain studies of human embryonic stem cells, an enormous shift has occurred in the public debate. No longer does it revolve around the question of whether the science is ethical. Now the question is whether Bush's plan is adequate to support the research. By Sheryl Gay Stolberg.  COLUMNS  (Will move in ``k'' news file)  HERBERT-COLUMN (Undated) _ Commentary by Bob Herbert. CULTURE  (Coded e)  FUGARD-SAFRICA-THEATER (Cape Town, South Africa) _ Athol Fugard's newest play, ``Sorrows &AMP; Rejoicings,'' opened on Aug. 28 for a four-week run at the Baxter Theater here. It is the unwanted inheritance of a young mixed-race woman, who is unsure of what to keep and what to throw away from her past. It is a symbol of a modern South Africa still wrestling with its history, and perhaps of the aging playwright himself. Fugard, 69, is the undisputed giant of South African theater, the defiant white artist who championed the liberation struggle and cheered apartheid's demise in 1994. Yet today, he says he finds himself feeling a bit lonely and a bit unwanted. By Rachel L. Swarns.  BLACK-WRITERS-WORKSHOP (New York) _ The Frederick Douglass Creative Arts Center, one of the oldest, continuously running workshops for minority artists and writers in this city, is celebrating its 30th anniversary. The center is a word-of-mouth kind of place that for three decades has quietly helped start the careers of some of the country's most acclaimed black writers, actors, directors and performers. Famous alumni include Danny Glover, Garrett Morris and Bill Duke. Early in their careers Samuel L. Jackson and S. Epatha Merkerson (who plays Lt. Anita Van Buren on NBC's ``Law and Order'') both performed in plays produced by the center. By Sherri Day.  ARTS-ONLINE (Undated) _ And the Academy Award for best picture goes to ... MTV? It would never happen at the Oscars. But for a prominent Internet prize being given out Monday night, such a scenario is not so far-fetched. The prize in question is the Prix Ars Electronica, awarded annually during the Ars Electronica Festival in Linz, Austria. The electronic-arts festival is a mecca for Internet artists, computer-music composers and others working in the digital realm. By Matthew Mirapaul.  WAR-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ A review of ``War Story'' by Gwen Edelman (Riverhead/Putnam). By Richard Bernstein.  SCHOOL-TV-REVIEW (Undated) _ Critic's Notebook on PBS series ``School: The Story of American Public Education'' , ``The First Year,'' also on PBS, and the HBO documentary series ``Kindergarten.'' By Julie Salamon.  FINANCIAL  (Coded f)  BELL-SOUTH (Atlanta)_ Of all the regional Bell companies that were spun off from AT&AMP;T in 1984, BellSouth is the only one that is still a regional Bell. And the strategy seems to be working. By foregoing national expansion to focus on local service in the same nine states where it has operated the last 17 years, BellSouth has found the local telephone business a haven during the storm that has ravaged so much of the rest of the telecommunications industry. By Simon Romero.  with  NEW-ECONOMY-COLUMN (Undated) _ The House is considering whether to scale back regulations that the Bell companies say makes it difficult to offer broadband Internet access. Meanwhile, the Senate is considering a bill backed by AT&AMP;T to break the Bells into separate companies. Are the bills really meant to help consumers, or are they merely tools to hurt competitors and make up for technical shortcomings? By Seth Schiesel.  ECOMMERCE-COLUMN (Undated) _ As Internet retailing has dwindled mainly to the online extensions of the old-line merchants, ideas about e-profitability have become a bit more nuanced than they used to be. According to two recently released reports from Internet consulting firms _ one by Forrester Research, the other by Jupiter Media Metrix _ bricks-and-mortar retailers that judge their Web divisions solely on the basis of profits may be shortchanging themselves. By Bob Tedeschi.  PATENTS-COLUMN (Undated) _ Patents on products for backpackers and beachgoers. By Sabra Chartrand.  BIZGLANCE (Undated) _ Major financial stories at a glance.  ECON-CALENDAR (Undated) _ Key government figures this week.  BOND-CALENDAR (Undated) _ The week's planned offerings.  Eds., fyi, there is no ADCOL or EQUITIES scheduled for Monday paper.  MEDIA-BUSINESS  (Coding varies.)  MEYER-PROFILE (Undated) _ The tale of Irwin Meyer, the atypical Internet entrepreneur, who has won a Tony Award, served prison time for tax fraud, and is still trying to stay afloat. By Michael Brick.  HBO-WWII-SERIES (Undated) _ HBO is spending an unheard of sum _ $120 million _ on the Tom Hanks-Steven Spielberg production of ``Band of Brothers,'' a tale of World War II. How can this possibly be worth the money? Isn't America finally burning out on World War II nostalgia? By Bill Carter.  NBC-CBS-BATTLE (Undated) _ On Wednesday night, CBS and NBC will go head to head for two hours with heavily promoted reality shows. The lineups on Wednesday represent several months of moves and countermoves by the networks' programmers, Leslie Moonves of CBS and Jeff Zucker of NBC, who seem to be approaching the season like two gunslingers. Or as one longtime network executive put it: ``These guys want to kill each other.'' By Bill Carter.  BUSINESS-WEEK-PLAGIARISM (Undated) _ Ken Layne, a columnist with The Online Journalism Review, at the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication, went to the Web last week to shame a Business Week Online reporter whom, he believed, had stolen his work without credit. He may have a point. By Felicity Barringer.  QUESTIONS OR RERUNS: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927:  The supervisor is Mitch Keller (E-mail, mikell(at)nytimes.com). COMMENTARY  BBO-BERKOW-COLUMN (Undated) _ Sports of the Times column on the Little League debacle. By Ira Berkow.  DAY'S EVENTS  TEN-U.S.-OPEN (New York) _ Lede story on the U.S. Open. By Selena Roberts.  FEATURES  MANTLE-FAMILY (Dallas) _ If Merlyn Mantle is haunted by the suffering in her life, she does not easily show it. The widow of Mickey Mantle is 5-foot-2 and vivacious, wearing a white top and white pants as she sits in her 15th-floor condominium. Nearing 70, her eyes are lively, her manner straightforward. She speaks openly about her drinking, Mickey's alcoholism and his philandering. And while she has no doubt shed many tears, none are coming now. By Richard Sandomir.  BBO-LITTLE-LEAGUE (New York) _ The godmother of Little League pitcher Danny Almonte says Danny has been wronged, and that it will ultimately be proved that Danny is 12, not 14. By Edward Wong. For questions, please call Dominick Calicchio at 415-777-7815 or the business desk at 415-536-5172. For business stories running in main news, call the news desk at 415-777-7074.  NETWORTH (COLUMN) _ The dog days of summer ended with a snarl last week.  Since Memorial Day, the Dow Jones industrial average is down 9.6 percent, the Standard &AMP; Poor's 500 is off 11.3 percent and the Nasdaq composite has fallen 19.8 percent.  By comparison, since 1971, the S&AMP;P 500 has gained 1.8 percent on average between Memorial Day and Labor Day, according to Ned Davis Research.  Last week alone, the three major indexes slid 4 to 6 percent, mocking all talk of a summer rally. COLUMN BY KATHLEEN PENDER  MONEYTALKS (COLUMN) _ Somewhere in Seattle, Bill Gates is smiling.  Mr. Bill can rest assured his monopoly is safe from the great minds of the Linux revolution.  Four of those minds _ including ``Kernel'' Linus Torvalds himself _ got together on a San Francisco stage last week and proceeded to give an hourlong demonstration on why the open source computing revolution will fail.  Essentially, the group proved that democracy has no place in the business world. COLUMN BY ALAN T. SARACEVIC  ONLINEGUIDE (COLUMN) _ Labor Day is a once-a-year reminder of who is responsible for economic good times and who gets hit the hardest when the good times go bad.  Go online to compare your salary with others in your line of work and to see what your paycheck will buy in today's economy. Look for federal employment and workplace rules, and review job prospects for hundreds of occupations. Lastly, go online to learn more about Labor Day and the work of early labor leaders. COLUMN BY JOHN BATTEIGER  ADVERTISE _ Randy Hibbitts suspected the end was near for him as a copywriter at AKQA, a San Francisco advertising agency, when there was no copy to write and he was getting a lot of quality windsurfing time in the afternoon.  Hibbitts was in the first round of the advertising industry's current cost-cutting phase. He is freelancing now, or would like to. There's not a lot of work to do. BY GEORGE RAINE  INSURER _ A federal investigation of an alleged swindle involving the notorious, now-defunct Executive Life Insurance Co. could result in indictments this month or soon afterward against French investors and companies, law-enforcement sources say.  For some policyholders it may be too little, too late, after a decade of pain. But if they are issued, criminal charges stemming from the Los Angeles company's 1991 nosedive might prove helpful to attorneys still trying to avenge in civil courts what has been described by state and federal law-enforcement officials as a gigantic international fraud. BY SCOTT WINOKUR  PAY _ After nearly two years of big losses and then job cuts, executives for Britannica.com decided that their strategy of giving away online encyclopedias was doomed. The Chicago company's only hope for survival, they believed, was to begin charging consumers, abandoning one of the Internet industry's most sacred traditions: a free ride.  Get used to it. BY VERNE KOPYTOFF  TECH21 (COLUMN) _ Things are looking up on the wireless-networking front.  First and foremost, it looks as though a relatively quick and painless fix may be in the offing for the security problems hanging over the hot wireless technology known as 802.11 _ a.k.a. Wi-Fi, or wireless Ethernet or, depending on your vendor, AirThis or AirThat. COLUMN BY HENRY NORR  BIOSCOPE (COLUMN) _ In money manager Kurt von Emster's third-story office in the heart of South San Francisco's biotech cluster, a pistol-grip microphone, meant for eavesdropping, sits on the sill of his picture window.  ``My colleagues gave me that as a joke,'' said von Emster, who helps manage $300 million in public and private investments for MPM Capital. ``They say all I have to do is point it out the window and listen.'' COLUMN BY TOM ABATE  SCHOOLS _ When it came to exposing students to technology in the classroom, Apple had all the popularity of a football captain, valedictorian and homecoming queen.  For years, the Cupertino, Calif., company had everyone sitting at its lunch table, claiming the education market as its own by getting students hooked on computers before anyone else.  Then the new kid arrived _ Dell. BY PIA SARKAR  OVERTIME _ From Allstate Insurance to U-Haul, a growing number of businesses in California are being hit with class-action lawsuits seeking overtime pay from employees who traditionally do not get it.  The flurry of suits has been triggered by some large court settlements, including a $90 million overtime pay award last month for 2,400 claims adjusters at Farmers Insurance Exchange. BY MATTHEW YI  INVESTING (COLUMN) _ Comparing stock-selection strategies to see which ones pick the best stocks is a good way to improve your own stock-picking proficiency.  OnMoney.com (www.onmoney.com), a service of Ameritrade, provides a resource for doing that if you're patient and willing to plan ahead. COLUMN BY HARRY DOMASH  PHONE _ Cisco Systems, its sales depressed by the economic slump, has found a glimmer of hope on the phone.  Sales of the company's Internet technology phone systems, which use data networks to transmit conversations, have fared better than Cisco's overall business, merely dipping while total sales have plunged. BY DAVID R. The center is a word-of-mouth kind of place that for three decades has quietly helped start the careers of some of the country's most acclaimed black writers, actors, directors and performers. Famous alumni include Danny Glover, Garrett Morris and Bill Duke. Early in their careers Samuel L. Jackson and S. Epatha Merkerson (who plays Lt. Anita Van Buren on NBC's ``Law and Order'') both performed in plays produced by the center. By Sherri Day.  ARTS-ONLINE (Undated) _ And the Academy Award for best picture goes to ... MTV? It would never happen at the Oscars. But for a prominent Internet prize being given out Monday night, such a scenario is not so far-fetched. The prize in question is the Prix Ars Electronica, awarded annually during the Ars Electronica Festival in Linz, Austria. The electronic-arts festival is a mecca for Internet artists, computer-music composers and others working in the digital realm. By Matthew Mirapaul.  WAR-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ A review of ``War Story'' by Gwen Edelman (Riverhead/Putnam). By Richard Bernstein.  SCHOOL-TV-REVIEW (Undated) _ Critic's Notebook on PBS series ``School: The Story of American Public Education'' , ``The First Year,'' also on PBS, and the HBO documentary series ``Kindergarten.'' By Julie Salamon.  FINANCIAL  (Coded f)  BELL-SOUTH (Atlanta)_ Of all the regional Bell companies that were spun off from AT&AMP;T in 1984, BellSouth is the only one that is still a regional Bell. And the strategy seems to be working. By foregoing national expansion to focus on local service in the same nine states where it has operated the last 17 years, BellSouth has found the local telephone business a haven during the storm that has ravaged so much of the rest of the telecommunications industry. By Simon Romero.  with  NEW-ECONOMY-COLUMN (Undated) _ The House is considering whether to scale back regulations that the Bell companies say makes it difficult to offer broadband Internet access. Meanwhile, the Senate is considering a bill backed by AT&AMP;T to break the Bells into separate companies. Are the bills really meant to help consumers, or are they merely tools to hurt competitors and make up for technical shortcomings? By Seth Schiesel.  ECOMMERCE-COLUMN (Undated) _ As Internet retailing has dwindled mainly to the online extensions of the old-line merchants, ideas about e-profitability have become a bit more nuanced than they used to be. According to two recently released reports from Internet consulting firms _ one by Forrester Research, the other by Jupiter Media Metrix _ bricks-and-mortar retailers that judge their Web divisions solely on the basis of profits may be shortchanging themselves. By Bob Tedeschi.  PATENTS-COLUMN (Undated) _ Patents on products for backpackers and beachgoers. By Sabra Chartrand.  BIZGLANCE (Undated) _ Major financial stories at a glance.  Eds., fyi, there is no ADCOL or EQUITIES scheduled for Monday paper.  MEDIA-BUSINESS  (Coding varies.)  MEYER-PROFILE (Undated) _ The tale of Irwin Meyer, the atypical Internet entrepreneur, who has won a Tony Award, served prison time for tax fraud, and is still trying to stay afloat. By Michael Brick.  HBO-WWII-SERIES (Undated) _ HBO is spending an unheard of sum _ $120 million _ on the Tom Hanks-Steven Spielberg production of ``Band of Brothers,'' a tale of World War II. How can this possibly be worth the money? Isn't America finally burning out on World War II nostalgia? By Bill Carter.  NBC-CBS-BATTLE (Undated) _ On Wednesday night, CBS and NBC will go head to head for two hours with heavily promoted reality shows. The lineups on Wednesday represent several months of moves and countermoves by the networks' programmers, Leslie Moonves of CBS and Jeff Zucker of NBC, who seem to be approaching the season like two gunslingers. Or as one longtime network executive put it: ``These guys want to kill each other.'' By Bill Carter.  BUSINESS-WEEK-PLAGIARISM (Undated) _ Ken Layne, a columnist with The Online Journalism Review, at the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication, went to the Web last week to shame a Business Week Online reporter whom, he believed, had stolen his work without credit. He may have a point. By Felicity Barringer.  QUESTIONS OR RERUNS: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927:  The supervisor is Mitch Keller (E-mail, mikell(at)nytimes.com). , they disband,	 ``Talented people (actors, directors, writers, animators, key grips and so on) and very small firms come together for a particular, finite project. When they complete the project, they disband, each participant having learned new skills, forged new connections, deepened existing relationships, enhanced their reputations within the industry, and earned a credit they can add to their resume.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, it said,	 Even the Library of Congress when it announced that Billy Collins had been appointed its poet laureate used the dreaded phrase. Collins' work, it said, was ``widely accessible,'' a description Collins dislikes because, as he has said in interviews since his appointment, it makes him seem like a hero of the ``poetically handicapped.'' He simply does not believe that poetry must be difficult, and his fans (they include the likes of John Updike and Annie Proulx) love him for it. In keeping with that popular tone, Random House compares this new collection to a singer's album of ``greatest hits.'' Most of this work comes from four previous collections, with 20 new poems at the end of the book. We've read them all, and while we don't believe poetry must be difficult, we enjoy a challenge or a little weight now and again. We didn't find much here. Maybe accessibility is not for everyone. Collins' predecessors at the Library of Congress include Rita Dove, Randall Jarrell, Robert Lowell, Maxine Kumin and Robert Penn Warren. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010902.0074 type=story > <HEADLINE> BC-NEW&AMP;NOTABLE-AZR(a) </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-NEW&AMP;NOTABLE-AZR) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he said,	 Part of the problem, Cassar said, is that retailers find it difficult to measure their Web sites' impact on in-store sales. But generally speaking, he said, less than half the investments a company makes in its Web division actually pay off in online sales. The bulk of the benefits accrue to the traditional stores, in the form of more sales, operating efficiencies and better customer service. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, she said,	 Evie Black Dykema, author of the report from Forrester, came to a different conclusion on this point, suggesting that most of a company's online investments do pay off in the form of Web sales. Yet the fact remains, she said, that the offline impact of a Web site is often overlooked. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, she said,	 Still, she said, a growing number of retailers are starting to delve into the fuzzy science known in industry circles as ``ROI analysis.'' ROI stands for return on investment. Among those that are further along than most, Dykema said, are merchants with a catalog pedigree, because ``they've operated their businesses by the numbers for years.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 For instance, Forgan said, the company surveys customers in its stores a few times a year to determine whether they have researched certain Sharper Image products on the Web before buying. And product codes online are different from those in the catalog, he said, so if a customer calls to place an order and uses the Web product number, the Web site is credited with a percentage of that sale. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, she says,	 LEONE _ Behind the Census numbers showing growth among older Americans is Leone Good. The 88-year-old has worked all her life, and has no plans to quit. If she stopped, she says, she'd end up like the people at the nursing home where she works. Older faces are nothing new at places like Wal-Mart, known for its grandfatherly greeters. But here's a woman taking care of ``old folks'' who are younger than she is. (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, they said,	 The fun began in 1999 when Prix Ars jurors bypassed hundreds of official entries to pick their own nominee: Linux, an alternative to Microsoft's computer operating system. The choice, they said, would start a discussion on whether computer code could be considered as art. Jurors took a similar route last year, ignoring the official submissions and instead honoring Neal Stephenson, a science-fiction author whose vision of cyberspace has inspired software developers. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 The change clarifies what the Prix Ars voters have long understood, said one juror, Bruno Beusch, co-founder of TNC Network, a new-media concern in Paris. The award, he said, ``is not an arts prize, but a prize for the whole spectrum of innovative activities on and with the Internet.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 For example, he said, jurors liked the Warp Records site because it showed how a small music label could use the Net to sell its wares and stay independent. PrayStation, by the New York artist Joshua Davis, was praised not so much for its graphic-design experiments as for its educational and community-building elements. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Noting that two of the finalists were computer games, he said, ``A game engine doesn't change the way I experience art, even when there is a clever interface.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

Not to worry. It could just be the latest in backpacker accessories.  MERCHANTS TRY TO ACCESS WEB SALES  When there were still enough Internet retailers around for bricks-and-mortar merchants to sneer at, the catch phrase of condescension went something like this: ``In my company, we have to worry about a little thing called profit.'' But as Internet retailing has dwindled mainly to the extensions of the old-line merchants, ideas about e-profitability have become more nuanced.  CANADIAN BANKS BEAT EXPECTATIONS  Despite a rocky quarter, Canadian banks reported earnings that, while not the reports of recent years, topped analyst estimates in all but one case.  TABLOIDS SQUABBLE IN NAME-CALLING  An entertaining skirmish broke out at the fringes of New York City's tabloid newspaper war last week. With all the verve of children yowling ``I'm the king of the castle,'' The New York Post and The Daily News vied for the title of king of the crybaby concept.  AN ACCUSATION OF ONLINE PLAGIARISM  Ken Layne, a columnist with The Online Journalism Review, at the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication, went to the Web last week to shame a Business Week Online reporter whom, he believed, had stolen his work without credit. Bob Arnold, the editor of Business Week Online, said Layne ``is exaggerating.''  TV'S 2 HOURS AT THE OK CORRAL  On Wednesday night, CBS and NBC will go head to head for two hours with heavily promoted reality shows. This will be only the first confrontation in what is shaping up as a season-long chess match between the two networks.  JAPAN WARNED ABOUT SPENDING  The Japanese finance minister warned against a huge government spending package to prop up the economy.  SINGAPORE AIRLINES WITHDRAWS BID  Singapore Airlines has dropped its bid for a stake in Air-India, citing political opposition to the sale, the slowing economy and its plans to invest in the southwest Pacific.  KMART ENDS PRICE PROMOTION  Kmart has removed ``Dare to Compare'' price promotions from its stores after a rival, Target, had filed a lawsuit accusing the retailer of lying to consumers with the advertising.  A BREAK FOR WALL STREET  The markets are closed Monday for Labor Day. They will reopen on Tuesday. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010902.0123 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-COX-ADVISORY-ESPORTS-0903) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTN. (Andrew Testa/The New York Times)Mags Out/No Sales  (NYT13) NEW YORK --NY-COURTROOM-WEAPONS-2 -- Some three million people walk through the metal detectors in New York City's criminal court buildings each year. With potential weapons intercepted by the bushel, court visitors are invited to retrieve their property upon leaving. There is no exact count of the weapons retrieved, but each year, the officers destroy boxes of the ones left behind. A court officer in Manhattan uses a metal detector to screen people visiting the courthouse. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- NY-COURTROOM-WEAPONS -- Some three million people walk through the metal detectors in New York City's criminal court buildings each year. There is no exact count of the weapons retrieved, but each year, the officers destroy boxes of the ones left behind. Some of the weapons found or confiscated by court officers in New York City Criminal buildings. , he said,	 Defining which species belong in an ecosystem is based less on science than on historical, cultural, moral, geographic and theological arguments, said Dr. Mark Sagoff, who studies the issue at the University of Maryland's Institute for Philosophy and Public Policy. , it said,	 Even the Library of Congress when it announced that Billy Collins had been appointed its poet laureate used the dreaded phrase. Collins' work, it said, was ``widely accessible,'' a description Collins dislikes because, as he has said in interviews since his appointment, it makes him seem like a hero of the ``poetically handicapped.'' He simply does not believe that poetry must be difficult, and his fans (they include the likes of John Updike and Annie Proulx) love him for it. In keeping with that popular tone, Random House compares this new collection to a singer's album of ``greatest hits.'' Most of this work comes from four previous collections, with 20 new poems at the end of the book. We've read them all, and while we don't believe poetry must be difficult, we enjoy a challenge or a little weight now and again. We didn't find much here. Maybe accessibility is not for everyone. Collins' predecessors at the Library of Congress include Rita Dove, Randall Jarrell, Robert Lowell, Maxine Kumin and Robert Penn Warren. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010904.0040 type=story > <HEADLINE> BC-NEW&AMP;NOTABLE-AZR(a) </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-NEW&AMP;NOTABLE-AZR) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, it said,	 Even the Library of Congress when it announced that Billy Collins had been appointed its poet laureate used the dreaded phrase. Collins' work, it said, was ``widely accessible,'' a description Collins dislikes because, as he has said in interviews since his appointment, it makes him seem like a hero of the ``poetically handicapped.'' He simply does not believe that poetry must be difficult, and his fans (they include the likes of John Updike and Annie Proulx) love him for it. In keeping with that popular tone, Random House compares this new collection to a singer's album of ``greatest hits.'' Most of this work comes from four previous collections, with 20 new poems at the end of the book. We've read them all, and while we don't believe poetry must be difficult, we enjoy a challenge or a little weight now and again. We didn't find much here. Maybe accessibility is not for everyone. Collins' predecessors at the Library of Congress include Rita Dove, Randall Jarrell, Robert Lowell, Maxine Kumin and Robert Penn Warren. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010904.0041 type=story > <HEADLINE> BC-MORMONOLY-AZR(a) </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-MORMONOLY-AZR) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he says,	 The latest fad among French parents this ``rentree(acute on second e)'' (start of classes) is insurance to protect children against bullying and extortion rackets by their fellow pupils. If you have any questions, please call Tom Uhler, John Yearwood, Lou Hudson or Libby Afflerbach on the Star-Telegram's National/International Desk at (817) 390-7784 or (817) 390-7785.  (Visit the Star-Telegram's online services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com)  P O L I T I C S  GRAMM-IMPACT  AUSTIN, Texas _ What U.S, Sen. Phil Gramm's announcement that he won't seek re-election does to the Texas political scene. At least two popular Democrats, Dallas Mayor Ron Kirk and former state Attorney General Dan Morales, have voiced interest in the job, and Gramm's formal declaration may trigger a scramble. Byline TK. Story will move in ``p'' political category.  SANCHEZ-GOVERNOR  (Dateline TK) _ South Texas millionaire Tony Sanchez ended months of speculation and announced before a hometown crowd Tuesday that he is running for governor. ``Some are going to be tempted to call this a campaign of firsts,'' Sanchez said. ``I am not running to be first in anything. I am running to make sure Texas is first in everything.'' If elected in 2002, Sanchez would be the first Hispanic governor of Texas. By JAY ROOT. Story will move in ``p'' political category.  N A T I O N A L / T E X A S  BOTULISM-CHILI  FORT WORTH, Texas _ Developments in the chili recall. Another botulism case reported. Developing. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  LOCKED-GIRL  DALLAS _ Grandparents of 8-year-old girl who was kept locked in a closet are seeking custody of her; Dallas hearing scheduled today. Byline TK. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  BEATENBABY  IRVING, Texas _ Irving baby who police say had been severly beaten dies. Mother will be rearraigned on capital murder charges. Developing. By DOMINGO RAMIREZ. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  HOSPITAL-STUDY  AUSTIN, Texas _ With a few computer keystrokes, a state agency could generate a first-ever profile of medical care that could help Texans choose their hospitals. Heart bypass patients could find facilities that perform the most surgeries and have the lowest mortality rates. Expectant mothers could check the frequency of Caesarean sections. Large companies could contract with hospitals best suited to handle their employees' needs. Staff members at the Texas Health Care Information Council had initially planned to release the first hospital-by-hospital performance reports by last summer. But a series of delays, including a recent request by two advisory committees for more study, has postponed release of the reports to at least March _ seven years after the Legislature created the agency. By CHARLOTTE HUFF. Story will move in ``n'' regional category for Texas points only.  TRASH-FOR-CHARITIES  UNDATED: For Goodwill workers, the stained mattresses and broken refrigerators were insult enough. Then one day, in suburban Fort Worth, someone dropped off a 55-gallon barrel of toxic chemicals. A hazardous materials crew had to haul the poison away. ``That's why they dump it after hours,'' said David Cox, director of community relations for Goodwill. ``It's the charity that has to clean it up.'' Goodwill's trouble is among the worst examples of a trend that is tormenting charities nationwide. People increasingly use collection centers to dump bulky, bothersome trash. By JOSH SHAFFER. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  LABBE-COLUMN  UNDATED: Wallace Bowman kept telling himself he couldn't possibly be an alcoholic. As a judge who has sat across the bench from thousands of people whose substance abuse problems led to legal problems, Bowman couldn't see himself in the tattered bodies and tortured lives that passed through his courtroom. ``The second-hardest thing I've ever done is coming to grips with being an alcoholic,'' said Bowman, tall and lean in a well-cut navy suit, his full head of salt-and-pepper hair neatly trimmed. ``The first was admitting to my wife what happened that night.'' By J.R. LABBE. Story will move in ``k'' commentary category.  L I F E S T Y L E  20-MINUTE-ARTIST  UNDATED: Give your up-do an Asian flair with a bejeweled hair ornament. Short. By BEVERLY BUNDY. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  SLAIN-INTHE-SPIRIT  UNDATED: Tina Pace was skeptical and afraid as she watched Christians line up at the church altar for prayer and then fall down dramatically. Pace had been raised in a Baptist church that dismissed the phenomenon of being ``slain in the Spirit.'' But after she met her husband, Jerry, who had grown up in a church that embraced the religious experience, Pace said she unexpectedly wilted to the floor during a 1993 revival service at a rural Texas Pentecostal church. She says that just before she was slain, she had been filled with the Holy Spirit and was speaking in tongues. By BRETT HOFFMAN. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  CHAPTER&AMP;VERSE  UNDATED: Mini-reviews of a book and a CD: `Hidden Gospels' and `God (AT) Work'. By ALAN COCHRUM and JOSH SHAFFER. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  E N T E R T A I N M E N T  BOOKS-`BROWN-VS-BOARD'  UNDATED: The legacy of ``Brown'' cannot be summed up in simple terms. ``Sometimes I wonder if we really did the children and the nation a favor by taking this case to the Supreme Court,'' historian James T. Patterson quotes one woman as saying in ``Brown v. Board of Education.'' ``I know it was the right thing for my father and others to do then. But after nearly 40 years we find the Court's ruling unfulfilled.'' By ALAN COCHRUM. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  BOOKS-`HOTHOUSE'  UNDATED: Keetenheuve is a thinker and a dreamer, an unreasonable man in a too reasonable world, ``a dilettante in politics'' and thus singularly ill-suited to be, as he is, a member of the Bundestag, the lower house of the West German parliament. Yet, as Wolfgang Koeppen makes clear in this excellent novel, he is just the sort of person needed by his country, in the midst of its ``economic miracle,'' even if no one bothers to listen to him. By JAY GOLDIN. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  BOOKS-`AVA'S-MAN'  UNDATED: Thanks to all the thrillers we read, it's hard not to think of heroes as infinitely larger than life, playing out their lavish adventures in glamorous, awe-inspiring settings. But if life is so small and tight it leaves you gasping for breath, how can you be heroic then? Pulitzer-Prize winning journalist Rick Bragg shows us how in his latest memoir, a follow-up to the acclaimed ``All Over But the Shoutin'.'' By LEV RAPHAEL. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  BOOKS-`ARTIST'  UNDATED: Despite its tongue-twisting, Tom Wolfe-evoking title that could impede a movie deal, Dan Jenkins' new golf novel is estimable on a number of levels. ``The Money-Whipped Steer-Job Three-Jack Give-Up Artist'' is awash with tantalizing metaphors. Not all are printable in this gazette, though it can be revealed that ``steer-job'' is a method of coaxing one's tee shot down a narrow fairway and ``three-jack'' means three putts. The book dishes wondrous dirt on professional golf and golfers and the author's hometown, Fort Worth, Texas. It comments with laudable candor on life, love, sex, golf course architecture and nouvelle cuisine. It even provides self-help hints for those afflicted with ``the Scottish Madness.'' By PERRY STEWART. Story will be double-filed in ``e'' entertainment and ``s'' sports categories.  BOOKS-`UNDEFEATED'  UNDATED: Jim Dent, the author of ``The Undefeated: The Oklahoma Sooners and the Greatest Winning Streak in College Football,'' can be called the consummate sports writer. But Dent, 48, thinks his books are as much about sociology as sports. By JEFF GUINN. Story will be double-filed in ``e'' entertainment and ``s'' sports categories.  MOVIES-KELLY-COLUMN  UNDATED: The summer movie season is over, and this critic is breathing a sigh of relief. Week after week of empty-headed spectacles like ``Planet of the Apes'' and ``Evolution'' can wear a guy down. Not that I think this summer was all that bad for movies. In fact _ provided you knew where to look _ pleasures abounded. By CHRISTOPHER KELLY. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  OBROTHER-MUSIC  UNDATED: When local country radio station KTFW/92.1 FM fired up the soundtrack to ``O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' for the first time last year, Mike Crow had no idea he'd still be firing it up today. ``It just came out of nowhere and caught on,'' says Crow, KTFW's station manager and morning show host. ``It was popular from Day One. And we still have it in our rotation. Fads come and go, but this has stuck around.'' To date, the bluegrass-driven soundtrack, which was produced by Fort Worth-reared T-Bone Burnett, has sold more than 2 million copies. After being released in winter 2000, the CD is still at the top of the country charts and remains a top seller on Internet sites such as Amazon.com and CDNOW.com. By MALCOLM MAYHEW. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  LOST-AND-FOUND  UNDATED: Jerry Bruckheimer has become a rich man by producing movies in which men are men, women are women, stuff blows up and brains aren't challenged. So it's no wonder that CBS' ``The Amazing Race,'' a reality show produced by Bruckheimer, looks like ``Survivor'' with the dull parts removed. No pompous introspection (well, very little). No sanctimonious ``giving back to the land.'' No Jeff Probst ``tallying'' four votes. Just people zooming around the world, bickering and celebrating as they hit checkpoints to find clues, which will lead them to the next exotic place, and on and on until the first team back in New York wins a million bucks. It's one of two similar reality series premiering Wednesday night, the other being NBC's ``LOST,'' which doesn't have nearly the energy of ``The Amazing Race.'' By ROBERT PHILPOT. , he says,	 Aczel goes back to the Bible to explore the origins of the use of the four cardinal directions. The Etruscans, he says, were responsible for the appearance in the Renaissance of the diagrams known as wind roses, used in compasses to this day. Their Etruscan design, based on divination practices, led to the common 16-point navigation system, each point representing a different wind direction. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he writes,	 A 12-point system, he writes, was devised by one Aristotle Timosthenes, ``a sailor-scholar who lived around 250 B.C. and was chosen by Ptolemy II, king of Egypt, to be the chief pilot of his navy.'' But Aczel recognizes that the compass was invented not in Europe but in China, though he speculates that it was used there largely for feng shui _ the Chinese art of positioning objects according to the flow of spiritual energies _ and not for navigation. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For questions about photos, call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  ENTERTAINMENT &AMP; ARTS (Coded `e')  FILM  FILM-WIZARDS _ The release of two fantasy films, ``The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' on Dec. 19 and ``Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' on Nov. 16 may make this the winter of the wizard. It is only the beginning. The director, Peter Jackson, filmed two more feature in the Hobbit series simultaneously. That meant actors like Elijah Wood, who plays the hobbit, assorted elves (Cate Blanchett, Orlando Bloom, Liv Tyler) and human warriors (Viggo Mortensen, Sean Bean) lived for a year in Middle Earth. By Polly Shulman.  With photo.  FILM-VIETNAM-GREENE (Hanoi, Vietnam) _ The filming of Graham Greene's novel ``The Quiet American'' is the most ambitious film project made in Vietnam since the war ended in 1975. On its surface, it is the story of a love triangle involving a naive American secret agent, a world-weary English journalist and a determined Vietnamese woman. The book, published in 1955, is read today as a prescient warning of the American involvement in Vietnam. As for Michael Caine, who plays the journalist, he says journalists will be pleased. ``I get the girl and I get the story. What more do you want?'' By Seth Mydans.  With photo.  FILM-GOSFORD-ALTMAN (London) _ In ``Gosford Park,'' Robert Altman casts an American eye on the English class system during a weekend shooting party in 1932. The film has no starring roles, but some of the extras include the aristocrats of British drama: Sir Michael Gambon, Sir Derek Jacobi, Dame Eileen Atkins, and Dame Maggie Smith, plus Alan Bates, Kristin Scott Thomas, Emily Watson and Charles Dance. The film opens Dec. 7. By Kristin Hohenadel.  With photo.  FILM-ALI-MANN (New York) _ Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. It's about the real Ali, Mann says. ``We show him at his best, defying the U.S. government, refusing to be inducted into the Army and losing three and a half years of his career for it. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' By Allen Barra.  With photo.  FILM-BANYAN-DILLON (Kampot, Cambodia) _ ``Under the Banyan Trees'' is what Matt Dillon calls an ``atmospheric thriller'' set in post-holocaust Cambodia. Robert Turnbull interviews Dillon, the writer, director and actor, in Cambodia where anecdotes of bizarre filming conditions abound. Dillon plays a New York insurance con man who goes to Cambodia in pursuit of a Vietnam veteran who owes him money. He encounters colorful characters (Gerard DePardieu and Stellan Skarsgard) along the road to the film's denouement in a faceoff against James Caan's corrupt expatriate.  With photo.  FILM-HOUSE (Undated) _ A hard-to-love son with blue-streaked hair and a hard-to-love and perpetually unshaven father appear to be lost causes, but in the second-chance narrative, they aren't. Molly Haskell takes a look at this genre pegged to the new film, ``Life as a House,'' starring Kevin Kline, as a once-gifted architect, who kidnaps his estranged son in the hope of enlisting his help in rebuilding a house.  With photo.  FILM-IRIS (Southwold, England) _ What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. The script shows a couple having to find a language beyond words. Judi Dench plays the older Murdoch and Kate Winslet plays her as a young woman. By Matt Wolf.  With photo.  TELEVISION  TV-BICKFORD-DREYFUSS (Pasadena, Calif.) _ When CBS began talking to Richard Dreyfuss about a television series, the 53-year-old actor told CBS he wanted to play a man of his own age ``who's uncertain about his whole life, who's having a midlife crisis, who's not sure how to deal with women, work, sex, money.'' ``I wanted to play _ me,'' he said. The result is ``The Education of Max Bickford,'' a new Sunday drama series that starts Sept. 23 in the high-profile 8 p.m. time slot following ``60 Minutes.'' By Bernard Weinraub.  MUSIC  OPERA-WAR&AMP;PEACE (New York) _ There are 27 operas based on the works of Leo Tolstoy, but the best known is Sergei Prokofiev's ``War and Peace,'' which is being performed in February at the Metropolitan Opera. It's a tall order, perhaps the tallest for any opera house to mount. Even after winnowing most of the novel away, Prokofiev was left with 71 solo roles, a chorus; 13 scenes, each requiring a set; and a running time of more than four hours. By Richard Taruskin.  MUSIC-MACY-GRAY (New York ) _ Macy Gray, the singer-songwriter whose 1999 debut album, ``On How Life Is,'' has sold three million copies in the United States, is releasing ``The Id'' on Sept. 18. The album got its title, she said, because a friend once described her as ``all id.'' Then, Gray said, ``I remembered my Psychology 101 class. The album is very automatic, spontaneous, a kind of pouring out of whatever.'' By Jon Pareles.  ART  TV-ART21 (New York) _ ``Art21: Art in the 21st Century,'' will be broadcast on PBS on Sept. 21 and 28. By getting rid of narrators, ``Art21'' has changed the genre of art on television. Behind the camera is Susan Sollins, a founder and former executive director of Independent Curators International, who inaudibly and invisibly prodded the artists to tell their stories. By Kay Larson.  With photo.  TRAVEL  (Coded `t')  TRAVEL-COLONIAL-VIETNAM (Undated) _ In search of Vietnam's colonial past, Catherine Texier found grand hotels, a post office designed by Gustave Eiffel, a classroom of girls singing ``Alouette, Gentille Alouette,'' men in berets and restaurants serving croissants and creme caramel.  TRAVEL-VIETNAM-CAFES (Undated) _ Vietnam has a cafe culture to rival Italy's, but it's not about people-watching or food. It's about coffee, because unlike the rest of Asia, Vietnam is a coffee drinking country. By Katherine Zoepf.  With 500-word box and photo.  TRAVEL-VIETNAM-ART-COPIERS (Undated) _ Day and night in open shopfronts in the central shopping district of Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, men and women with paintbrushes are turning out reproduction masterpieces. Van Gogh's sunflowers sell for $50 or $60, Impressionists are easy, say the painters, and therefore cheap. If you want, the enigmatic Mona Lisa can be ordered frowning or giggling. By Seth Mydans.  TRAVEL-WHALE-WATCHING (Undated) _ Whale watching worldwide now accounts for $1 billion in spending each year by more than nine million people who take part in excursions from almost 90 countries, according to a report published in July. By John Cushman Jr.  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) _ With a son who loves roller coasters, the more dangerous the better, Susan Gilbert began researching to find out if her fears were justified. She found some news reassuring and some not so reassuring.  TRAVEL-BRIEFS (Undated) _ A Web operation, www.airportparkinglots.com, is offering guaranteed reserved parking at more than 40 airports in the United States and Canada. Plus items on exhibitions in Toronto, Chicago and Lafayette, La.  TRAVEL-CYBER (Undated) _ Travel Medicine experts advise using the Web to prepare for potential medical emergencies before leaving on a trip. By Bob Tedeschi.  TRAVEL-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Answers to questions about child-friendly tours to Japan, the Camino pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela and cruises that allow pets. By Florence Stickney. , he said,	 As more people move more of their lives onto the Internet, Westin explained, longstanding boundaries between the groups have shifted. Until the 1990s, he said, those in the unconcerned group made up about 20 percent of the population, and privacy fundamentalists stood at about 25 percent; the pragmatists occupied the middle 55 percent. But a recent poll by Westin showed that the group of unconcerned Americans had shrunk by nearly half, to just 12 percent of the population; the people who shifted, in general, joined the ranks of the pragmatists: not radicalized, but more wary than before. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, she announces,	 The other museums she visits are the Kimbell in Fort Worth; the  Metropolitan in New York; the Los Angeles County Museum of Art; The Art  Institute of Chicago; and the Cleveland Museum of Art. , they argue,	 Think Napster, they say. The search engines, they argue, are enabling computer users to pilfer online art, since they can use the search sites to view and download images without setting foot on the artists' sites. , they say,	 In the Ditto.com case, the result may hinge on how the court considers at least two tricky issues. The first is whether search engines are, in subtle ways, inviting people to copy images. Most artists do not want people copying images from their sites _ they want visitors who have an interest in hiring them for their services. Search engines, they say, expose their sites to people who are merely interested in finding a picture to copy and paste. When search engines display images without permission and out of context, they argue, they are paving the way for infringement. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
