, I think,	 ``I grew up in a colonial society in Africa in the '50s and '60s, and I couldn't boil an egg for myself until I went to university,'' Grant said. ``I can clearly remember the paternalistic, feudal attitude that goes through any kind of master-servant relationship. You hear people say, `Oh, I couldn't live without my housekeeper, I absolutely adore my maid.' They may see them as a servile extension of their family, but, I think, rare are the cases where people have actually left money to servants. The employer very often feels that they have lifelong loyalty from people who are their servants, and they don't. It was just a job. You think this person does actually care for you because they've either dressed you or bathed you or fed you or done everything for you, but the reality of it is that servants are as opportunistic and upwardly mobile as anybody else.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

(NYT49) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-3 -- Rep. John Langevin, a paraplegic with a damaged spine, testified before the Senate Wednesday in favor of stem cell research. A Democrat from Rhode Island who was first elected last year, Langevin was greeted by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., Susan Collins, R-Me., Judd Gregg, R-N.H., Bill Frist, R-Tenn., and Jack Reed, D-R.I. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT48) TUCSON, Ariz. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- SCI-EPHEDRA-DEATHS -- A consumer advocacy group and a prominent pharmacologist filed a petition Wednesday asking the Food and Drug Administration to ban dietary supplements containing the stimulant ephedra, saying that reports of illness from the supplements had doubled in recent years, reaching 407 in 1999. Ephedra has been linked to deaths, strokes, heart attacks and other health problems. Dr. Raymond Woosley, a pharmagologist at the University of Arizona, wants controls on ephedra. Woosley at the University of Arizona in Tucson. (University of Arizona/The New York Times) MAGS OUT--NO SALES  (NYT47) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III-2 -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. In Washington, Mozelle W. Thompson, a member of the Federal Trade Commission says companies will have to prove to consumers that giving up privacy is a trade that will not have nasty surprises. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT46) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. Marc Rotenberg of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington says the nation needs a legal framework on how these technologies are used. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT45) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TV-FOX-ZAHN -- The Fox News Channel on Wednesday fired Paula Zahn, center, one of its prime-time talk show hosts, after learning that she had received an offer from CNN. The move is the latest escalation in an increasingly bitter fight for supremacy in cable television news. Zahn meeting with producers in New York in July. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT44) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS-2 -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. At a midday service, the monks at New Melleray Abbey attend to their main task, prayer. (Andy Manis/The New York Times)  (NYT43) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. (The New York Times)  (NYT31) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-GEEK-NOTES-2 -- Keyboards are, by definition, touchy-feely. Microsoft's new model, called the Microsoft Office Keyboard takes advantage of previously mouse-intensive operations. The keyboard has also been designed to take fuller advantage of Microsoft's operating system called Windows XP. (The New York Times)  (NYT30) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-GEEK-NOTES -- The 50-pound Butter Palm VII PDA sculpture, left, from this year's Minnesota State Fair is for sale at eBay. The $500 Sony eVilla Internet appliance, which was introduced in the United States in June, has been withdrawn from the market. Screenshots of the Butter Palm VII PDA and  the Sony EVilla. (The New York Times)  (NYT29) CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- KIM-MUSIC -- As a composer and a teacher of composers, Earl Kim maintained that every sound in a piece should be faithful to the composer's sensibilities. Kim, who died in 1998 at 78, lived during an era of contention and dogma in contemporary music, a challenging time, he knew, for composers to cultivate their musical identity. Kim at his home in Cambridge, Mass., in 1989. (Lilian Kemp/New World Records/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY ANTHONY TOMMASINI ENTITLED ``KIM-MUSIC'' MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT28) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-HISTORICAL-GAMES-2 -- Strategy games like Civilization III, a computer game that puts gamers in the position of building an empire over centuries, are among the best-selling PC titles. A screen shot from the PC strategy game, Civiliaztion III. (The New York Times)ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY DAVID KUSHNER ENTITLED ``CIR-HISTORICAL-GAMES'' MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT26) IRVINE, Calif. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-IMAGE-SEARCHES -- Today, anyone on the Web can gain access to a trove of images. But to make such gawking possible, search engines must make a copy of every image they come across, whether they have permission to do so or not. These images are then displayed in the search engine's results listings without approval from the creators. In Irvine, Calif., photographer Leslie A. Kelly, right, and his lawyer, Steven Krongold, contend that a search engine hijacked his photos. (Marissa Roth/The New York Times)  (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- NY-MODEL-HOMES-3 -- Country Home magazine has sponsored the building of two model homes inside Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. In Grand Central Terminal, workers are in front of a model farmhouse. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS-2 -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. Murdoch at home with her husband, John Bayley, in 1998 in Oxford, England. (Jonathan Player/The New York Times)  (NYT19) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. The script shows a couple having to find a language beyond words. Judi Dench plays the author Iris Murdoch, and Jim Broadbent is her husband, John Bayley, in ``Iris.'' (Clive Coote/Mirimax Films) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MATT WOLF ENTITLED ``FILM-IRIS.''  (NYT18) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' Ali during a photo shoot in New York earlier this year. (Fred R. In the new operating system, the Start menu, top, is now a better organized. Below, an annoying feature, everyone using the system, even if only one person, needs to log on. (NYT49) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-3 -- Rep. John Langevin, a paraplegic with a damaged spine, testified before the Senate Wednesday in favor of stem cell research. A Democrat from Rhode Island who was first elected last year, Langevin was greeted by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., Susan Collins, R-Me., Judd Gregg, R-N.H., Bill Frist, R-Tenn., and Jack Reed, D-R.I. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT48) TUCSON, Ariz. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- SCI-EPHEDRA-DEATHS -- A consumer advocacy group and a prominent pharmacologist filed a petition Wednesday asking the Food and Drug Administration to ban dietary supplements containing the stimulant ephedra, saying that reports of illness from the supplements had doubled in recent years, reaching 407 in 1999. Ephedra has been linked to deaths, strokes, heart attacks and other health problems. Dr. Raymond Woosley, a pharmagologist at the University of Arizona, wants controls on ephedra. Woosley at the University of Arizona in Tucson. (University of Arizona/The New York Times) MAGS OUT--NO SALES  (NYT47) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III-2 -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. In Washington, Mozelle W. Thompson, a member of the Federal Trade Commission says companies will have to prove to consumers that giving up privacy is a trade that will not have nasty surprises. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT46) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. Marc Rotenberg of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington says the nation needs a legal framework on how these technologies are used. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT45) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TV-FOX-ZAHN -- The Fox News Channel on Wednesday fired Paula Zahn, center, one of its prime-time talk show hosts, after learning that she had received an offer from CNN. The move is the latest escalation in an increasingly bitter fight for supremacy in cable television news. Zahn meeting with producers in New York in July. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT44) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS-2 -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. At a midday service, the monks at New Melleray Abbey attend to their main task, prayer. (Andy Manis/The New York Times)  (NYT43) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. Some critics fault such games for departing from historical accounts of world events while the makers acknowledge that their purpose is to entertain. A screen shot from the PC strategy game, Civiliaztion III. (The New York Times)ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY DAVID KUSHNER ENTITLED ``CIR-HISTORICAL-GAMES'' MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT27) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-HISTORICAL-GAMES -- Strategy games like Civilization III, a computer game that puts gamers in the position of building an empire over centuries, are among the best-selling PC titles. Some critics fault such games for departing from historical accounts of world events while the makers acknowledge that their purpose is to entertain. An undated photo of game designer Sid Meier. (The New York Times)ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY DAVID KUSHNER ENTITLED ``CIR-HISTORICAL-GAMES'' MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT26) IRVINE, Calif. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-IMAGE-SEARCHES -- Today, anyone on the Web can gain access to a trove of images. But to make such gawking possible, search engines must make a copy of every image they come across, whether they have permission to do so or not. These images are then displayed in the search engine's results listings without approval from the creators. In Irvine, Calif., photographer Leslie A. Kelly, right, and his lawyer, Steven Krongold, contend that a search engine hijacked his photos. (Marissa Roth/The New York Times)  (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- NY-MODEL-HOMES-3 -- Country Home magazine has sponsored the building of two model homes inside Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. The 1,300-square-foot penthouse, which rises to 20 feet at one corner, has ``rice-paper'' walls rendered with a metal grid sandwiched between two layers of Kalwall, a sturdy translucent fiberglass. In Grand Central Terminal, workers are in front of a model farmhouse. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)  (NYT24) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- NY-MODEL-HOMES-2 -- Country Home magazine has sponsored the building of two model homes inside Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS-2 -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. Murdoch at home with her husband, John Bayley, in 1998 in Oxford, England. (Jonathan Player/The New York Times)  (NYT19) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. The script shows a couple having to find a language beyond words. Judi Dench plays the author Iris Murdoch, and Jim Broadbent is her husband, John Bayley, in ``Iris.'' (Clive Coote/Mirimax Films) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MATT WOLF ENTITLED ``FILM-IRIS.''  (NYT18) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-HOUSE -- A hard-to-love son with blue-streaked hair and a hard-to-love and perpetually unshaven father appear to be lost causes, but in the second-chance narrative, they aren't. Molly Haskell takes a look at this genre pegged to the new film, ``Life as a House,'' starring Kevin Kline, as a once-gifted architect, who kidnaps his estranged son in the hope of enlisting his help in rebuilding a house. Kline in ``Life as a House'' directed by Irwin Winkler, which opens in October. (M.W. Wallace/New Line Cinema/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MOLLY HASKELL ENTITLED ``FILM-HOUSE.''  (NYT15) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-ALI-MANN-2 -- Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. It's about the real Ali, Mann says. ``We show him at his best, defying the U.S. government, refusing to be inducted into the Army and losing three and a half years of his career for it. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' Ali during a photo shoot in New York earlier this year. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)  (NYT14) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-ALI-MANN -- Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-BANYAN-DILLON-2 -- ``Under the Banyan Trees'' is what Matt Dillon calls an ``atmospheric thriller'' set in post-holocaust Cambodia. He encounters colorful characters along the road to the film's denouement in a faceoff against a corrupt expatriate. (NYT49) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-3 -- Rep. John Langevin, a paraplegic with a damaged spine, testified before the Senate Wednesday in favor of stem cell research. A Democrat from Rhode Island who was first elected last year, Langevin was greeted by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., Susan Collins, R-Me., Judd Gregg, R-N.H., Bill Frist, R-Tenn., and Jack Reed, D-R.I. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT48) TUCSON, Ariz. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- SCI-EPHEDRA-DEATHS -- A consumer advocacy group and a prominent pharmacologist filed a petition Wednesday asking the Food and Drug Administration to ban dietary supplements containing the stimulant ephedra, saying that reports of illness from the supplements had doubled in recent years, reaching 407 in 1999. Ephedra has been linked to deaths, strokes, heart attacks and other health problems. Dr. Raymond Woosley, a pharmagologist at the University of Arizona, wants controls on ephedra. Woosley at the University of Arizona in Tucson. (University of Arizona/The New York Times) MAGS OUT--NO SALES  (NYT47) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III-2 -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. In Washington, Mozelle W. Thompson, a member of the Federal Trade Commission says companies will have to prove to consumers that giving up privacy is a trade that will not have nasty surprises. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT46) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. Marc Rotenberg of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington says the nation needs a legal framework on how these technologies are used. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT45) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TV-FOX-ZAHN -- The Fox News Channel on Wednesday fired Paula Zahn, center, one of its prime-time talk show hosts, after learning that she had received an offer from CNN. The move is the latest escalation in an increasingly bitter fight for supremacy in cable television news. Zahn meeting with producers in New York in July. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT44) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS-2 -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. At a midday service, the monks at New Melleray Abbey attend to their main task, prayer. (Andy Manis/The New York Times)  (NYT43) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. Kim at his home in Cambridge, Mass., in 1989. Murdoch at home with her husband, John Bayley, in 1998 in Oxford, England. (Jonathan Player/The New York Times)  (NYT19) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. The script shows a couple having to find a language beyond words. Judi Dench plays the author Iris Murdoch, and Jim Broadbent is her husband, John Bayley, in ``Iris.'' (Clive Coote/Mirimax Films) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MATT WOLF ENTITLED ``FILM-IRIS.''  (NYT18) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-GOSFORD-ALTMAN-2 -- In ``Gosford Park,'' Robert Altman casts an American eye on the English class system during a weekend shooting party in 1932. The film has no starring roles, but some of the extras include the aristocrats of British drama. Altman on the set of ``Gosford Park,'' juggling 44-speaking roles. The film opens Dec. 7. (Mark Tillie/USA Films/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY KRISTIN HOHENADEL ENTITLED ``FILM-GOSFORD-ALTMAN.''  (NYT17) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-GOSFORD-ALTMAN -- In ``Gosford Park,'' Robert Altman casts an American eye on the English class system during a weekend shooting party in 1932. The film has no starring roles, but some of the extras include the aristocrats of British drama. From left, Natasha Wightman, Tom Hollander, Claudie Blakley, Sir Michael Gambon, Geraldine Somerville and Kristin Scott Thomas in ``Gosford Park'' which opens Dec. 7. (Mark Tillie/USA Films/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY KRISTIN HOHENADEL ENTITLED ``FILM-GOSFORD-ALTMAN.''  (NYT16) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-HOUSE -- A hard-to-love son with blue-streaked hair and a hard-to-love and perpetually unshaven father appear to be lost causes, but in the second-chance narrative, they aren't. Molly Haskell takes a look at this genre pegged to the new film, ``Life as a House,'' starring Kevin Kline, as a once-gifted architect, who kidnaps his estranged son in the hope of enlisting his help in rebuilding a house. Kline in ``Life as a House'' directed by Irwin Winkler, which opens in October. (M.W. Wallace/New Line Cinema/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MOLLY HASKELL ENTITLED ``FILM-HOUSE.''  (NYT15) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-ALI-MANN-2 -- Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. It's about the real Ali, Mann says. ``We show him at his best, defying the U.S. government, refusing to be inducted into the Army and losing three and a half years of his career for it. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' Ali during a photo shoot in New York earlier this year. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)  (NYT14) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-ALI-MANN -- Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. It's about the real Ali, Mann says. ``We show him at his best, defying the U.S. government, refusing to be inducted into the Army and losing three and a half years of his career for it. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' Will Smith hoped to capture Muhammad Ali's voice, not his looks. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-BANYAN-DILLON-2 -- ``Under the Banyan Trees'' is what Matt Dillon calls an ``atmospheric thriller'' set in post-holocaust Cambodia. Dillon plays a New York insurance con man who goes to Cambodia in pursuit of a Vietnam veteran who owes him money. He encounters colorful characters along the road to the film's denouement in a faceoff against a corrupt expatriate. Gerard Depardieu, left, and Dillon at one of the 40 locations used for his film, tentatively titled ``Under the Banyan Trees.'' (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT8) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-2 -- The Bush administration acknowledged Wednesday that fewer than half the stem cell lines approved for federal funding are fully developed and ready for researchers. Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy Thompson said more cell lines will probably be ready by the time federal grants are issued next year. Thompson during his testimony Wednesday before the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee. It was the first day of school for children in the town in New York's Westchester County. Rosen, right, was able to persuade Cheng-Tzu to stay. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-CIRCUITS-COLUMN -- XP is Microsoft's attempt to merge its home line (the friendly but cranky Windows 95, 98 and Me) with its corporate line (the unattractive but rock-solid Windows NT and 2000) into a unified operating system that offers the best of both. In the new operating system, the Start menu, top, is now a better organized. Below, an annoying feature, everyone using the system, even if only one person, needs to log on. (NYT49) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-3 -- Rep. John Langevin, a paraplegic with a damaged spine, testified before the Senate Wednesday in favor of stem cell research. A Democrat from Rhode Island who was first elected last year, Langevin was greeted by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., Susan Collins, R-Me., Judd Gregg, R-N.H., Bill Frist, R-Tenn., and Jack Reed, D-R.I. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT48) TUCSON, Ariz. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- SCI-EPHEDRA-DEATHS -- A consumer advocacy group and a prominent pharmacologist filed a petition Wednesday asking the Food and Drug Administration to ban dietary supplements containing the stimulant ephedra, saying that reports of illness from the supplements had doubled in recent years, reaching 407 in 1999. Ephedra has been linked to deaths, strokes, heart attacks and other health problems. Dr. Raymond Woosley, a pharmagologist at the University of Arizona, wants controls on ephedra. Woosley at the University of Arizona in Tucson. (University of Arizona/The New York Times) MAGS OUT--NO SALES  (NYT47) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III-2 -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. In Washington, Mozelle W. Thompson, a member of the Federal Trade Commission says companies will have to prove to consumers that giving up privacy is a trade that will not have nasty surprises. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT46) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. Marc Rotenberg of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington says the nation needs a legal framework on how these technologies are used. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT45) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TV-FOX-ZAHN -- The Fox News Channel on Wednesday fired Paula Zahn, center, one of its prime-time talk show hosts, after learning that she had received an offer from CNN. The move is the latest escalation in an increasingly bitter fight for supremacy in cable television news. Zahn meeting with producers in New York in July. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT44) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS-2 -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. At a midday service, the monks at New Melleray Abbey attend to their main task, prayer. (Andy Manis/The New York Times)  (NYT43) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. (The New York Times)  (NYT29) CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- KIM-MUSIC -- As a composer and a teacher of composers, Earl Kim maintained that every sound in a piece should be faithful to the composer's sensibilities. Kim, who died in 1998 at 78, lived during an era of contention and dogma in contemporary music, a challenging time, he knew, for composers to cultivate their musical identity. Kim at his home in Cambridge, Mass., in 1989. (The New York Times)ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY DAVID KUSHNER ENTITLED ``CIR-HISTORICAL-GAMES'' MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT26) IRVINE, Calif. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-IMAGE-SEARCHES -- Today, anyone on the Web can gain access to a trove of images. But to make such gawking possible, search engines must make a copy of every image they come across, whether they have permission to do so or not. These images are then displayed in the search engine's results listings without approval from the creators. In Irvine, Calif., photographer Leslie A. Kelly, right, and his lawyer, Steven Krongold, contend that a search engine hijacked his photos. (Marissa Roth/The New York Times)  (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- NY-MODEL-HOMES-3 -- Country Home magazine has sponsored the building of two model homes inside Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. The 1,300-square-foot penthouse, which rises to 20 feet at one corner, has ``rice-paper'' walls rendered with a metal grid sandwiched between two layers of Kalwall, a sturdy translucent fiberglass. In Grand Central Terminal, workers are in front of a model farmhouse. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-BANYAN-DILLON-2 -- ``Under the Banyan Trees'' is what Matt Dillon calls an ``atmospheric thriller'' set in post-holocaust Cambodia. Dillon plays a New York insurance con man who goes to Cambodia in pursuit of a Vietnam veteran who owes him money. He encounters colorful characters along the road to the film's denouement in a faceoff against a corrupt expatriate. Gerard Depardieu, left, and Dillon at one of the 40 locations used for his film, tentatively titled ``Under the Banyan Trees.'' (Ronald Neveu/United Artists Films/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY ROBERTM TURNBULL ENTITLED ``FILM-BANYAN-DILLON.''  (NYT12) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-BANYAN-DILLON -- ``Under the Banyan Trees'' is what Matt Dillon calls an ``atmospheric thriller'' set in post-holocaust Cambodia. Dillon plays a New York insurance con man who goes to Cambodia in pursuit of a Vietnam veteran who owes him money. He encounters colorful characters along the road to the film's denouement in a faceoff against a corrupt expatriate. Dillon and a co-star at one of the 40 locations used for his film, tentatively titled ``Under the Banyan Trees.'' (Ronald Neveu/United Artists Films/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY ROBERTM TURNBULL ENTITLED ``FILM-BANYAN-DILLON.''  (NYT11) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT8) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-2 -- The Bush administration acknowledged Wednesday that fewer than half the stem cell lines approved for federal funding are fully developed and ready for researchers. Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy Thompson said more cell lines will probably be ready by the time federal grants are issued next year. Thompson during his testimony Wednesday before the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT7) SCARSDALE, N.Y. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- BACK-TO-SCHOOL -- Five-year old Cheng-Tzu Li was reluctant to stay in Diane Rosen's kindergarten classroom on her first day at Edgewood School in Scarsdale, Wednesday. It was the first day of school for children in the town in New York's Westchester County. Rosen, right, was able to persuade Cheng-Tzu to stay. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-CIRCUITS-COLUMN -- XP is Microsoft's attempt to merge its home line (the friendly but cranky Windows 95, 98 and Me) with its corporate line (the unattractive but rock-solid Windows NT and 2000) into a unified operating system that offers the best of both. In the new operating system, the Start menu, top, is now a better organized. Below, an annoying feature, everyone using the system, even if only one person, needs to log on. (The New York Times)  (NYT2) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- BUSH-FOX-MEXICO -- President Vicente Fox of Mexico startled his American hosts at the beginning of the state visit Wednesday when he called for an agreement with the United States on a migration policy by the end of the year. (NYT49) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-3 -- Rep. John Langevin, a paraplegic with a damaged spine, testified before the Senate Wednesday in favor of stem cell research. A Democrat from Rhode Island who was first elected last year, Langevin was greeted by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., Susan Collins, R-Me., Judd Gregg, R-N.H., Bill Frist, R-Tenn., and Jack Reed, D-R.I. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT48) TUCSON, Ariz. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- SCI-EPHEDRA-DEATHS -- A consumer advocacy group and a prominent pharmacologist filed a petition Wednesday asking the Food and Drug Administration to ban dietary supplements containing the stimulant ephedra, saying that reports of illness from the supplements had doubled in recent years, reaching 407 in 1999. Ephedra has been linked to deaths, strokes, heart attacks and other health problems. Dr. Raymond Woosley, a pharmagologist at the University of Arizona, wants controls on ephedra. Woosley at the University of Arizona in Tucson. (University of Arizona/The New York Times) MAGS OUT--NO SALES  (NYT47) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III-2 -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. In Washington, Mozelle W. Thompson, a member of the Federal Trade Commission says companies will have to prove to consumers that giving up privacy is a trade that will not have nasty surprises. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT46) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. Marc Rotenberg of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington says the nation needs a legal framework on how these technologies are used. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT45) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TV-FOX-ZAHN -- The Fox News Channel on Wednesday fired Paula Zahn, center, one of its prime-time talk show hosts, after learning that she had received an offer from CNN. The move is the latest escalation in an increasingly bitter fight for supremacy in cable television news. Zahn meeting with producers in New York in July. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT44) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS-2 -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. At a midday service, the monks at New Melleray Abbey attend to their main task, prayer. (Andy Manis/The New York Times)  (NYT43) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. Kim, who died in 1998 at 78, lived during an era of contention and dogma in contemporary music, a challenging time, he knew, for composers to cultivate their musical identity. Kim at his home in Cambridge, Mass., in 1989. (The New York Times)ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY DAVID KUSHNER ENTITLED ``CIR-HISTORICAL-GAMES'' MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT26) IRVINE, Calif. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-IMAGE-SEARCHES -- Today, anyone on the Web can gain access to a trove of images. But to make such gawking possible, search engines must make a copy of every image they come across, whether they have permission to do so or not. These images are then displayed in the search engine's results listings without approval from the creators. In Irvine, Calif., photographer Leslie A. Kelly, right, and his lawyer, Steven Krongold, contend that a search engine hijacked his photos. (Marissa Roth/The New York Times)  (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- NY-MODEL-HOMES-3 -- Country Home magazine has sponsored the building of two model homes inside Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. In Grand Central Terminal, workers are in front of a model farmhouse. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS-2 -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. Murdoch at home with her husband, John Bayley, in 1998 in Oxford, England. (Jonathan Player/The New York Times)  (NYT19) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. The script shows a couple having to find a language beyond words. Judi Dench plays the author Iris Murdoch, and Jim Broadbent is her husband, John Bayley, in ``Iris.'' (Clive Coote/Mirimax Films) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MATT WOLF ENTITLED ``FILM-IRIS.''  (NYT18) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-HOUSE -- A hard-to-love son with blue-streaked hair and a hard-to-love and perpetually unshaven father appear to be lost causes, but in the second-chance narrative, they aren't. Molly Haskell takes a look at this genre pegged to the new film, ``Life as a House,'' starring Kevin Kline, as a once-gifted architect, who kidnaps his estranged son in the hope of enlisting his help in rebuilding a house. Kline in ``Life as a House'' directed by Irwin Winkler, which opens in October. (M.W. Wallace/New Line Cinema/The New York Times) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MOLLY HASKELL ENTITLED ``FILM-HOUSE.''  (NYT15) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-ALI-MANN-2 -- Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. It's about the real Ali, Mann says. ``We show him at his best, defying the U.S. government, refusing to be inducted into the Army and losing three and a half years of his career for it. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' Ali during a photo shoot in New York earlier this year. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)  (NYT14) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-ALI-MANN -- Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- CIR-CIRCUITS-COLUMN -- XP is Microsoft's attempt to merge its home line (the friendly but cranky Windows 95, 98 and Me) with its corporate line (the unattractive but rock-solid Windows NT and 2000) into a unified operating system that offers the best of both. In the new operating system, the Start menu, top, is now a better organized. Below, an annoying feature, everyone using the system, even if only one person, needs to log on. (The New York Times)  (NYT2) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- BUSH-FOX-MEXICO -- President Vicente Fox of Mexico startled his American hosts at the beginning of the state visit Wednesday when he called for an agreement with the United States on a migration policy by the end of the year. Fox and President Bush with their wifes, Martha Fox, left, and Laura Bush, on the balcony overlooking the South Lawn of the White House during welcoming ceremonies for the Mexican head of state, Wednesday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)  (NYT1) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- BUSH-FOX-MEXICO -- President Bush with President Vicente Fox of Mexico during the playing of the national anthem at the White House, Wednesday. (NYT49) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- STEM-CELLS-3 -- Rep. John Langevin, a paraplegic with a damaged spine, testified before the Senate Wednesday in favor of stem cell research. A Democrat from Rhode Island who was first elected last year, Langevin was greeted by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., Susan Collins, R-Me., Judd Gregg, R-N.H., Bill Frist, R-Tenn., and Jack Reed, D-R.I. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT48) TUCSON, Ariz. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- SCI-EPHEDRA-DEATHS -- A consumer advocacy group and a prominent pharmacologist filed a petition Wednesday asking the Food and Drug Administration to ban dietary supplements containing the stimulant ephedra, saying that reports of illness from the supplements had doubled in recent years, reaching 407 in 1999. Ephedra has been linked to deaths, strokes, heart attacks and other health problems. Dr. Raymond Woosley, a pharmagologist at the University of Arizona, wants controls on ephedra. Woosley at the University of Arizona in Tucson. (University of Arizona/The New York Times) MAGS OUT--NO SALES  (NYT47) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III-2 -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. In Washington, Mozelle W. Thompson, a member of the Federal Trade Commission says companies will have to prove to consumers that giving up privacy is a trade that will not have nasty surprises. (Susana Raab/The New York Times)  (NYT46) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ONLINE-PRIVACY-III -- Recently, momentum has dissipated in Washington for new laws that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities. Some lawmakers say the politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that a deliberate approach is best -- but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge. Marc Rotenberg of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington says the nation needs a legal framework on how these technologies are used. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT45) NEW YORK -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TV-FOX-ZAHN -- The Fox News Channel on Wednesday fired Paula Zahn, center, one of its prime-time talk show hosts, after learning that she had received an offer from CNN. The move is the latest escalation in an increasingly bitter fight for supremacy in cable television news. Zahn meeting with producers in New York in July. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT44) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS-2 -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. At a midday service, the monks at New Melleray Abbey attend to their main task, prayer. (Andy Manis/The New York Times)  (NYT43) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. (The New York Times)  (NYT29) CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- KIM-MUSIC -- As a composer and a teacher of composers, Earl Kim maintained that every sound in a piece should be faithful to the composer's sensibilities. Kim, who died in 1998 at 78, lived during an era of contention and dogma in contemporary music, a challenging time, he knew, for composers to cultivate their musical identity. Kim at his home in Cambridge, Mass., in 1989. But to make such gawking possible, search engines must make a copy of every image they come across, whether they have permission to do so or not. These images are then displayed in the search engine's results listings without approval from the creators. In Irvine, Calif., photographer Leslie A. Kelly, right, and his lawyer, Steven Krongold, contend that a search engine hijacked his photos. In Grand Central Terminal, workers are in front of a model farmhouse. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS-2 -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. Murdoch at home with her husband, John Bayley, in 1998 in Oxford, England. (Jonathan Player/The New York Times)  (NYT19) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. The script shows a couple having to find a language beyond words. Judi Dench plays the author Iris Murdoch, and Jim Broadbent is her husband, John Bayley, in ``Iris.'' (Clive Coote/Mirimax Films) ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY BY MATT WOLF ENTITLED ``FILM-IRIS.''  (NYT18) UNDATED -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- ADV. FOR SUN. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' Ali during a photo shoot in New York earlier this year. (Fred R. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT44) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS-2 -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. But with the growing emphasis on technology and the Internet, the notion of what constitutes work has changed. Their ranks have also dwindled as their average age has risen to 68, forcing the monks to contemplate diversification and marketability. Using trees cut down from their forest, the monks have developed a product with simple design reflecting simple Trappist ideals. Trappist Caskets. At a midday service, the monks at New Melleray Abbey attend to their main task, prayer. (Andy Manis/The New York Times)  (NYT43) PEOSTA, Iowa -- Sept. 5, 2001 -- TRAPPIST-MONKS -- For 150 years, the monks at the Trappist monastery, New Melleray Abbey, just outside Dubuque, have sustained their cloistered lifestyle by working the land. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS-2 -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. SEPT. 9 -- FILM-IRIS -- What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. , he suggested,	 Steven Johnson's 1997 book, ``Interface Culture,'' remains one of the most thoughtful, literate studies yet published on the cultural impact of recent technological changes. Writing in lucid, user-friendly prose and drawing analogies from a prodigious range of fields (including literature, painting, architecture, philosophy and semiotics), Johnson made the provocative argument that the graphic interface _ those software-mediated interactions between users and computers _ is potentially ``a medium as complex and vital as the novel or the cathedral or the cinema.'' In much the same way that the novels of Dickens attempted to make sense of the galvanic changes unleashed by the Industrial Revolution, he suggested,today's high-tech interfaces are providing us with tools to grapple with the dislocations and data overload wrought by the information revolution. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, they discovered,	 The results led them to a particular gene, PB2, that is used in viral replication. STEVENSON c.2001 New York Times News Service  WASHINGTON _ President Bush said on Friday that ``too many people are losing their jobs,'' and cast the surge in the unemployment rate as reason for Congress to advance his economic agenda by expanding trade agreements and reducing energy costs while holding down government spending.  ``The slowdown is real and it's affecting too many lives, and we're concerned about it,'' Bush said. ``Any American out of work is too many Americans out of work.''  His hastily arranged appearance outside the Oval Office Friday afternoon reflected growing concern among his aides and officials throughout his party that the deteriorating economic and budget outlook could cost both the White House and congressional Republicans in political terms.  With Wall Street tumbling on word that the unemployment jumped last month to 4.9 percent, a full percentage point above where it was on Election Day 10 months ago, Bush spoke to reporters with Vice President Dick Cheney and the leaders of his party in Congress at his side. The country, he said, needs a ``growth plan'' to reverse a downturn that he pointedly noted started before he took office.  But Bush, the son of a president whose loss in 1992 was widely blamed on a failure to address the last recession more aggressively, seemed mostly intent on assuring voters that he is in touch with what the weakened economy means to individuals.  ``I want the American people to know we're deeply concerned about the unemployment rates and we intend to do something about it,'' he said.  But he did not say what he intends to do, beyond pushing for policies he has been pressing all along and waiting for his tax cut to give the economy a kick. As he did in selling his tax cut, Bush used the changing economic situation as further justification for initiatives that he proposed long before the downturn became apparent.  They included seeking authority from Congress to negotiate international trade agreements. Such a step might benefit the economy in the long run by increasing opportunities to sell American goods abroad, but would be very unlikely to come in time to influence the current business cycle.  Bush also renewed his call for Congress to take steps, such as opening up new areas to oil and gas drilling and reducing regulatory restrictions on energy companies, that could reduce energy costs. Energy prices, however, have already fallen in recent months without any major actions by the government, substantially reducing their drag on the economy.  Bush's aides said he was confident that the tax cut he signed into law three months ago, combined with the Federal Reserve's campaign of interest rate cuts, would lead the economy to start rebounding by the end of the year.  (BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM)  The Treasury Department on Friday sent out the eighth of ten batches of tax rebate checks of up to $300 for individuals and $600 for couples, money that the administration said should help keep consumers spending as the economy goes through a temporary rough patch.  Further cuts in income tax rates will take effect in January. Bush has declined to back a push by Republican leaders in Congress for a quick reduction in the capital gains tax, saying the rebate checks and rate cuts should be enough.  ``The president is confident that the plan that is in place will work,'' said Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman. ``The best advice of the economists, private sector and public sector, even taking into account rising unemployment, has been that the economy is projected to come back late this year and next.''  (END OPTIONAL TRIM)  The president spoke after Democrats stepped up their attacks on the administration's handling of the budget and the economy, saying Bush had squandered the surplus on an excessive tax cut, pushing up interest rates on Wall Street and undermining confidence among consumers.  (BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM)  ``The unemployment level now is at the highest it has been in four years,'' said Sen. Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader. ``We're at 4.9 percent, and that's intolerable. I think it's a reflection, unfortunately, of the Bush budget and the Bush economy.''  Democrats have been working to link the shrinking budget surplus to questions about Bush's economic management, in part by arguing that Bush's tax cut is forcing the government to violate pledges by both parties not to use excess funds generated by Social Security for other government programs.  (END OPTIONAL TRIM)  A few Republicans, including Sen. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, have suggested that using a portion of the retirement system's surplus would be an acceptable way of easing pressure on both the economy and the budget. Bush and most Republican leaders, however, have stuck to their vows not to touch the Social Security money.  (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)  Some Republicans floated a plan Friday under which any further dissipation of the surplus next year that might force the budget to use Social Security money would trigger an automatic, across-the-board spending cut.  The idea was discussed at the White House on Friday by J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the speaker of the House, and Sen. Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican minority leader in the Senate.  Republicans said the idea had considerable political appeal, but many practical problems. Among them, they said, is concern that cutting spending in response to a weakening economy would run counter to what traditional economic theory says a government should do when confronted with a recession or the risk of one.  Typically, governments have increased spending during economic slowdowns to give the economy a boost. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010907.0322 type=story > <HEADLINE>     Gordon's greatest competition is himself </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> RICHMOND, Va. If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For questions about photos, call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  ENTERTAINMENT &AMP; ARTS (Coded `e')  FILM  FILM-WIZARDS _ The release of two fantasy films, ``The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' on Dec. 19 and ``Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' on Nov. 16, may make this the winter of the wizard. It is only the beginning. The director, Peter Jackson, filmed two more feature in the Hobbit series simultaneously. That meant actors like Elijah Wood, who plays the hobbit, assorted elves (Cate Blanchett, Orlando Bloom, Liv Tyler) and human warriors (Viggo Mortensen, Sean Bean) lived for a year in Middle Earth. By Polly Shulman.  With photos NYT21 and NYT22 sent on Sept. 5.  FILM-VIETNAM-GREENE (Hanoi, Vietnam) _ The filming of Graham Greene's novel ``The Quiet American'' is the most ambitious film project made in Vietnam since the war ended in 1975. On its surface, it is the story of a love triangle involving a naive American secret agent, a world-weary English journalist and a determined Vietnamese woman. The book, published in 1955, is read today as a prescient warning of the American involvement in Vietnam. As for Michael Caine, who plays the journalist, he says journalists will be pleased. ``I get the girl and I get the story. What more do you want?'' By Seth Mydans.  With photos NYT 10 and NYT11 sent on Sept. 5.  FILM-GOSFORD-ALTMAN (London) _ In ``Gosford Park,'' Robert Altman casts an American eye on the English class system during a weekend shooting party in 1932. The film has no starring roles, but some of the extras include the aristocrats of British drama: Sir Michael Gambon, Sir Derek Jacobi, Dame Eileen Atkins, and Dame Maggie Smith, plus Alan Bates, Kristin Scott Thomas, Emily Watson and Charles Dance. The film opens Dec. 7. By Kristin Hohenadel.  With photos NYT17 and NYT18 sent on Sept. 5.  FILM-ALI-MANN (New York) _ Michael Mann's ``Ali,'' starring Will Smith, opens Dec. 7. It's about the real Ali, Mann says. ``We show him at his best, defying the U.S. government, refusing to be inducted into the Army and losing three and a half years of his career for it. We also show him at his worst, taunting and insulting his black opponents and cheating on his wife. This isn't an idealized Ali.'' By Allen Barra.  With photos NYT14 and NYT15 sent on Sept. 5.  FILM-BANYAN-DILLON (Kampot, Cambodia) _ ``Under the Banyan Trees'' is what Matt Dillon calls an ``atmospheric thriller'' set in post-holocaust Cambodia. Robert Turnbull interviews Dillon, the writer, director and actor, in Cambodia where anecdotes of bizarre filming conditions abound. Dillon plays a New York insurance con man who goes to Cambodia in pursuit of a Vietnam veteran who owes him money. He encounters colorful characters (Gerard DePardieu and Stellan Skarsgard) along the road to the film's denouement in a faceoff against James Caan's corrupt expatriate.  With photos NYT12 and NYT13 sent on Sept. 5.  FILM-HOUSE (Undated) _ A hard-to-love son with blue-streaked hair and a hard-to-love and perpetually unshaven father appear to be lost causes, but in the second-chance narrative, they aren't. Molly Haskell takes a look at this genre pegged to the new film, ``Life as a House,'' starring Kevin Kline, as a once-gifted architect, who kidnaps his estranged son in the hope of enlisting his help in rebuilding a house.  With photo NYT16 sent on Sept. 5.  FILM-IRIS (Southwold, England) _ What everyone connected to ``Iris'' agreed they didn't want to make was a conventional disease-of-the-week movie. Instead, the aim was to animate the 43-year marriage between Iris Murdoch and John Bayley while honoring the grotesque irony of her succumbing to Alzheimer's disease: that so fearless a communicator and so deft a wielder of language should suffer an illness that blocked her ability to do both. The script shows a couple having to find a language beyond words. Judi Dench plays the older Murdoch and Kate Winslet plays her as a young woman. The film is not yet scheduled for release. By Matt Wolf.  With photos NYT19 and NYT20 sent on Sept. 5.  TELEVISION  TV-BICKFORD-DREYFUSS (Pasadena, Calif.) _ When CBS began talking to Richard Dreyfuss about a television series, the 53-year-old actor told CBS he wanted to play a man of his own age ``who's uncertain about his whole life, who's having a midlife crisis, who's not sure how to deal with women, work, sex, money.'' ``I wanted to play _ me,'' he said. The result is ``The Education of Max Bickford,'' a new Sunday drama series that starts Sept. 23 in the high-profile 8 p.m. time slot following ``60 Minutes.'' By Bernard Weinraub.  MUSIC  OPERA-WAR&AMP;PEACE (New York) _ There are 27 operas based on the works of Leo Tolstoy, but the best known is Sergei Prokofiev's ``War and Peace,'' which is being performed in February at the Metropolitan Opera. It's a tall order, perhaps the tallest for any opera house to mount. Even after winnowing most of the novel away, Prokofiev was left with 71 solo roles, a chorus; 13 scenes, each requiring a set; and a running time of more than four hours. By Richard Taruskin.  MUSIC-MACY-GRAY (New York ) _ Macy Gray, the singer-songwriter whose 1999 debut album, ``On How Life Is,'' has sold three million copies in the United States, is releasing ``The Id'' on Sept. 18. The album got its title, she said, because a friend once described her as ``all id.'' Then, Gray said, ``I remembered my Psychology 101 class. The album is very automatic, spontaneous, a kind of pouring out of whatever.'' By Jon Pareles.  ART  TV-ART21 (New York) _ ``Art21: Art in the 21st Century,'' will be broadcast on PBS on Sept. 21 and 28. By getting rid of narrators, ``Art21'' has changed the genre of art on television. Behind the camera is Susan Sollins, a founder and former executive director of Independent Curators International, who inaudibly and invisibly prodded the artists to tell their stories. By Kay Larson.  With photo.  TRAVEL  (Coded `t')  TRAVEL-COLONIAL-VIETNAM (Undated) _ In search of Vietnam's colonial past, Catherine Texier found grand hotels, a post office designed by Gustave Eiffel, a classroom of girls singing ``Alouette, Gentille Alouette,'' men in berets and restaurants serving croissants and creme caramel.  TRAVEL-VIETNAM-CAFES (Undated) _ Vietnam has a cafe culture to rival Italy's, but it's not about people-watching or food. It's about coffee, because unlike the rest of Asia, Vietnam is a coffee drinking country. By Katherine Zoepf.  With 500-word box and photo.  TRAVEL-VIETNAM-ART-COPIERS (Undated) _ Day and night in open shopfronts in the central shopping district of Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, men and women with paintbrushes are turning out reproduction masterpieces. Van Gogh's sunflowers sell for $50 or $60, Impressionists are easy, say the painters, and therefore cheap. If you want, the enigmatic Mona Lisa can be ordered frowning or giggling. By Seth Mydans.  TRAVEL-WHALE-WATCHING (Undated) _ Whale watching worldwide now accounts for $1 billion in spending each year by more than nine million people who take part in excursions from almost 90 countries, according to a report published in July. By John Cushman Jr.  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) _ With a son who loves roller coasters, the more dangerous the better, Susan Gilbert began researching to find out if her fears were justified. She found some news reassuring and some not so reassuring.  TRAVEL-BRIEFS (Undated) _ A Web operation, www.airportparkinglots.com, is offering guaranteed reserved parking at more than 40 airports in the United States and Canada. Plus items on exhibitions in Toronto, Chicago and Lafayette, La.  TRAVEL-CYBER (Undated) _ Travel Medicine experts advise using the Web to prepare for potential medical emergencies before leaving on a trip. By Bob Tedeschi.  TRAVEL-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Answers to questions about child-friendly tours to Japan, the Camino pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela and cruises that allow pets. By Florence Stickney.  MONEY AND BUSINESS (Coded `f')  IBM-R&AMP;D (Undated) _ When it comes to research and development, IBM is now the power corporation, not Bell Labs of AT&AMP;T. IBM has the most patents, the best recruiting record for scientists and the biggest budget ($600 million). It also managed to earn $1.7 billion in licensing fees in 2000. One reason that IBM Research is so effective is that the company treats its labs like businesses. By Barnaby J. Feder.  With photo and graphics.  ENVIRONMENT-PAYOFFS(Undated) _ Some companies from Starbucks to Nova Chemicals to ITT Industries are unexpectedly discovering that it pays to be nice to Mother Nature. They are either making money or saving money on their investments to safeguard the environment. By Claudia H. Deutsch.  MARKET-WATCH (Undated) _ Enron, the giant energy trading company in Houston, Enron closed on Friday at $31.57, down 62 percent for the year. The slide has destroyed more than $38 billion in shareholder value. The company's problems are partly the result of the collapse in natural gas prices this year and investor fears of a coming glut in electricity. But the deepest wound at Enron is self-inflicted. Insider selling, indecipherable accounting practices and a stream of executive departures have combined to create a growing credibility gap between the company and Wall Street. By Alex Berenson.  With graphic.  OTHER FEATURES  BOOK-LIVERMORE (Undated) _ Jesse Lauriston Livermore burst on the trading scene in the 1890s at such an early age that traders labeled him the ``Boy Plunger.'' He made and lost several fortunes, then ended his career by putting a pistol to his head in a cloakroom at the Sherry Netherland. There's a new book about one of the nation's first celebrity investors, ``Jesse Livermore: World's Greatest Stock Trader,'' being published this month by John Wiley &AMP; Sons. By Diana B. Henriques.  With graphic on top books on business.  SOLAR-INTERNET (Undated) _ In the United States, solar energy companies have had decent sales as an environmentally friendly complement to the existing power grid, but the fastest-growing business for solar energy companies is providing electricity in rural areas of the world that have no reliable power source. Not only are these companies getting people in Third World countries to forsake kerosene, they are selling them on the advantages of the Internet. By David Lipschultz.  With photo.  COLUMNS  ECON-COLUMN (Undated) _ Everyone knows about the gross domestic product, which tracks the value of all the goods and services that the nation produces. So far, it is rising just enough to keep the economy out of recession. But net domestic product, which is GDP minus depreciation on capital goods, is shrinking and NDP is a truer measure of living standards. By Louis Uchitelle.  With graphic.  MYMONEY-MYLIFE-COLUMN (Undated) _ Chris Rapalje, a survivor of drastic layoffs at a telecom in Atlanta, wonders whether those who got laid off might not be the real winners. The office today is a pressure cooker. There is zero room for blunders. There are so many people with doctor's appointments Rapalje wonders if people are as sick as the company's $2 stock or are they job hunting? Her biggest fear: ``I'll just be voted off the island for messing something up.''  Includes a box asking for readers to submit their stories to The New York Times.  BACKSLASH-COLUMN (Undated) _ Owner manuals through the ages. By Matt Richtel.  MARKET-INSIGHT (New York) _ The fourth quarter may determine the fate of many internet retailers, including the genre's giant, Amazon.com. Holly Becker, an Internet and media analyst at Lehman Brothers, talked last week about prospects for a shrinking list of companies that tried to dominate a retail environment. By Kenneth N. Gilpin.  INVESTING  INVEST-FOLIOS (Undated) _ The SEC recently told mutual fund companies it won't regulate investing in folios, or individually selected baskets of stocks, opening the way to what is expected to be a big surge in such investing. By Patrick McGeehan.  INVEST-BONDS (Undated) _ Through August, corporate bonds have been on a pace to return more than 14 percent this year. Municipal bonds are on track to return 10 percent, which is an after-tax return over 15 percent for top-bracket investors. While junk bonds, at 9 percent, and Treasury bonds and notes, at 8 percent, still look fabulous when compared with the negative performance of stocks. But as the summer ends, investors might want to consider whether the good news can continue. By Jonathan Fuerbringer.  With graphic.  INVEST-OPTIONS (New York) _ Options used to give astute traders clues about mergers and acquisitions. Now, when they provide information at all, it's usually about corporate problems. Options traders must tread a fine line, however. By Dan Colarusso.  SHORTS  JOB-OPENINGS (Undated) _ Job recruiters say that a few industries are still looking to fill positions. Job-placement services report strong demand in biotechnology, energy and construction and executive-search services see openings in medical devices and human resources, according to a recent survey of recruiters. By Vivian Marino. (220 words.)  AMITOR-FUND-LIQUIDATION (Undated) _ One of the longest-running but least enviable streaks in the mutual fund industry has ended. The Ameritor Industry Fund, which held the dubious distinction of performing more poorly than the S&AMP;P 500 for 11 straight years, has been liquidated, according to a July filing with the Securities Exchange Commission. By Jeff Sommer. (290 words)  BUSINESS-PEOPLE (Undated) _ Short items on various business, including Roger A. Enrico and John F. Welch Jr.  SHARPER-IMAGE (Undated) _ Sharper Image Corp., the specialty retailer of gadgets was riding fast and furious last year on the strength of its popular Razor scooters, but tastes change. Last week, Sharper Image reported that sales of stores open at least a year declined by 32 percent in August from the same period a year ago. Total company sales fell 23 percent. By Vivian Marino.  AUTOS  AUTO-FUEL (Detroit) - With this year's unpredictable gasoline prices, consumer's are showing more interest in cars that run on diesel fuel and hybrids such as the Toyota Prius and Honda Insight, which run on a combination electric motor and gasoline engine. By Micheline Maynard.  With graphic.  ABOUTCARS-CAMRY (Undated) _ While Detroit has put most of its marketing muscle into high-profit, truck-based vehicles, Japanese manufacturers _ in particular, Toyota _ have been busy covering all bets. Toyota's latest is a new version of the Camry, the best-selling family sedan in America for the last four years. It is bigger, quieter, more powerful, carries a lower sticker price and is Lexus-like in its attention to detail. By Peter Passell.  With photo.  TOYOTA-MEN (Ann Arbor, Mich.) _ Toyota is making an effort to sell more Camrys to men. Why? Men are more emotional when buying cars and in a competitive market emotion may make for easier sales. Their new advertising is pitched to a 49-year-old man who earns $60,000. By Micheline Maynard.  STYLE  (Coded `l')  PET-BEREAVEMENT (New York) _ Not so long ago, grieving for a pet was a hush-hush affair. The death itself happened on the road or in a veterinarian's office. Today not only are there support groups and grief counselors, but there are also memoirs, self-help videos and commemorative Web sites. Not to mention the comfort derived from custom-built coffins, urns, mausoleums built for two _ pet and pet owner _ and National Pet Memorial Day on Sept. 9. By Julie V. Iovine.  With photo NYT7 sent on Sept. 7.  TENNIS-STARS (New York) _ An A-list of black celebrities is flocking to the U.S. Open to mingle in the same arena as Venus and Serena Williams. ``They got game,'' said one courtside fan, Spike Lee. By Liz Robbins.  FASHION-CAVALLI (Florence, Italy ) _ Some think Roberto Cavalli's feathered evening clothes, rhinestone-encrusted jeans and python pants are vulgar, but for many he has the right touch of flamboyance. Ruth LaFerla interviews him at his farmhouse and describes it as including a helicopter, medieval tower, zebra-striped lounge chairs, 12th-century Madonna and a room that looks like a well-appointed opium den.  With photo NYT6 sent on Sept. 7.  NIGHTOUT-COUPLAND (New York) _ Douglas Coupland, whose novel ``13th Gen'' defined Generation X, has now written ``All Families Are Psychotic.'' Last week, he celebrated the book and ``Spike,'' his sculpture show at the Totem Gallery. The show and the novel are both related to a family crisis: Two years ago his niece was born without a left hand, a birth defect that showed up as a ``spike'' in the incidence of birth defects in his native Vancouver. By Phil Patton.  FASHION-STOLMAN (Undated) _ Steven Stolman, who has five stores in New York and Florida, is a small but estimable force in the fashion world for his use of decorative furnishing fabrics like toile de Jouy in clothing designs for women and men. By William L. Hamilton.  With photos NYT8 and NYT9 sent on Sept. 7.  SHORTS  JORDACHE-DOLLS (New York) _ Jordache is introducing dolls with attitude. There's a rollerblading blonde, a peroxide-enhanced African-American and a pixie-styled brunette. Their wardrobes, of course, are Jordache hot pants and jeans. By Karen Robinovitz.  FASHION-PREGNANT (New York) _ On Tuesday, when Liz Lange takes the first maternity show in Seventh Avenue history to Bryant Park, most of the models will be authentically pregnant. By Ellen Tien.
