, it seems,	 Mexico may never be the southern half of the United States of North America. The border may not crumble like the Berlin Wall. But in time it may look more like a golden door. ``The bottom line is the fences are going to go down between these two countries,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D- Conn., after listening to Fox's speech. ``And it's in the interests of both countries and both peoples that we make it work.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010908.0056 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-REVIEW-BUDGET-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Editors: The following items from The New York Times Week in Review for Sunday, Sept. 9, moved Saturday.  On the dress page:  MEXICO-MIGRATION-REVIEW (Mexico City) _ The end of the Cold War opened up new routes to the world's centers of capital, setting off a great migration not seen since the calamitous 1940s. Tens of millions of people cross international borders illegally every year. Some are fleeing poverty, some oppression. Some are simply looking for a job. Since Mexico's border is the most open path to the United States, millions try to cross it. This is the world in which U.S. and Mexican leaders have decided to rewrite their mutual rules of the road for migration. The route across their border was well-traveled long before globalization and its discontents, but it has been made more labyrinthine by new political and economic forces. By Tim Weiner. (Moved in `i' category)  BUSH-DEMS-REVIEW (Washington) _ Talk about shark season. Congress came back into session last week, and the Democrats were circling, sensing blood in the political waters. The Republicans had an air of panic. Only last spring, the Democrats were unable to stop President Bush's $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax cut. But with the economy slowing, the budget surplus shrinking and Bush in danger of having to break his pledge not to dip into the Social Security surplus, Democrats have returned to Washington crowing, `` I told you so.'' By Alison Mitchell. WITH PHOTO NYT2. (Moved in `a' category)  _ Also moved in the `a' category:  FBI-CIA-REVIEW (Washington) _ Robert Mueller has been installed as FBI director with a mandate to reform the bureau. But if the CIA is any guide, a simple change in leadership is merely an uncertain start. In fact, the CIA's lesson may well be that in federal agencies in crisis, creating fundamental change can be nasty, brutish _ and prolonged. The leaders who make the first attempts at reform may not survive the political and bureaucratic heat they inevitably provoke. And the end result can be, not a restoration of the strength and reliability of a crucial institution, but a permanent erosion of that institution's power and influence. By James Risen.  MICROSOFT-ANTITRUST-REVIEW (Washington) _ The Bush administration's retrenchment in the Microsoft antitrust case seems to epitomize its belief that government should not play a decisive role in business affairs, and that market forces should dictate how companies compete. Some antitrust experts and some state officials wonder whether it will be possible to curb a pervasive corporate culture through a consent decree. In any case, it will require years of close and onerous supervision by the judiciary and law enforcement, an outcome the Clinton administration and the states rejected last year in favor of a breakup. By Stephen Labaton. WITH PHOTO NYT 1.  BUSH-SPORTS-REVIEW (Washington) _ President Bush will toss a coin in the White House Rose Garden to open the 2001 National Football League season, an act that will further burnish the president's credentials as the nation's First Fan. Presidents are far more accustomed to throwing the first pitch to open a Major League Baseball season. But Bush, an avid sports fan who was a part-owner of the Texas Rangers, will have the honor of being the first chief executive to launch a professional football season. By Don Van Natta Jr.  BASEBALL-PERSONAL-REVIEW (Undated) _ A look at the growing tendency of baseball teams to respect players' personal lives more than when they were paid one hundredth as much. Players are routinely given three days off to attend the birth of a child; their predecessors got no such furloughs. Shawn Green of the Los Angeles Dodgers will sit out a key game against the San Francisco Giants on Sept. 26 in observance of Yom Kippur. He is the first prominent baseball player to do so since 1965, when the Dodgers' Sandy Koufax declined to pitch the first game of the World Series. By Alan Schwarz.  RACIST-MEMORABILIA-REVIEW (Undated) _ As predictably as people will scour even the darkest cultural crawl spaces for lucrative pieces of the past, so too, it seems, will industrious sorts seek to manufacture fakes _ and the booming trade in racist memorabilia is not immune. Slave shackles, Sambo imagery and other racist memorabilia have all been reproduced in recent years, collectors say, and eventually sold on the market as authentic period pieces. It is a bizarre cultural digestion in which the artifacts left behind by a social ill have, by their very value, yielded another social ill. By Tom Zeller. WITH GRAPHIC.  SIMPSONS-PHILOSOPHY-TEXT-REVIEW (Undated) _ Academia has turned its gaze to ``The Simpsons.'' A new collection of essays called ``The Simpsons and Philosophy: The D'oh! of Homer,'' dissects the show's many cultural and political messages _ both liminal and subliminal.  BOOKS-SPONSORS-REVIEW (Undated) _ Remember the good old days when commercials stopped once you turned off the television? Now it's not even safe to curl up in an armchair with a good book anymore. By Jenny Lyn Bader.  THISWEEK-REVIEW (Undated) _ Some highlights of the week.  _ Also moved in the `i' category:  REFUGEES-EUROPE-REVIEW (London) _ The 1951 U.N. Convention on Refugees was an acknowledgment of a new global commitment to human rights. But since it took effect, the world has changed almost beyond recognition. Modern travel has made movement between countries easier. And with each new war, each new brutal regime, each new flood or drought or earthquake, the number of displaced persons has increased still more. With the floods of people seeking refuge has come a reluctance on the part of other countries to offer it to them. Nowhere is the confusion over how to handle refugees more clearly illustrated than in Europe, where each country has its own ideas about who qualifies as a refugee under the 1951 convention and its own rules for dealing with immigrants. By Sarah Lyall.  NAZI-HUMOR-REVIEW (Undated) _ The 1960s sitcom ``Hogan's Heroes'' is going to be made into a feature film, while on Broadway packed houses are saluting the ``The Producers,'' with its number that has dancers form a twirling swastika. Some Germans, however, are holding their applause, and wondering whether Hitler can really ever be an object of fun. What, some also wonder, does the humor about the Third Reich say about Americans? The answer may help define the limits of laughter as therapy for a painful past. By Alan Cowell.  JAPAN-JOBS-REVIEW (Tokyo) _ This is a moment of great peril for the Japanese economy, but it may be a moment of great opportunity as well. Japan's fabled lifetime employment system died over a decade ago, but many economists say the failure to create fluid new labor markets, where changing jobs mid-career can be a commonplace, has a lot to do with the country's persistent, decade-long crisis. Yet, even as they are cut loose by their companies, many Japanese have managed to maintain great optimism despite the psychic trauma that record unemployment has taken on the Japanese as a whole. And they could prove the key to giving this society new hope. By Howard w. French.  STORY QUESTIONS OR RERUNS:  The Weekend Supervisor is Lynn Hoogenboom. The supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Lynn Hoogenboom, followed by Scott Akin; phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: lyhoog(at)nytimes.com and rsakin(AT)nytimes.com.  TOP  Lede story:  BUSH-CHALLENGES (Washington) _ Challenges President Bush will face in the fall. By Richard L. Berke and David E. Sanger.  With photos NYT 10 sent Sept. 7; NYT 1 sent Sept. 5; NYT 9 sent Sept. 4 and NYT13 sent Aug. 31.  (We plan to move the story by 3 p.m. ET in ``w'' news file.)  Top center story:  CHINA-EXECUTIONS (Hefei, China) _ China routinely executes more people than all other countries combined. This year, though, has been far from routine. Without much notice at home or abroad, the government has begun sending unknown thousands of people to execution grounds, often after they have been tortured into confessing crimes that to foreigners seem minor. By Craig S. Smith.  With map.  Off-lead story:  ISRAEL-MOOD (Jerusalem) _ To someone who last lived here in 1995, the darkened mood, among Palestinians as well as Israelis, is as enveloping as a shroud. There was a sense in the mid-1990s that these long-suffering combatants had come to grips with the fact that they were destined to go through life together and that they might finally figure out how to share their postage-stamp-sized land. Now, they seem doomed to claw at each other into the far future. Everyone, especially in Jerusalem, has a gremlin inside whispering that it may not be safe. By Clyde Haberman.  With photos NYT 2,3 sent Sept. 7.  FOLD  SCHOOLS-JUNK-FOOD (Undated) _ For countless American children, breakfast or lunch drops out of a vending machine at school: a can of soda, perhaps, washing down a chocolate bar or a bag of potato chips. Now a growing number of states are striking back, trying to curb the rise in childhood obesity by placing strict limits on the sale of candy, soda and fatty snack foods in schools. By Greg Winter.  With graphic.  2-graf refer:  CINCINNATI-RACE (Cincinnati) _ Talk has been sounding more precious than cheap this summer along the deep racial divide laid bare in civil rights protests and running violence on the streets here last spring. There has been an unusual effort to mine candid talk about grievances as the means for settling a pending racial profiling lawsuit against the city and the police. By Francis X. Clines.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``a'' news file.)  BOTTOM  ARRANGED-MARRIAGE (Morristown, Tenn.) _ Casey Moss and Kara Price never dated one another. Yet two years ago, when Kara was 14 and Casey was 20 and heading off to medical school, they pledged their lives to one another in an improvised ceremony at their church that they called a betrothal. While their story may seem a throwback to a quaint Victorian age, Casey and Kara are actually on the front edge of a small but growing movement among conservative Christian youth who are rejecting the dominant culture's approach to dating and romance. By Laurie Goodstein.  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. NFL PREVIEW  FBN-PREVIEW-OFFENSE (Undated) _ Winning with defense is on the mind of every NFL team this season, but in their hearts, offense still rules. Offense, and particularly the passing attack, remains the sexy part of the game, the fans' favorite, the league rulemakers' desire, the players' fancy. And the way the game is now played, when you find a top-notch offense, you find a team that uses the slot receiver as a potent weapon. By Thomas George. 1,300 words. With graphic.  FBN-PREVIEW-DEFENSE (Undated) _ For much of football history, the middle linebacker was the most glamorous and most feared position on defense. The position was made exceptionally popular by a nonpareil group from the late 1950s until about 1970, considered the golden age of middle linebackers. But after Dick Butkus retired, the middle linebacker became less of a factor as teams went from a four-man defensive line front with three linebackers _ a scheme that allowed the middle linebacker to be the star _ to a 3-4 alignment of three linemen and four linebackers. Now, as often happens in football, a cycle is repeating itself and middle linebackers, like old movie stars making a triumphant return to the screen after a long absence, are again dominating football. By Mike Freeman. 1,800 words. With graphic.  FBN-PREVIEW-CONTRACTS (Undated) _ For several players, this is their money season. It is the year their contracts expire and they audition once again for their current teams or, if they gain free agency in 2002, for new ones. For players in this position and for their teams, it is a season with severe implications. By Thomas George. 1,000 words.  FBN-PREVIEW-TV (Undated) _ On the changes in football coverage this season. By Richard Sandomir. 900 words.  FBN-PREVIEW-GIANTS (Undated) _ A preview of the New York Giants season. By Bill Pennington. 1,600 words.  FBN-PREVIEW-JETS (Undated) _ A preview of the New York Jets season. By Judy Battista.  FBN-AFC-CAPSULES (Undated) Capsules of teams in the AFC.  FBN-NFC-CAPSULES (Undated) Capsules of teams in the NFC.  For information and repeats call the News Service at 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. , she says,	 Sandau shrugs off criticism that wedding insurance isn't for the financially savvy. If a bride can put her mind at ease during a stressful time, she says, a few hundred dollars is money well spent. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, they said,	 Deepwater carries the potential for a damaging blowout that is nearly impossible to stop, they said, and natural gas drilling poses the threat of the accidental release of a potent poison, hydrogen sulfite, which, if inhaled, can kill. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, she says,	 The camaraderie extends to shore, she says, where crew members organize family picnics, softball games and even sponsor food drives for a nearby coastal town. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he says,	 Robert ``Hutch'' Hutchinson, the Shell drilling foreman, has one of the most high risk jobs on Mars but, he says, he never worries. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, it seems,	 Story Filed By Cox Newspapers </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010909.0053 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (AM-ADD-NYT-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Add New York Times News Service budget for papers of Monday, Sept. 10.  CULTURE  ANIMALS-IN-FILMS (Los Angeles) _ Animals have been part of the movie business from the very beginning, even before Rin Tin Tin first fetched the sheriff or Cheetah clambered up Johnny Weissmuller's leg. But never before, it seems, has there been such a demand for them, what with the proliferation of films aimed at families and young audiences and the explosion in cable-television channels. Depite slowdown in movie business, use of animals in films is up. Rick Lyman.  WRITERS-ON-WRITING (Undated) _ Next article in the Writers on Writing series. By Honor Moore.  SERBIAN-DIRECTOR (Venice, Italy) _ Arts Abroad: The Serbian director Goran Paskaljevic and his strange and subversive film, ``How Harry Became a Tree,'' at the Venice Film Festival. By Melinda Henneberger.  AVA-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ Theodore Rosengarten reviews ``Ava's Man,'' by Rick Bragg.  FINANCIAL  (Coded f)  HYUNDAI-AIG (Seoul, South Korea) _ The American International Group has resolved a dispute with Hyundai Securities that appeared to remove the last major barrier in its takeover of the financial units of the Hyundai group, South Korea's largest conglomerate until its break-up last year. By Don Kirk.  SCHOOL-WEBSITE-PLAGIARISM (Undated) _ A look at SchoolSucks.com _ a Web site whose founder says it is providing a useful public service by posting student research papers. Educators say it looks a lot like an aid for plagiarism. By Laurie Flynn.  ATT-AOL-CABLE (Undated) _ AOL/Time Warner's negotiations to buy AT&AMP;T's cable operations appear to be getting serious. Checking whether AOL has made a formal offer, which would have huge implications for competitors and for the media deregulation debate. By Andrew Ross Sorkin.  MEDIA-BUSINESS  (Coding varies.)  MAGS-FEMINISM-MEDIA (Undated) _ At a time when Cosmopolitan still splashes its cover with headlines like ``Our Most Outrageous Lust Lessons,'' and the women of ``Sex and the City'' trail martini glasses and slingbacks into their fifth season of stereotyped single-woman behavior, it is clear that American popular culture isn't exactly hewing to the feminist ideals of a quarter-century ago. But a band of independent magazine publishers is struggling to define feminism for women in their twenties. By Alex Kuczynski.  GERMANY-CABLE-MEDIA (Frankfurt, Germany) _ In back-to-back deals, one announced last week and one that could be announced as early as Monday, two Denver-based companies are paying about $7 billion to buy 80 percent of the cable television systems in Germany. By Edmund L. Andrews.  CHINA-TV-MEDIA (Shanghai, China) _ AOL Time Warner and the News Corp. are both expected to win licenses soon from the Chinese government that will allow them to broadcast television programming into a portion of southern China. That was the positive news. But behind the hoopla that will surround the announcement of licenses is the realization that about 97 percent of China's 1.26 billion people will still be barred from receiving foreign broadcasts. A news analysis. By Craig S. Smith with Geraldine Fabrikant.  MEDIA-TALK (Undated) _ Short news items about the media business. What's the editor-writer relationship like when the writer, a white-collar criminal, is behind bars; 10 Questions about the magazine business this fall; how Phil Bronstein, top editor of The San Francisco Chronicle and husband of Sharon Stone, tried to get an interview with Gary Condit.  OTHER REGULAR COLUMNS AND FEATURES:  HBO-AD-COLUMN (New York) _ During the 10 parts of ``Band of Brothers,'' the World War II miniseries on HBO, there are so many scenes featuring the vehicles now sold under the Jeep brand name by the Chrysler Group division of DaimlerChrysler that no one from HBO or Chrysler seems to have an exact count. However many there are _ estimates range from 600 to more than 1,000 _ none, it turns out, are the result of product placement. By Stuart Elliot.  ECOMMERCE-COLUMN (Undated) _ As Excite(at)Home collapses, what becomes of Blue Mountain, the electronic greeting card company for with Excite paid $780 million during better times? By Bob Tedeschi.  NEW-ECONOMY-COLUMN (Undated) _ ``Services'' was the siren song accompanying the merger announcement of Compaq and Hewlett-Packard. How viable is the services market? By Hal Varian.  TERAYON-MARKETPLACE (Undated) _ Terayon Communications may be a rarity: A former high-flying tech stock that is getting a second chance. Last Tuesday, Terayon finally proved the shorts wrong, as CableLabs, a nonprofit research center financed by the cable industry, decided that the next generation of modems should include Terayon's technology. By Alex Berenson.  PATENTS-COLUMN (Undated) _ Patents column on ``method and system for scripting interactive animated actors. By Teresa Riordan. For questions, please call Karen Petterson at 415-777-6579 or the business desk at 415-536-5172. For business stories running in main news, call the news desk at 415-777-7074.  DIABLO: William Chang has spent countless hours in front of his computer playing the wildly popular video game called Diablo II. But he's not playing to win _ he's playing to profit. The Orange County resident hunts for virtual treasures _ weapons or magical items _ that can boost a player's powers in the game. But in an unusual, entrepreneurial twist, he's taking these imaginary items and auctioning them online to other serious gamers for cold hard cash. Chang and thousands of other online treasure seekers are part of a virtual economy built on the demand for these items found in video games. Chang's biggest payoff so far was a weapon that sold for $750 on EBay. Other traders have sold items for up to $2,000. BY JOSH GREEN  MERGERS: Investors have knocked down the value of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq shares by 22.4 and 14.2 percent, respectively, since Labor Day when the computer-makers disclosed their urge to merge. But HP Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Carly Fiorina remains gung-ho about the latest potential high-tech combo. At a conference in Boston last week, she told skeptical shareholders and portfolio managers that ``these companies fit together like a zipper.'' In the argot of the mergers and acquisitions trade, Fiorina explained that the proposed $25 billion deal is ``a clear creator of shareholder value in the relatively short-term,'' providing impressive ``synergies'' and ``a very compelling platform for growth.'' Sound familiar? BY PETER SINTON  CHANG: JoMei Chang is her name and global domination _ accompanied by a soft voice and a disarming smile _ is her aim. Chang, the co-founder and chief executive officer of Sunnyvale softwaremaker Vitria Technology, makes no secret of her boundless ambition, but she doesn't boast about it either. Standing before a roomful of recruits at a recent company orientation, wearing a stylish silk suit and standing barely over 5 feet tall, Chang spelled out a corporate vision as clear as the diamonds at her throat. ``What is our goal? Our goal is worldwide dominance,'' she told the assembled troops in soft, heavily accented English. ``How do we do it? It's very simple. We do not take no for an answer.'' That's tough talk for a CEO whose company's revenue _ after five years of rapid-fire growth _ is slipping and whose once high-flying stock has slid to $2.40 from $273 at its peak in late 1999. BY CAROL EMERT  ONLINE (COLUMN): In the market for Internet service? Maybe you want a superfast DSL or cable connection, or perhaps a simpler, less-expensive hookup via America Online is more your speed. Whether you're upgrading your connection or bringing the Internet home for the first time, selecting an Internet service provider, or ISP, will depend on how familiar you are with computers and what you plan to do online. ONLINE GUIDE COLUMN BY JOHN BATTEIGER  NETWORTH (COLUMN): Has the Gap gotten too big for its britches? That's the question of the week as Gap stock sinks lower than a pair of ultralow-rise jeans. Gap shares fell to their lowest price since December 1997 last week after the San Francisco company reported that same-store sales fell 17 percent in August. It was the 16th consecutive monthly drop in sales at stores open more than a year. With $14 billion in revenue, Gap is the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, 40 percent bigger than its closest rival, Limited. NET WORTH COLUMN BY KATHLEEN PENDER  SONICBLUE: Sonicblue Inc. chief executive Ken Potashner likes to say his company's business is ``disruptive.'' ``We use that word a lot,'' Potashner said. ``It's a good word. Disruptive technologies, disruptive products that change the status quo.'' Indeed, the Santa Clara company's best-known products, the Rio brand of MP3 digital audio players, have already helped disrupt the way the recording industry does business. Last week, Sonicblue introduced a pricey ReplayTV digital video recorder capable of storing up to 320 hours of video and sharing those files via the Internet. The firm hopes the machine will disrupt the way consumers watch TV. BY BENNY EVANGELISTA  TECH21 (COLUMN): In the wake of last week's megamerger news, at least one thing is perfectly clear: Dell Computer has become the scourge of the PC industry. Everyone else in the business is reeling from the combined effects of sagging demand and the scorched-earth price war Dell began this spring. But Dell just keeps gaining ground, and I don't see anything on the horizon that's likely to slow it down _ certainly not the tag team of Carly Fiorina and Michael Capellas. In fact, a market share of 40 percent no longer looks quite so much like the megalomaniacal fantasy I thought it was when Michael Dell, the Round Rock, Texas, company's founder and chief executive officer, began talking about that target a year or two back. Worldwide, Dell's share in the second quarter, measured in units shipped, was only 13.1 percent, according to Gartner Dataquest _ enough to put it at the head of the pack in an industry that remains highly fragmented but obviously a far cry from 40 percent. TECH 21 COLUMN BY HENRY NORR  BIOSCOPE (COLUMN): Pride, profit and a page out of biotech history will be on trial in Los Angeles during the next few weeks, as Genentech Inc. battles the City of Hope Medical Center in a dispute over whether the biotech giant owes the hospital $460 million in royalties. Stories about the dispute started appearing shortly before the trial began last week, and snippets of testimony will dribble out until early November, when a Los Angeles County Superior Court jury is expected to decide what was meant by two key clauses in the contract that launched the biotech industry. The case revolves around a contract written in 1976, when the fledgling South San Francisco firm hired two scientists at the Southern California hospital to help do what had never been done before _ splice a human gene into bacteria to produce insulin and growth hormone, two medicinal proteins. BIOSCOPE COLUMN BY TOM ABATE </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010909.0057 type=story > <HEADLINE> THE WONDER YEARS: HOMEWORK IS FREE ONLINE </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-SCHOOL-WEBSITE-PLAGIARISM-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Sahr said his customers ranged in age from about 12 to 25, most of them middle-school and high-school students. Of the 10,000 visitors to his site every day, he said, 8,000 on average are from the United States, 1,000 are Canadian and the remainder are from other countries. Anyone can log onto schoolsucks.com and download any of 5,000 research papers free on topics as diverse as the Magna Carta and encephalitis, sometimes even in Hebrew or French. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he insists,	 Rather than plagiarism, Sahr argues, what his site really offers students is a mixture of research and inspiration. The site helps intimidated students ``get their feet wet,'' providing bibliographies and research material. Besides, he insists, students would not use his Web site to plagiarize material because it would be too easy for teachers and professors to check the site themselves. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Sahr even offers a public-service defense of his business. The generally poor quality of the homework available for free on his site, he said, should send a red flag to educators that something is seriously wrong with today's schools. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Sahr said that he and his two partners, Yasha Harari and Nimrod Carmi, did not exercise quality control. Anything and everything gets posted, he said, except for the occasional violent essay or anything that proselytizes for a political cause. As a result, a student downloading an essay has no way of knowing if the paper received an A or an F. ``We tell people, `You could be downloading garbage, and you probably are,''' Sahr said. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 The idea for the site came to Sahr when he was a journalism student at the University of Miami, he said, and saw firsthand the ``mediocrity'' of the educational system. Sahr, who is 30 and holds dual American and Israeli citizenship, divides his time between Tel Aviv and Miami. The company was founded in Florida, but is now run from Israel, where it has developed a Hebrew language site of its own. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Docsis 2.0 modems should be adopted relatively quickly, said Tim Savageaux, analyst at W.R. Hambrecht. While telecommunications companies are pulling back on capital spending as their profits plunge, cable companies continue to report strong cash flow, he said, and consumer demand for high-speed Internet access remains strong. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he says,	 Chang still plays Diablo for fun, he says, but the lure of big money puts a different spin on it. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he says,	 The problem, he says, is not Gap's size, but its merchandise. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, she said,	 The circulations of the magazines vary from 10,000 to more than 100,000 in the case of Bust, Stoller said. None of the magazines are audited by the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Bust makes a slim profit, she said, and as the magazine's circulation topped out at 100,000 this year, she decided to transform it from a quarterly to a monthly magazine beginning in January, and use a national newsstand distributor. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he added,	 That is particularly true now, he added, when ``the clients are asking `Is this the best way to spend my money?' _ if they have money.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, it seems,	 Animals have been part of the movie business from the beginning, even before Rin Tin Tin first fetched the sheriff or Cheetah clambered up Johnny Weissmuller's leg. But never before, it seems, has there been such a demand for them, what with the proliferation of films aimed at families and young audiences and the explosion in cable-television channels. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, they say,	 Still, humane association officials say, the treatment of animals in movies, television shows and commercials _ at least for those productions shot in the United States or monitored by the humane association _ is significantly better today than it was two or three decades ago. And the outlook is even brighter, they say, as greater proficiency with realistic-looking computer images will make it easier and cheaper to use digital animals for the trickiest and most dangerous stunts. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, we watch,	 ``What they are trying to do is say, `We are there, we watch, we monitor, therefore everything is fine,''' Derby said. ``But they can't say that. They're not there all the time. And while you can say that at least the situation for the animals is better than it would be if they weren't there, we don't really know.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 The morning after ``Harry'' showed at the festival, Paskaljevic sat over his breakfast _ just a cappuccino and some Dunhill cigarettes, really _ on a hotel terrace overlooking the water and moaned that he had perhaps celebrated his movie's friendly reception here a little too enthusiastically the night before. (His producers were even more thrilled, he said, because the film is to be released in the United States.) </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 And the little hangover was nothing, he said, compared with the one he worked up three days into filming ``Harry'' in the countryside outside Dublin, the day of Milosevic's outster. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Some of ``Harry'' was actually based on Milosevic, he said, though the story was adapted from a Chinese fable. ``Harry is an authoritarian,'' Paskaljevic said, ``and when he chooses George as his enemy because he's the most powerful man in the village, I thought of Milosevic making America his enemy. It's a metaphor for me.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 And even after Milosevic's arrest, he said, Serbia has not turned into a democracy overnight. ``Most of the guilty are unpunished,'' Paskaljevic said, ``and their children will be the bosses of my children, enriched as they were under Milosevic.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Beyond the reference to the newspaper's editorial policy, the Bronstein letter cited several other reasons the congressman should give The Chronicle an interview. One, he said, is that ``unlike other electronic and print media which rushed to print unfounded allegations, particularly those of an affair with a minister's daughter, we have refrained from tabloid coverage of the story.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 His departure, he said, had nothing to do with the Democrats' takeover of the Senate last spring _ and, more specifically, his loss of the chairmanship of the Banking Committee. ``The decision would have been the same whether we kept the Senate or not,'' he said, quickly adding, however, that he would have stayed if he seriously feared that a Democrat might take his seat. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Gramm insisted that he would leave Congress with no regrets (``I never agonize over a vote, I never second-guess things, and that's why I sleep good at night''), even as he acknowledged that his departure would come with some sadness. He knew, he said, that a victim of his stubborn, never-compromise style on Capitol Hill has been his friendship with Sen. , she said,	 Alice Moss, 49, a hospital fund-raiser in Beaufort, S.C., said that shortly after she enrolled her teen-age son in a wilderness therapy program for help with his drug problem and failing grades, the program mailed her and her husband, Dean, a utility executive, 12 audiocassettes on parenting. They listened to them in the car on the way to a vacation in New England. A lot of what they heard was about setting limits, she said, which had not been her strong suit. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he said,	 Martin Reynolds, research fellow at Gartner Dataquest, attributed Dell's success largely to its management's focus on cash flow and velocity. While competitors focus on maintaining gross margins, he said, Dell concentrates on quick turnover, even if it has to lower prices and margins to keep sales growing. Its build-to-order manufacturing system and minimal inventory of components lets it recoup its costs in a hurry _ sometimes it collects from customers even before it pays suppliers. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he said,	 Sahr said his customers ranged in age from about 12 to 25, most of them middle-school and high-school students. Of the 10,000 visitors to his site every day, he said, 8,000 on average are from the United States, 1,000 are Canadian and the remainder are from other countries. Anyone can log onto schoolsucks.com and download any of 5,000 research papers free on topics as diverse as the Magna Carta and encephalitis, sometimes even in Hebrew or French. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he insists,	 Rather than plagiarism, Sahr argues, what his site really offers students is a mixture of research and inspiration. The site helps intimidated students ``get their feet wet,'' providing bibliographies and research material. Besides, he insists, students would not use his Web site to plagiarize material because it would be too easy for teachers and professors to check the site themselves. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Sahr even offers a public-service defense of his business. The generally poor quality of the homework available for free on his site, he said, should send a red flag to educators that something is seriously wrong with today's schools. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 Sahr said that he and his two partners, Yasha Harari and Nimrod Carmi, did not exercise quality control. Anything and everything gets posted, he said, except for the occasional violent essay or anything that proselytizes for a political cause. As a result, a student downloading an essay has no way of knowing if the paper received an A or an F. ``We tell people, `You could be downloading garbage, and you probably are,''' Sahr said. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 The idea for the site came to Sahr when he was a journalism student at the University of Miami, he said, and saw firsthand the ``mediocrity'' of the educational system. Sahr, who is 30 and holds dual American and Israeli citizenship, divides his time between Tel Aviv and Miami. The company was founded in Florida, but is now run from Israel, where it has developed a Hebrew language site of its own. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

The PMs news desk, 212-556-1927, opens at 7 a.m. Eastern Time. To get story repeats before this hour call 212-621-1595 for reruns on AP DataFeatures or 214-980-8305 or 8367 for repeats on UPI DataNews.  NYT News Service  INTERNATIONAL _ (Moved in ``i'' category)  CHINA-U.S.-VISA (Beijing) _ In a year in which record numbers of Chinese have applied for visas _ and been rejected _ the American Embassy visa section here has suddenly become a focal point of anti-American resentment, its decisions derided as arbitrary and unfair. By Elisabeth Rosenthal.  PLANE-MISHAP (Toronto) _ The first reports were of an out-of-control flight salvaged at the last moment by quick thinking and heroism. But by now, the story of how a Canadian jet crossing the Atlantic survived disaster has changed into a tangle of missteps. By Barbara Crossette.  BERLIN-JEWISH-MUSEUM (Berlin) _ The tortured history of the life and destruction of Germany's Jews was on display Sunday night, as prominent politicians and cultural figures turned out for the opening of a new museum, in a building so strongly symbolic and emotionally disorienting as to overshadow the exhibit it houses. By Steven Erlanger.  U.N.-RACE (Durban, South Africa) _ What the actual results of the U.N. conference on racism might be. Will nations carry out the plan of action? By Rachel L. Swarns.  NATIONAL _ GENERAL (Moved in ``a'' category)  TROUBLED-TEENS (Colombia, S.C.) _ Parents who have given up trying to handle troubled teen-agers on their own now have more avenues of outside help than ever. They include therapeutic boarding schools, ``emotional growth'' schools and residential treatment schools. There also are rural farms and desert boot camps, many imposing strict military or religious discipline. Some are as well-established as a prep school, others as small and informal as a teacher's home. What they have in common is cost: usually thousands of dollars a month. A special report. By Sara Rimer.  With photos NYT 13 and 20.  MISS-LAND-DISPUTE (Canton, Miss.) _ Mississippi decided last year that nothing would stop its effort to acquire a huge Nissan truck factory and finally take a place in the international economy. It successfully outbid every other competing state for the plant. As part of the package, Mississippi agreed to acquire more than 1,500 acres for the plant using the state's power of eminent domain, if necessary, to move out homeowners living on the site. And that is when this high-revving engine of Mississippi's new economy ran directly into the Archie and Bouldin families, a small but unyielding pocket of an older Mississippi that is not quite as impressed by the rush to join the global economy. By David Firestone.  With map.  WORKING-MOMS (Undated) _ Two-thirds of American women with preschool children _ and 56 percent of those with infants under 1 year old _ are in the labor force, but by ratios of 3- or 4-to-1, Americans say it is best for mothers to stay home with their babies, says a new report. By Tamar Lewin.  With graphic.  ORE-TENT-CITY (Portland, Ore.) _ In an unusual move that has stretched the definition of public services for the homeless, Portland has provided a patch of land for the tent city and put in a water hook-up and portable toilets. By Sam Howe Verhovek.  With photo NYT 15.  WASHINGTON _ (Moved in ``w'' category)  CHILDREN-EXPLOIT (Washington) _ A study of the sexual exploitation of children in Canada, the United States and Mexico shows that the numbers of victims are higher than previously thought. But is it a byproduct of globalization? By Raymond Hernandez.  GRAMM-PROFILE (Washington) _ Profile of Sen. Phil Gramm. By Philip Shenon.  With photo NYT 14.  BUSINESS DAY _ (Moved in ``f'' category)  ECON-IMPLICATIONS (Washington) _ Whether or not it meets formal definitions, the economy, judging by Friday's unemployment report, is for all practical purposes in a recession. A look at the implications, ranging from the federal budget to Federal Reserve rate cuts. By Richard W. Stevenson.  MALPRACTICE-COSTS (Undated) _ Medical malpractice rates, stable for the last five years, are soaring, and doctors and hospitals are passing along their higher costs. Higher medical malpractice judgments, and settlements, are a major cause. By Joseph B. Treaster.  With graphic.  HYUNDAI-AIG (Seoul, South Korea) _ The American International Group has resolved a dispute with Hyundai Securities that appeared to remove the last major barrier in its takeover of the financial units of the Hyundai group, South Korea's largest conglomerate until its break-up last year. By Don Kirk.  SCHOOL-WEBSITE-PLAGIARISM (Undated) _ A look at SchoolSucks.com _ a Web site whose founder says it is providing a useful public service by posting student research papers. Educators say it looks a lot like an aid for plagiarism. By Laurie Flynn.  With photo NYT 9.  ATT-AOL-CABLE (Undated) _ AOL/Time Warner's negotiations to buy AT&AMP;T's cable operations appear to be getting serious. Checking whether AOL has made a formal offer, which would have huge implications for competitors and for the media deregulation debate. By Andrew Ross Sorkin.  CHINA-TV-MEDIA (Shanghai, China) _ AOL Time Warner and the News Corp. are both expected to win licenses soon from the Chinese government that will allow them to broadcast television programming into a portion of southern China. That was the positive news. But behind the hoopla that will surround the announcement of licenses is the realization that about 97 percent of China's 1.26 billion people will still be barred from receiving foreign broadcasts. A news analysis. By Craig S. Smith with Geraldine Fabrikant.  With photo NYT 11.  COMMENTARY (Moved in ``k'' category)  SAFIRE-COLUMN (Undated) _ Why the government should not hesitate to use the Social Security surplus to stimulate the economy. By William Safire.  HERBERT-COLUMN (Undated) _ In the race for the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York, racial mudslinging is obscuring issues important to city voters, including education and housing. By Bob Herbert.  SPORTS (Moved in ``s'' category)  TEN-VECSEY-COLUMN (New York) _ Sports of The Times on the U.S. Open men's final. By George Vecsey.  FBN-COLUMN-BRONCOS (Denver) _ On Pro Football article on the Broncos getting a new start in new stadium. By Thomas George.  FBC-RECAP (Undated) _ On College Football on the hopes of Fresno State. By Joe Lapointe.  ENTERTAINMENT (Moved in ``e'' category)  ANIMALS-IN-FILMS (Los Angeles) _ Animals have been part of the movie business from the very beginning, even before Rin Tin Tin first fetched the sheriff or Cheetah clambered up Johnny Weissmuller's leg. But never before, it seems, has there been such a demand for them, what with the proliferation of films aimed at families and young audiences and the explosion in cable-television channels. Despite slowdown in movie business, use of animals in films is up. Rick Lyman.  SERBIAN-DIRECTOR (Venice, Italy) _ Arts Abroad: The Serbian director Goran Paskaljevic and his strange and subversive film, ``How Harry Became a Tree,'' at the Venice Film Festival. By Melinda Henneberger.  AVA-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ Theodore Rosengarten reviews ``Ava's Man,'' by Rick Bragg. , he added,	 ``These days, it's all about numbers,'' he said. ``That's all they care about.'' There would be no more high-risk surgery, he added, unless the risk had been documented in detail. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 In the past, he said, surgeons were willing to take more chances, but now they cannot afford to do so. It is a lamentable situation, he added, because the sickest patients are being denied the surgery that may help them. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he said,	 Hueter said blacktips overlapped bulls ecologically because both were comfortable in warm, shallow waters. , he said,	 In past slowdowns, housing has tended to lead the economy's fall. (Will move on the ``s'' sports file.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010910.0338 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-TRAVEL-BRIEFS-$ADV16-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> NOTES FROM PHILADELPHIA, NEW YORK AND RAND McNALLY (For release Sunday, Sept. 16)  c.2001 New York Times News Service  Philadelphia Airport Adds a Terminal  US Airways has opened a $100 million terminal at Philadelphia International Airport for passengers on its regional jets and turboprops, part of a major expansion of its facilities there. The new terminal means that most passengers will no longer board and deplane on the Tarmac, where buses carried people to and from the existing terminals.  The 190,000-square-foot terminal is the largest in the United States devoted to regional flights. It has 38 gates, 24 of which offer covered jetways leading to the doors of regional jets. (US Airways uses 35, AirTran the other three.) The terminal also has a 10,000-square-foot food court and a 3,700-square-foot US Airways Club.  A free shuttle bus will take passengers to US Airways jet flights at Terminals A, B and C. A parking garage with space for 3,400 cars is to open later this year, said David Castelveter, a spokesman for the airline.  Next summer the airline plans to open an international terminal in Philadelphia for its flights to nine European cities.  Rand McNally Now More Than Maps  Rand McNally is trying to tap the Internet and its cartographic services to create competition for AAA. The new program, Rand McNally Road Explorers, will offer roadside assistance and discounts with hotels, rental-car companies and other highway-travel service benefits.  What Rand McNally hopes will set Road Explorers apart is its members' ability to tap into the Internet to print out detailed maps, similar to those found in its road atlases, and driving directions from the Web site. AAA members have long been able to order TripTiks, customized printed itineraries with highlighted road maps, to help plan a driving vacation. They can be prepared while a member waits at AAA branches, or ordered on the Web with a 14- to 21-day wait.  The Road Explorers program, expected to be launched this month, will have two levels of subscription annual memberships. Premier ($34.95) provides the discounts and mapping services; Premier Plus ($79.95) adds roadside assistance, including four tows a year, for any family member. Information, www.randmcnally.com.  Brazilian Treasures on Loan in New York  A monumental Baroque altarpiece from Brazil will occupy the rotunda of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum as part of ``Brazil: Body and Soul,'' from Oct. 12 to Jan. 27. The exhibition, numbering around 350 objects, will include artwork from the 17th and 18th centuries as well as modern and contemporary Brazilian pieces.  The recently restored altar is approximately 45 feet high and 26 feet wide and comes from the Monastery of Sao Bento in Olinda in northeast Brazil. Other highlights of the exhibition include feather capes and other body ornaments from the Amazonian and coastal regions, as well as gold and silver jewelry.  The modern section of the exhibition will include works from the 1920s and '30s by Tarsila do Amaral, Anita Malfatti and Lasar Segall, among others. Representing the 1950s to the'70s, when the Concrete and Neo-Concrete movements were in vogue, there will be a display of works by artists including Franz Weissman, Mary Vieira, Luis Sacilotto and Sergio Camargo.  Running concurrently with the show will be a film festival, a music program and a lecture series featuring Brazilian art scholars and a symposium called ``Brazil: Visual Culture Matters.''  The Brazilian exhibition moves to the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, in March.  Information: (212) 423-3500 or at www.guggenheim.org. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010910.0339 type=story > <HEADLINE> PINAULT WINS LONG BATTLE FOR CONTROL OF GUCCI GROUP </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> LONDON (BC-GUCCI-DEAL-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he says,	 But would the ocean ecology survive? ``Really, the capacity is determined by how much adverse environmental impact you're willing to accept,'' says Ken Caldeira, who directs the ocean-sequestration project at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. Mixing carbon dioxide into the water makes it more acidic, which potentially could harm marine organisms. Brewer doubts the amount of carbon we're likely to add will cause much harm, as the pH of seawater already varies significantly by location. Besides, he says, nature eventually delivers 80 percent of atmospheric carbon into the sea anyway: ``We already have an ocean CO2 disposal program we put it in the air and the air puts it in the ocean.'' Still, the technological and ecological uncertainties mean ocean sequestration won't be in widespread use anytime soon. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he said,	 Story Filed By Cox Newspapers </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010911.0141 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WORLD BUSINESS NEWS IN BRIEF  c.2001 New York Times News Service  SOUTH KOREA: MORE DEVELOPMENT URGED  President Kim Dae-jung called for overall economic development as the best antidote to declining exports to the United States, Japan and the European Union. Kim warned of growing economic difficulties while welcoming a new cabinet that he formed after the break-up of his ruling coalition last week. Korean manufacturers, he said, should not rely so heavily on export of products such as semiconductors, whose fall on world markets is blamed for Korea's plummeting export figures. Several hours later, at a reception for the country's top business leaders, Kim said his government would remove some of the restrictions that they say have impeded them since the economic crises of 1997 and 1998.  SWITZERLAND: WTO STILL SNAGGED ON CHINA  Negotiators trying to put the final touches on China's entry into the World Trade Organization appeared to be stymied by some last-minute problems, including the conditions that will govern the expansion of the insurance company, the American International Group. Envoys insisted they could meet Thursday's deadline to usher in one of the trade arbiter's biggest members. Among the remaining differences were exactly what goods China wants on its list of those subject to price controls. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010911.0142 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-TERROR-ART-ADVISORY-UPDATE2-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> We call your attention to a series of photos by Kristen Brochmann showing the south tower of the World Trade Center exploding. , they abruptly,	 How tiny is tiny in the ornithological kingdom? Imagine half a golf ball with wings, nosing around with a whittled-down tee for a beak, and you have the hummingbird, teeniest of birds. Endlessly mesmerizing avian midgets, they whiz and freeze, dart and park. Parking motionlessly on a nonexistent shelf for an instant or two, they abruptly, briskly take off _ backward . . . forward . . . up . . . down . . . cutting angles that would drive a helicopter off its rotor. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

The Boston Globe  ATTACK-BOSTON _ Authorities in Boston on Tuesday began searching for a terrorist cell that carried out the most crucial part of the most coordinated, audacious terrorist attack ever directed at Americans. Boston Police Superintendent-in-Chief James Hussey said a task force of local police, the State Police, the FBI and the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms was trying to determine if those who commandeered a pair of Boston-to-Los Angeles flights had been in Boston for some time, plotting the attack. By Kevin Cullen.  ATTACK-FLIGHT - A number of Boston business executives who had been on the Los Angeles-bound plane that rammed into the World Trade Center after an apparent hijacking were feared dead Tuesday. Framingham retailer TJX Cos., owner of the TJ Maxx and Marshalls discount stores, is believed to have had several employees aboard. By Steven Syre and Beth Healy.  ATTACK-BUSH (Washington) _ A shell-shocked President Bush vowed Tuesday to ``hunt down'' the terrorists that attacked New York's World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Reprising a refrain used by his father in the Gulf War, Bush solemnly declared, ``Terrorism against our nation will not stand.'' But within minutes, a plane slammed into the Pentagon. By Michael Kranish.  ATTACK-MARKETS _ The major financial markets remain closed at midday after the twin towers of the World Trade Center collapsed only blocks from Wall Street. By Ross Kerber.  ATTACK-TERROR (Washington) _ How could it have happened? Almost as soon as news spread of Tuesday's horrific attacks in New York and Washington, investigators began to explore a number of difficult questions, including which groups could coordinate such an orchestrated effort and how domestic security was penetrated. By John Donnelly.  ATTACK-LOGAN _ Two of the four US passenger jets known to have been hijacked Tuesday _ including one that crashed into and leveled one of the World Trade Center towers in New York City _ took off from Boston, adding new weight to long-running questions about the adequacy of security at Logan International Airport. By Matthew Brelis.  ATTACK-WEB _ The apparent terrorist attacks in New York and Washington sent millions of anxious Americans across the country scrambling to their phones and computers, overloading Web sites and telecommunications systems and causing many calls to be blocked. By Bruce Mohl.  For questions about stories, please call Jean Conley at the Boston Globe, 617-929-2597. For individual purchase of budgeted graphics or photos please call 212-556-4204 or 888-603-1036.  Cox News Service  TER-MAIN _ Ledeall on the unprecedented terror attacks on New York and Washington and the U.S. response. (Shephard/Emling, Cox News Service)  TER-BUSH _ While President George Bush spent the day moving from one secure location to another, chaos reigned at the White House, with staff standing on the sidewalks, without instructions or direction. Press operations were reduced to a junior staffer standing on a corner with a cell phone. (Heath, Cox News Service)  TER-FEDRESPONSE _ How is America going to respond? What did the military do, the State Department, etc. (Deans, Cox News Service)  TER-NTSB _ Reports on the plane crashes, how do they monitor them, the continuing investigation. Terrorism experts weigh in. Stock markets and transportation systems were shut down, and communications and banking were disrupted. The attacks could have a significant negative impact on the U.S. economy. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution) W/PHOTO  TV-TERROR-NETWORKS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ In a matter of minutes, all sets were tuned to CNN. From New York City came the report of what appeared to be a bizarre accident: A plane crashed into one of the World Trade Center towers. People had seen it, but couldn't agree: It was a prop plane; a commuter plane; a jet; a missile. (Dempsey, Dayton Daily News) MOVED IN NEWS AND FEATURE CATEGORIES.  TER-RELIGION _ Thoughts turn spiritual in times of national crisis. (White, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  OPED/EDITORIAL  EDIT-TERROR-INFAMY _ Dec. 7, 1941, the date that will live in infamy forever, has been eclipsed by Sept. 11, 2001. The United States of America has fallen under attack by foreign enemies, just as it came under attack by the forces of imperial Japan almost 60 years ago. (Grand Junction News-Sentinel). MOVED.  EDIT-TERROR-OLIVER _ Monday night on the History Channel, I watched ``Moment of Truth'' with historian and author Stephen Ambrose. It centered on World War II and the ordinary men and women who answered in various heroic ways the call to arms after our country was attacked. Each spoke of that particular moment _ in a foxhole or parachuting behind enemy lines or scaling a cliff with the enemy shooting at them like fish in a barrel _ that was for them a moment of truth. Tuesday morning, again on television, I watched history in the making. (Thomas Oliver, Atlanta Journal). MOVED.  EDIT-TERROR-JOURNAL _ In the heady days after Japan's surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, colleagues rushed to congratulate Adm. Isoroku Yamamoto, the man who had planned and executed the stunning operation. He was far less enthusiastic about his success; Japan, he feared, had only ``awakened a sleeping giant and filled him with a terrible resolve.'' (Atlanta Journal)  TER-BAXTER-COLUMN _ How this affects every part of government and your life. (Baxter, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  EMOTION-TERROR-0912-COX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ As the story unfolded in all its explosive horror, we went from shocked disbelief to irrational fear. From fear to relief. And, finally, to anger. (D.L. Stewart, Dayton Daily News.) MOVED.  LATHAM-TERROR _ MARSHALL, Texas _ I wanted to tell employees to get back to work and away from the television. ``There's a newspaper to get out,'' I wanted to say in a stern voice. But the TV news wouldn't let him. (Latham, Marshall News Messenger). MOVED.  HOW TO REACH US  Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.  News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.  Assistant news editor Alan Gordon, 404-526-7282, agordon(at)coxnews.com  Cox Washington Bureau:  News editor Carl Rauscher, 202-887-8307, crausher(at)coxnews.com  Foreign editor Chuck Holmes, 202-887-8320 , chuckh(at)coxnews.com  Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com  Photo Editor Rick McKay 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com  Hearst News Service  WASHINGTON (``w'' category)  TERROR-RDP (Undated) _ In the worst attack on U.S. soil since the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 at the start of World War II, terrorists staged a series of attacks Tuesday that sent two hijacked passenger airliners hurtling into the twin 110-story World Trade Center towers in Manhattan and a third passenger jetliner crashing into the Pentagon across the river from the White House. Authorities feared thousands of casualties and President Bush vowed revenge. By STEWART M. POWELL.  TERROR-SUSPECTS (Washington) _ Osama bin Laden topped the list of suspects as the mastermind of the worst terrorism attack against the United States in history. Bin Laden was linked to attacks against U.S. embassies in Africa in 1998 and the USS Cole last year. His organization is one of the few with combination of technical sophistication and fanatical zeal required for carrying out such attacks. By DAN FREEDMAN.  TERROR-INTELLIGENCE (Washington) _ Analysts blame a colossal intelligence failure for the worst terrorist attack in U.S. history. The size and complexity of the attack highlighted the weaknesses of U.S. ability to detect and deter suicidal fanatics. By CHARLES POPE.  TERROR-PENTAGON (Washington) _ The western side of the Pentagon _ the mighty fortress that serves as the nation's military command center _ was cratered after a passenger jet crashed into it. A Pentagon spokesman said there were extensive casualties and an unknown number of fatalities. ``It felt like a tornado _ like something was trying to lift the roof of the building,'' said one woman who works in the five-sided structure. BY LARA JAKES.  TERROR-CAPITOL (Washington) _ As the worst terrorist attack in U.S. history unfolded Tuesday morning, members of Congress with grimly evacuated the Capitol Building and expressed stunned outrage and vowed revenge. By JUDY HOLLAND and DAVID EGGERT.  TERROR-HIJACKINGS (Undated) _ The worst U.S. terrorist attack in U.S. history centered around the near-simultaneous hijackings of three airliners that added to the casualty toll. Investigators were uncertain if the crash of a fourth passenger jet was part of the attack. By MARK HELM and TIMOTHY SPENCE.  TERROR-SCENE (Washington) _ White House staffers raced from the West Wing and anxious tourists were ushered to shelter by Secret Service officers with automatic weapons when the White House was evacuated in the middle of the worst terrorist attack in U.S. history. By GARY MARTIN.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  MEANS-COLUMN (Washington) _ The fear and outrage that gripped the nation following the terrorist attacks Tuesday recalls similar emotions that penetrated Americans in November 1963 in the wake of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. By MARIANNE MEANS.  If you have questions, please call Chuck Lewis or Tim Spence at 202-298-6920.  The New York Times Regional Newspaper Group  BC-TERROR-DISNEYWORLD-NYTR (Lakeland, Fla.) _ Walt Disney World closed its parks Tuesday morning following the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. The Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center, Disney-MGM Studios and Animal Kingdom attractions, as well as the three water parks and its shopping and entertainment complex, were cleared of all visitors and employees. By Elizabeth McCormick.  Story has moved.  BC-TERROR-DC-REACT-NYTR (Washington) _ (Washington) _ At first, only bewilderment and disbelief were on the streets of the nation's capital on Tuesday. As updates came in, the mood changed to concern and horror. The streets around the White House and Pentagon were cordoned off. Tour buses and sightseers were turned away. By George Graham.  Story has moved.  BC-TERROR-FLIGHT-RECORDER-NYTR (Sarasota, Fla) _ What happened prior to the crash that began the terrorist assault on America? The best clues may emerge from flight data recorders and cockpit voice recorders, if the equipment survived the fire that engulfed the north tower of New York's World Trade Center. By Michael Pollick.  Story has moved.  BC-TERROR-BUSH-FLA-NYTR (Sarasota, Fla.) _ President Bush was first informed of the World Trade Center disaster soon after it began at about 8:45 a.m., just as he was beginning a visit to Emma E. Booker Elementary School here. After a quick debriefing, he came back to address the crowd of students, parents and teachers briefly. ``Today we've had a national tragedy,'' Bush told the group, which had gathered to hear the president talk about his education plans and a reading program at the school. By Tom Lyons, Jill Barton and Chris Davis. , he said,	 At 21, Oscar Wilde, a prodigy looking forward to a prodigious career, summarized his ambition in life as ``success: fame or even notoriety.'' Twenty-five years later, as death approached, he said, ``I wrote when I did not know life, now that I do know the meaning of life, I have no more to write.'' And: ``My time is short _ my work is done _ and when I cease to live, that work will begin to live.'' His work, he predicted, would be his ``great monument.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he says,	 Ridgely Evers, a Bay Area computer executive, is among those aiming to make a California olive oil to rival Tuscany's. Evers ``reverse-engineered'' his oil, he says, after tasting the oil from Fattoria Mansi Bernardini, a 350-year-old Tuscan farm. Intent on replicating that taste, he imported the same four Tuscan olive varieties in the same proportions used at Mansi Bernardini and planted 22 acres of them on his Healdsburg estate. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he says,	 Nevertheless, Evers says that he is just now breaking even and he seems unconvinced that the business will ever make money. At tastings, when customers flinch at the price ($24 for 375 ml.), he jokingly tells them that they can pay his cost instead. European producers make money, he says, because their land is already amortized and they receive government subsidies. For a California producer who, like Evers, is growing olives on prime vineyard ground, the return on investment looks particularly slim. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

NY-CHURCH-GARDEN (New York) _ You can hear the sound of water before you see it, burbling out of the fountain at the newly restored biblical garden at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The garden, tucked behind the church that towers over Amsterdam Avenue at 113th Street, offers solace to those in search of calm, a place to do some soul-searching or to simply contemplate a flower. This week, many people sought its benches and the shade of its grapevine-covered arbors. ``I saw many people throughout the day sitting in silence in the garden,'' the Rev. Jay Wegman said Wednesday, recalling the crowds that came on Tuesday, the day terrorists attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. You could hear sirens, he said, and children playing in the schoolyard next to the garden. By Anne Raver.  GARDEN-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Garden questions answered. By Leslie Land.  GARDEN-COLUMN (Undated) _ Euphboria: Just try to envision a poinsettia on steroids. By Anne Raver.  Others as time permits. For information on stories, or for reruns, please call: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For information on NYT photos and graphics, please call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  Business Day Front Page of The New York Times, Thursday, Sept. 13.  (Lede)  TERROR-ECON (Washington) _ Central banks around the world swung into action Wednesday in a coordinated effort to calm financial markets and reduce the chances that the attack on the United States would lead to a global economic crisis. By Richard W. Stevenson.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  (Center display)  TERROR-MISSING-FIRM (New York) _ Until Tuesday, few people beyond the rarefied world of the government bond market had ever heard of Cantor Fitzgerald LP. But in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center, the 57-year-old firm has emerged as a magnet for Wall Street's concern about the devastation and personal tragedy that the financial community has experienced. Of the 1,000 employees who worked at the company's headquarters on the 101st, 103rd, 104th and 105th floors of One World Trade Center, the first tower to be hit in Tuesday's attack, only about 270 had been accounted for by Monday afternoon. And almost all of those had been on vacation or otherwise out of the building. By Diana B. Henriques and Jennifer 8. Lee.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  TERROR-LIABILITY (Undated) _ The families of almost everyone who died in the World Trade Center attack or in the rescue effort are entitled to some kind of compensation, lawyers and experts in employee benefits say. So are the passengers and crews of the planes that were rammed into the twin towers. Some insurers estimate that they may end up paying $30 billion to $40 billion, or at least twice as much as the worst previous insurance disaster in the United States, Hurricane Andrew in 1992. And contrary to some reports, these policies do not exclude acts of terrorism, said Dean O'Hare, the chief executive of the Chubb Group. ``If it's terrorism, it's absolutely covered,'' O'Hare said. By David Johnston and Joseph B. Treaster.  (Scheduled to move by 8 p.m. ET.)  (Center right)  TERROR-MARKET (New York) _ A reeling financial community decided late Wednesday to resume trading of bonds on Thursday but to delay the resumption of stock trading for at least one more day. ``New York is the financial capital of the world,'' Richard Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, as he announced the decision, which was reached after a prolonged meeting of government and financial industry officials. ``It has been, it is, and it will remain so in the future.'' By Jonathan Fuerbringer and Alex Berenson.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  (Bottom)  TERROR-NORRIS-COLUMN (New York) _ If the motive was to halt the operations at the heart of the capitalist system of financial trading, then the terrorist attacks on Tuesday were a success. Wednesday, dispirited people found it their duty to rapidly reconstruct an intricate financial system. So the work went on even as Wall Streeters learned which of their colleagues had died and which firms had lost the bulk of their personnel. By Floyd Norris.  (Scheduled to move by 8 p.m. ET.)  Here are tonight's columns and regular features:  BIZGLANCE (Undated) _ Digest of the day's financial stories.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. , he said,	 ``If it's terrorism, it's absolutely covered,'' O'Hare said in an interview. Increases in terrorism prompted some London insurers to start excluding it a few years ago, he said, although separate terrorism coverage is easy to obtain there. It remains part of standard policies in the United States. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, they said,	 ``I suppose the first thing that would pop into most people's minds would be that perhaps the security of the airlines or at the airports was lax,'' said William Shernoff, a lawyer in Claremont, Calif., who represents plaintiffs in insurance cases. ``That would probably be the most fertile ground.'' The insurers' and plaintiffs' lawyers say they expect an avalanche of lawsuits against the airlines, the security companies that the airlines hired to screen passengers at the airports, and the government agencies that run the airports. In addition, they said, under a federal anti-terrorism law, families can sue any terrorist organizations that are deemed responsible, even though collecting any judgment would be next to impossible. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 When buildings collapse, victims' families often sue the owners, the architects and the contractors, Shernoff said. But in the World Trade Center case, he said, it was difficult for him to see how the building or those responsible for it had been at fault. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 The coverage is usually based on employees' compensation, said Stuart J. Brahs, a vice president of the Principal Financial Group, based in Washington. Executives, he said, often receive life insurance coverage equal to half their annual pay. , it seemed,	 One man walked up to a mail carrier near the main post office and asked if delivery would be normal Wednesday. The mail carrier didn't miss a step. He said, ``Sure. The mail's coming today. The mail comes every day.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010913.0006 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-BIZGLANCE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> BUSINESS AT A GLANCE  c.2001 New York Times News Service  WRECKAGE ON WALL STREET IS EMOTIONAL AND PRACTICAL  Wall Street employs about 200,000 people, enough to fill a good-sized city. But when disaster struck at its heart, it seemed more like a large extended family that had just suffered unimaginable losses and was wondering just how it would right itself.  Everyone, it seemed, had a friend, family member, co-worker or competitor who had reason to be in the World Trade Center on any given day. And the attack wrought a combination of emotional wreckage and urgent pressure to sort out business issues involving billions of dollars.  COMPANIES TRY TO RESTORE ORDER  Across corporate America, senior managers and executives grappled with trying to restore at least a semblance of business as usual _ even as they knew that, emotionally at least, it was anything but. Executives, many of them stranded in cities hundreds of miles from their usual bases, set up command posts in hotels and in offices borrowed from clients and customers as they tried to run their companies and figure out how to get home.  The gears of the economy began grinding again, though many of the human beings turning the cranks needed comforting and many of their customers were depressed.  TRAVEL INDUSTRY STILL IN TURMOIL  With the nation's airports closed, thousands of travelers struggling to return home from business trips, and conferences and corporate meetings canceled, the business travel industry, including airlines, hotels and car rental companies, faces turmoil for the coming week and uncertainty about prospects in the near future.  Federal authorities said that most planes would remain grounded until extra security measures could be put in place. It could take days for the air-travel system to return to any degree of normalcy.  OPEC VOWS TO MAINTAIN OIL SUPPLY  Oil-producing countries have hurried to issue assurances that the attacks and any subsequent retaliation by the United States will not affect petroleum supplies. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, which produces about 40 percent of the world's oil, said its members would not use oil as a political weapon as the U.S. reaction to the attacks takes shape in the weeks ahead.  BUSINESSES FACE LOSS OF RECORDS  As businesses began to digest the loss of life, they also had to address the loss of records. While many financial firms have automatic backups of their records, law firms are especially dependent on hard copies of documents that might be used in litigation or as legally binding originals.  EXODUS FROM NEW YORK FEARED  Some business executives, especially those in the real estate industry, expressed fear that more companies will move out of New York City to places with lower costs, more available land and fewer risks.  MEDIA COMPANIES POSTPONE PLANS  Television networks backed away from premiere dates for entertainment series; advertisers scrapped plans for product campaigns; Hollywood studios postponed dates for releases of big-budget movies; and publishers canceled promotional activities for high-profile new books. The print newsmagazines, on the other hand, are publishing special issues Thursday and Friday.  The coverage of the attacks brought tens of millions of Americans to television sets throughout Tuesday, peaking in President Bush's address to the nation, which according to preliminary figures, reached about 80 million viewers.  U.S. ACCOUNT DEFICIT NARROWS  The U.S. current account deficit narrowed in the second quarter as slowing economies around the world reduced the level of trade, government figures showed. The current account shortfall, the broadest measure of international commerce because it includes investments, shrank to $106.5 billion in the April-June period after narrowing to a revised $111.8 billion in the first quarter. As the United States and global economies have cooled, imports and exports have declined.  G.E. AND HONEYWELL APPEAL RULING  General Electric and Honeywell have appealed the European Commission's rejection of their $45 billion merger, the European Court of Justice said. The appeal is not aimed at resurrecting the deal but is an effort to nullify the ruling that GE has a dominant position in the aerospace sector. That ruling, if left unchallenged, could prevent GE from making future acquisitions. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010913.0007 type=story > <HEADLINE> ATTACK DRAWS NATION TO TV COVERAGE </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-TERROR-TV-RATINGS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
