To get story repeats before this hour call 212-621-1595 for reruns on AP DataFeatures or 214-980-8305 or 8367 for repeats on UPI DataNews.  NYT News Service  TERROR ATTACK (Moved in ``a'' category)  The New York Times plans 30 pages of stories, photos and graphics on the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington. Following is an early list of the stories being planned.  For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.  TERROR-RDP (New York) _ On the day after hijackers commandeered commercial jetliners and crashed them into two of the most visible symbols of America's financial and military might, President Bush on Wednesday condemned the attacks while investigators began piecing together leads and rescue workers continued their somber search through the ash-coated rubble. By Robert D. McFadden.  TERROR-VICTIMS (Undated) _ On the people who perished in the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks. By Janny Scott.  TERROR-NY-RESCUE (New York) _ Rescuers pulled seven people from the rubble of the devastated World Trade Center today as the search continued for survivors and victims of Tuesday's airborne attacks. By Dan Barry.  (An early version of this story by Terence Neilan has moved.)  TERROR-BOSTON-CLUES (Boston) _ Developing. Arrests reported in Boston; a look at what we know about the terrorist operations there. (Byline to come)  TERROR-FLORIDA-CLUES (Dateline to come) _ Developing. Arrests reported in South Florida; a look at what we know about the terrorist operations in Florida. By Dana Canedy.  With  TERROR-SUSPECT (Dateline to come) _ On Mohammed Atta. By Kevin Sack.  And  TERROR-FLORIDA-SCHOOL (Daytona, Fla.) _ One investigation centers on a prominent flight instruction school. By Jim Yardley.  Four reconstructions of the events and people on board the four hijacked aircraft:  TERROR-FLIGHT-11 (Undated) _ American Airlines Flight 11, en route from Boston to Los Angeles, carrying 81 passengers, nine flight attendants and two pilots, was the first to crash into the World Trade Center. By John Kifner.  TERROR-FLIGHT-175 (Undated) _ United Flight 175, carrying 56 passengers, two pilots and seven flight attendents, was the second plane to crash into the World Trade Center. By William Glaberson.  TERROR-FLIGHT-77 (Washington) _ Americans Airlines Flight 77, Dulles to Los Angeles, with Barbara Olson and 57 other passengers, four flight attendants and two pilots, crashed into the Pentagon at 9:40 a.m. By Elaine Sciolino.  TERROR-FLIGHT (Undated) _ United Flight 93, Newark to San Francisco, carrying 38 passengers, two pilots and five flight attendants, crashed southeast of Pittsburgh around 10 a.m. By Jodi Wilgoren.  TERROR-TRANSPORT (Chicago) _ U.S. air travel is scheduled to crank up again in midafternoon. Chicago, Denver, Atlanta under tight security. Are people eager to get home or are they afraid to fly? Highways are jammed; train and bus stations still crazed. By Pam Belluck.  TERROR-AFGHAN (Kabul, Afghanistan) _ If anyone is thinking about bombing Afghanistan back into the Stone Age, it won't have far to go. Kabul, capital of one of the poorest countries in the world where the average lifespan is 40, presents an apocalyptic picture. By Barry Bearak.  TERROR-U.S.-IMAGE (Undated) _ Is resentment of the United States growing? Does this distaste, even hatred, outweigh the cultural magnetism of a country whose products, films and music are consumed, seen and heard all over the world and which draws millions of immigrants every year? By John F. Burns.  TERROR-DIPLO (Washington) _ Is this the moment at which the Bush administration embraces unilateralism more wholeheartedly? Is it the time to reach out to the Arab leaders who had warned of violence as a consequence of what the Arab street sees as America's undiluted support of Israel? By Jane Perlez.  TERROR-NY-MORGUE (New York) _ The scene at the makeshift morgues and the mechanics and forensics of identifying the bodies. By Jim Dwyer.  TERROR-NY-MOURNS (New York) _ Makeshift memorials are springing up around the city. By Amy Waldman.  TERROR-NY-VOLUNTEERS (New York) _ Volunteers are showing up at hospitals, shelters and other sites by the hundreds. By Mirta Ojito.  TERROR-NY-RECONSTRUCT (New York) _ What happened inside the World Trade Center from the time the first plane hit until the second tower fell, with the emphasis on the decision to evacuate or not. (Byline to come)  TERROR-NY-HOMELESS (New York) _ The people left homeless after the World Trade Center attacks. By Randal C. Archibold and Andy Newman.  TERROR-NY-CLEANUP (New York) _ How they will clean up the mess to end all messes: getting rid of the dust, the asbestos, the debris, and all the environmental implications. By Kirk Johnson.  TERROR-NY-AIRPORTS (New York) _ The scene at the three New York airports. By Mary Jo Murphy.  TERROR-WTC-OBIT (New York) _ An obituary for the World Trade Center and the community that worked there. By David W. Dunlap.  TERROR-NY-MOOD (New York) _ The mood of a city that will never be the way it was a day ago. By N.R. Kleinfield.  TERROR-COMMERCE (Denver) _ The nation cranks back to life: post offices, gas lines, public business, etc. By Blaine Harden.  TERROR-PATRIOTISM (Undated) _ On how it feels now to be an American. By Timothy Egan.  TERROR-REACT-VOICES (Undated) _ Short (300 word) vignettes from a bloodline, a war memorial, a post office, a school.  TERROR-U.S.-BASES (Ft. Bragg, N.C.) _ Security at U.S. military bases. By Francis X. Clines.  TERROR-MUSLIMS (Undated) _ Anti-Muslim incidents have been reported around the country. By Laurie Goodstein and Gustav Niebuhr.  TERROR-MISSILE (Washington) _ What chance does missile defense have now in Congress? By Adam Clymer.  TERROR-IMF (Washington) _ The World Bank and IMF meetings have been canceled; the World Trade Organization meeting in Doha, Qatar in late November may be postponed. By Joseph Kahn.  TERROR-EUROPE (Brussels, Belgium) _ NATO and European Union allies meet to discuss the attacks on the United States. By Suzanne Daley.  TERROR-FRANCE (Paris) _ Americans are stranded all over Paris _ at the airport, the embassy, the sights. By Donald G. McNeil Jr.  TERROR-PALESTINIANS (Dateline to come) _ Palestinian officials are attempting damage control by stressing their sorrow at the terror attacks on America and saying that anybody who expressed pleasure was very much in a minority. By James Bennet.  TERROR-ARAB-REACT (Cairo, Egypt) _ Reaction to the attacks on the United States from the Arab world. By Neil MacFarquhar.  TERROR-ASIA (Tokyo) _ Throughout Asia, people poured over newspapers, tracked television reports by the hour and swamped telephone and internet networks for news of loved ones in the United States who might have been killed or hurt in Tuesday's attacks on New York and Washington. By Howard W. French.  (An early version of this story will move by 3 p.m. EDT.)  TERROR-AIR-FUEL-BOMB (Undated) _ Once you figure out how much jet fuel you need, anyone can use a plane to destroy the WTC. Re-engineering the air-fuel bomb. By James Glanz.  TERROR-MENTAL-HEALTH (Undated) _ What we know about how the impact of this event will echo in people's lives. Answer: it depends. By Erica Goode.  TERROR-RESCUE-TECH (Washington) _ Heat, sound, dogs and other ways of detecting victims, living and dead. Cell phone triangulation etc. By Warren E. Leary.  TERROR-AIR-DEFENSES (Undated) _ A look at air defenses we now have, and might have had. By William J. Broad.  BUSINESS DAY _ (Moved in ``f'' category)  TERROR-NORRIS-COLUMN (New York) _ If the motive was to halt the operations at the heart of the capitalist system of financial trading, then the terrorist attacks on Tuesday were a success. Wednesday, dispirited people found it their duty to rapidly reconstruct an intricate financial system. So the work went on even as Wall Streeters learned which of their colleagues had died and which firms had lost the bulk of their personnel. By Floyd Norris.  COMMENTARY (Moved in ``k'' category)  HERBERT-COLUMN _ Commentary by Bob Herbert.  SAFIRE-COLUMN _ Commentary by William Safire.  FRIEDMAN-COLUMN _ Commentary by Thomas L. Friedman.  ENTERTAINMENT (Moved in ``e'' category)  GRIEF-ARTS (Undated) _ In a series of 500 words pieces, critics for The New York Times discuss how grief is expressed in the arts. These pieces may be used singly or in combination.  TERROR-IMAGINATION (Undated) _ A Critic's Notebook: Life overtakes imagination. By Michiko Kakutani.  OATES-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ Joyce Carol Oates' new novel ``Middle Age: A Romance'' is about just what its plodding title suggests: middle age, and the series of mid-life crises that overtake the residents of a wealthy New York City suburb. Reviewed by Michiko Kakutani.  HOME (Moving in ``h'' category)  NY-CHURCH-GARDEN (New York) _ You can hear the sound of water before you see it, burbling out of the fountain at the newly restored biblical garden at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The garden, tucked behind the church that towers over Amsterdam Avenue at 113th Street, offers solace to those in search of calm, a place to do some soul-searching or to simply contemplate a flower. This week, many people sought its benches and the shade of its grapevine-covered arbors. ``I saw many people throughout the day sitting in silence in the garden,'' the Rev. Jay Wegman said Wednesday, recalling the crowds that came on Tuesday, the day terrorists attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. You could hear sirens, he said, and children playing in the schoolyard next to the garden. By Anne Raver.  GARDEN-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Garden questions answered. By Leslie Land.  GARDEN-COLUMN (Undated) _ Euphboria: Just try to envision a poinsettia on steroids. By Anne Raver.  CIRCUITS (Moving in `a' category)  CIR-CIRCUITS-COLUMN (Undated) _ The weekly column: New digital cameras that fit in a shirt pocket. By David Pogue.  CIR-GEEK-NOTES (Undated) _ Techno news and notes.  CIR-ONLINE-SHOPPING (Undated) _ The weekly feature: On buying a griddle _ when too many choices is a bad thing. By Michelle Slatalla.  CIR-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Techno questions answered. By J.D. Biersdorfer.  CIR-GAME-THEORY (Undated) _ The weekly feature: Empire of the Ants and Stretch Panic. By Charles Herold. , it reads,	 This fan painting was once backed by a calligraphic inscription, now displayed separately. A couplet by the eighth-century poet Wang Wei, it reads, ``Walking to where the water ends, I sit and watch when clouds rise,'' and it was transcribed on the fan by the Southern Song emperor Lizong, Ma Lin's patron. Such imperial collaborations were a regular feature of Song art, though few matching pairs survive. This one, in which verse, writing and painting are temperamentally in sync, is among the finest. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he says,	 For years, Tufts University child developmentalist David Elkind's formula for extra-curricular activities was to start a child at about age 7 with three activities: something social (scouting or a church group); something creative (an instrument or art); something physical (a sport or dance). The idea was to tweak different areas of development. (Children younger than 7 don't need structured programs of any kind, he says, as long as they are in a good early-childhood program.) </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, it seems,	 TERROR-US-ANALYSIS _ WASHINGTON _ As a youth, Chuck Butler came to Washington for the funeral of President Kennedy, and he returned five years later to protest the war in Vietnam. On Tuesday, he stood at the edge of the Potomac River and looked with sadness and anger upon the dark plume of smoke rising up from the smoldering rubble of the Pentagon. ``This city means freedom to me,'' he said. ``Now, I'm really worried for our country.'' The mightiest superpower in history, it seems, has suddenly been laid naked by terrorists willing to use commerical aircraft as weapons in a war that targets civilians. What sort of sacrifice can Americans expect to make in the weeks and months ahead, as the country and its institutions gird for this grim new war? And how much, after all, can the country change and still stay true to its core calling as a beacon of freedom for the rest of the world? (Deans, Cox News Service) </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 TERROR-SKYSCRAPERS _ ATLANTA _When Housh Rahimzadeh saw the second plane dive into the World Trade Center, he knew exactly what would happen next. But John Portman's chief engineer was in Atlanta, watching television, and could do nothing but watch the laws of physics do their fatal and inevitable work. The men and women who build and design skyscrapers and skylines say this most American style of architecture _ full of majesty and ego _ will survive the the NYC disaster. But it will be changed, and possibly be shorn of its braggadacio. This may be more of a pastiche of observations from Atlanta and NYC architects, including John Portman: one in Manhattan says speculation has already begun about what will take the WTC's place. Rahimzadeh explains why the WTC was the collision of a aberrant act of terrorism on the one building that would react as it did. Atlanta's skyscrapers are built differently, and would react differently. Hopefully, he said, they would survive longer. And one Atlanta architect says the bombing may have put the lid on ego trips that the trips that the Donald Trumps of the world are inclined toward. (G alloway, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

It has sexual situations. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010913.0260 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WORLD BUSINESS NEWS IN BRIEF  c.2001 New York Times News Service  ASIA  SOUTH KOREA: DEAL FOR HYUNDAI STAKE  The terrorist attacks in the United States helped drive down Hyundai Securities shares so much Thursday that its board readily agreed to sell a controlling block of shares to the American International Group. The company had hesitated earlier to accept AIG's offer of 7,000 won ($5.50) a share because it was more than 10 percent below the stock's market price before the attacks. Controlling stakes in two other Hyundai financial businesses will also be acquired by AIG, which will spend $850 million in all; the Korean government will invest $750 million for minority interests.  SOUTH KOREA: STIMULUS PLAN  Faced with new forecasts of much slower growth, the government announced a plan to spend $8 billion on road and railroad construction, including building a rail line to the new Inchon airport and restoring a line to North Korea that has been closed since 1950. A private research institute predicted that the economy would grow only 1.7 percent, not 6 percent, in the second half of 2001.  EUROPE  SWITZERLAND: ACQUISITION TALKS  The Zurich Financial Services Group confirmed that it is in an advanced stage of negotiations with Deutsche Bank to acquire asset manager Zurich Scudder Investments. As part of the deal, Zurich may acquire Deutsche Herold and other Deutsche Bank insurance subsidiaries in Europe but hang onto its British asset manager, Threadneedle. Zurich Financial said there would be no additional statement until negotiations are completed.  AUSTRALIA: AIRLINE SHUTS DOWN  Ansett Australia, the only national competitor to Qantas, said early on Friday that it would immediately suspend all flights. The airline, a subsidiary of Air New Zealand, filed for the equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection earlier this week and is being run by administrators from PricewaterhouseCoopers, who said the company's daily losses were so high and its finances so weak that it had no choice but to stop flying. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010913.0261 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-SUNBIZ-EARLY-BUDGET-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The New York Times News Service has scheduled the following money and business articles for release Sunday, Sept. 16. If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927.  ON THE SECTION FRONT  WTC-RELOCATION (New York) _ Along with offices in midtown, Alan Weil's law firm had 600 employees on five floors of One World Trade Center. When Weil got word that almost all of the employees of Sidly Austin Brown &AMP; Wood were safe, his relief was tainted by a chilling thought: if his 135-year-old firm was going to recover, he would have to act quickly. By noon, he had arranged to lease four more floors in the midtown building. Others within the firm set up delivery of 800 desks, 300 computers and cellphones by the score; contractors were hired to expand the company's computer network. You can get almost anything in New York over night, but even more important were the employees. Some walked from the rubble at the trade center to the midtown offices to report to work. The firm will be back in business Monday. By John Schwartz.  With photo and graphic.  ECONOMY (New York) _ What happens to the economy now? Louis Uchitelle identifies sectors that will be hard hit and explains the outlook for recovery. With photo and graphic.  MARKET-WATCH (New York) _ The Market Watch column on subject to come. By Gretchen Morgenson.  With graphic.  TERROR-RELATED STORIES  INVEST-AIRLINES (Undated) _ There are fears that losses by the U.S. aviation industry, which comprises 3% of gross domestic product, could exceed the $4.8 billion the industry lost in 1992, when it faced a recession and terrorism fears resulting from the war in the Persian Gulf. One airline, Midway, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday. ``This will be the worst year we've ever had,'' said Darryl Jenkins, director of the Aviation Institute at George Washington University in Washington, D.C. By Micheline Maynard.  With photo and graphic.  STRATEGIES-COLUMN (Undated) _ Studies show that noneconomic catastrophes, including the bombing of Pearl Harbor, the assassination of President Kennedy and bombing in Oklahoma City, do not have a lasting impact on the stock market. By Mark Hulbert.  With graphic.  CATASTROPHE-VETERANS (Undated) _ Personal accounts of veteran financial experts who have weathered market catastrophes. By Robert Hershey Jr.  TRAUMA-ADVICE (Undated) _ For people who were struggling with distressing issues, such as a divorce or job loss, last week's tragedy at the World Trade center and the Pentagon probably heightened their sadness. For many, the first repair mechanism is a downward comparison, being grateful to be alive, even if jobless. Returning to normal life as quickly as possible is meaningful, as is reaching out to others. By Ellyn Spragins.  With photo.  OTHER FEATURES  PROFILE-JAMES-ANTITRUST (Washington) _ Charles A. James, head of the antitrust division at the Justice Dept., is charged with resolving the most important antitrust case in a generation. In an interview, it is clear he would prefer settlement to conflict. By Stephen Labaton.  INVEST-DOLLAR-STORES _ With retail stores generally braced for poor earnings, dollar stores may offer promising returns. By Elizabeth Kelleher.  CYBIKOROOT-GAMES (Bloomingdale, Ill.) _ Cybiko, a maker of a wireless communication/games device, is run by David Yang, a Chinese Armenian in Moscow. Where else but Russia, he asks, can you start a company, hire 80 programmers and designers and produce a prototype for a communication device in less than a year for under $150,000? By Elizabeth Stanton.  With photo.  COLUMNS  MARKET-INSIGHT (Undated) _ The Market Insight Q&AMP;A. Subject to come. By Kenneth N. Gilpin.  PRELUDES-COLUMN (New York) _ More young people are joining the family business. Many of them had vowed to stay away, but because of the economy or the loss of their old jobs, it's now a more attractive option. By Abby Ellin. SHORT ITEMS  EBAY-SUSPENSION (Undated) _ EBay Inc., the largest Internet auction company, imposed a temporary ban on the sale of items related to the World Trade Center and the Pentagon in the wake of the terrorist attacks. (160 words)  TERROR-SPENDING (Undated) _ Most people were worried about layoffs and a volatile stock market, but the terrorists attacks are expected to further impact consumer spending. Overall consumer spending declined by about 40 percent in the five days following the Gulf War 10 years ago. (150 words)  BUSINESS-PEOPLE (Undated) _ Interviews with various business leaders.  AUTOS  ABOUTCARS-VW-LUPO (New York) _ The Volkswagen Lupo 3 Liter TDI gets 99 miles per gallon. There is no power steering and the windows must be cranked open, but the Lupo hit its fuel efficiency primarily by using a turbo direct-injection diesel fuel with a computer chip to regulate its use. Additional fuel economy is provided by the Start Stop function. After three seconds at a stop light, the engine switches off. The Lupo is not available in the United States yet, but a model was made available for a test drive. By Phil Patton.  With photo. His eyes tearing again, he said, ``It's a complicated world.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010914.0003 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-NATIONAL-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> NATIONAL NEWS IN BRIEF  c.2001 New York Times News Service  WEST  CALIFORNIA: STATE LIMITS LOAN RATES  California has become the second state, after North Carolina, to pass a law restricting what is known as predatory lending, the granting of loans with excessive fees and high interest rates to people with poor credit. The law will prohibit lenders from forcing borrowers, who are frequently members of minority groups and the elderly, to buy certain kinds of loan insurance. It will also limit the number of points lenders can charge to 6 percent of the loan amount, prohibit repeated refinancings and prohibit loans to people who do not have the means to repay them.  NORTHWEST  WASHINGTON: DRUNKEN DRIVER ARRESTS DROP  The number of reported drunken driving violations has decreased since the state lowered the threshold for blood alcohol content to 0.08 on Jan. 1, 1999, from 0.10, the state's Traffic Safety Commission said. A spokeswoman for the commission, Jonna VanDyk, attributed the drop in citations to successful public education programs for drivers and bartenders, like the 0.08 signs that began showing up on state roads in 1998. Since 1998 the number of citations issued annually has fallen by about 1,000, to 37,661 for 2000. There has also been a 10 percent drop in accidents involving drunken drivers and an 18 percent drop in fatalities from accidents involving these drivers since 1998.  MIDWEST  MINNESOTA: STRIKE THREAT POSTPONED  Two unions representing state employees have agreed to postpone a threatened strike, saying the time is not right, after the terrorist attacks. In a meeting on Wednesday with state authorities, officials of the Minnesota Association of Professional Employees and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees Council 6 agreed to extend a strike deadline by two weeks, to Oct. 1, in a dispute over wages and health benefits. The unions have nearly 30,000 members, representing about 60 percent of state government workers.  SOUTH  MISSISSIPPI: ADVOCATE DROPS FLAG EFFORT  The leader of a movement to amend the state Constitution to preserve the state's flag, which includes the Confederate battle emblem, says he will halt the drive. The leader, Greg Stewart of Tunica, said he would not submit the signatures, numbering more than 90,000, that he had gathered on a petition to put on the ballot a measure keeping the flag as it is, saying a referendum last April when two-thirds of voters said they did not want change is protection enough. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010914.0004 type=story > <HEADLINE> PRESIDENT'S MISSILE DEFENSE PLAN GAINS IN WAKE OF TERROR ATTACKS </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> WASHINGTON (BC-TERROR-MISSILE-1STLD-WRITETHRU-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, she says,	 Louis' seven years of impotence stirred gossip that Marie Antoinette was having affairs, including a lesbian one with the Comtesse Jules de Polignac. Fraser thinks that it actually would have helped the Queen's image if Louis, like his predecessors, had taken a lover. The French typically revered their queens and reviled royal mistresses. But, she says, ``Louis XVI found it difficult enough to make it with his wife, let alone a mistress.'' Marie Antoinette now became the queen the public loved to hate. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, she says,	 Fraser, daughter of the Earl of Longford, points out the irony that only a few years after the French Revolution, the upstart Napoleon briefly succeeded in setting himself and his heirs up as monarchs. And while Fraser generally refrains from drawing parallels between the past and the present, she can't help chuckling about the similarities between Napoleon and President Bush. Both, she says, are members of families who are trying to establish ruling dynasties. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he says,	 But would the ocean ecology survive? ``Really, the capacity is determined by how much adverse environmental impact you're willing to accept,'' says Ken Caldeira, who directs the ocean-sequestration project at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. Mixing carbon dioxide into the water makes it more acidic, which potentially could harm marine organisms. Brewer doubts the amount of carbon we're likely to add will cause much harm, as the pH of seawater already varies significantly by location. Besides, he says, nature eventually delivers 80 percent of atmospheric carbon into the sea anyway: ``We already have an ocean CO2 disposal program we put it in the air and the air puts it in the ocean.'' Still, the technological and ecological uncertainties mean ocean sequestration won't be in widespread use anytime soon. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

TERROR ATTACK (``a'' code)  The New York Times plans 21 pages of continuing coverage on the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.  For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.  PRINCIPAL STORIES  TERROR-BUSH (New York) _ President Bush's visit to New York and all of its implications for the president, the city and its mayor. By Robert D. McFadden.  (An early version of this story by Terence Neilan will move by 2 p.m. EDT.)  TERROR-PRAYER-DAY (Undated) _ A day of prayer and remembrance around the nation and around the world. By Dan Barry.  (An early version of this story by David Stout will move by 3 p.m. EDT.)  TERROR-BIG-CONSTRUCTION (New York) _ Construction of big buildings, including the major renovations at Lincoln Center, has been halted. By Ralph Blumenthal.  TERROR-NY-SCENE (New York) _ What's going on in New York City, from the Hudson River blockades still on, to more bomb scares, to growing worries about phony solicitations for assistance. By Richard Perez-Pena.  TERROR-NY-SITE (New York) _ The task of the cleanup and the search for body parts. Also take in the hoaxes by unauthorized people converging on the site. By Susan Sachs.  TERROR-CONGRESS (Washington) _ The Senate voted unanimously on Friday to approve a $40 billion emergency aid package and a congressional resolution giving President Bush support for military retaliation against the terrorists who masterminded this week's attacks in New York and Washington. By Philip Shenon and Lizette Alvarez.  (An early version of this story by Alison Mitchell and Philip Shenon has moved.)  TERROR-INQUIRY (Washington) _ Developing: On Friday afternoon the FBI expects to release the names and mugshots of 19 suspects in Tuesday's terror attacks. By David Johnston and others.  With  TERROR-SUSPECTS-IMMIG (Washington) _ How each of the 19 suspects entered the United States and what the Immigration and Naturalization Service says about the immigration status of each of them. By Robert Pear.  And  TERROR-SUSPECTS (Dateline to come) _ On the 19 suspected terrorists. (Byline to come)  And  TERROR-SUSPECTS-SAUDI (Dateline to come) _ Several of the suspected terrorists carried Saudi passports, and one of the suspected hijackers had a Saudi scholarship to a flight school. Investigating any Saudi connections to the attack. By Steven Lee Myers.  And  TERROR-SUSPECTS-ATTA (Undated) _ A profile of Muhammed Atta, one of the suspected terrorists. By Douglas Frantz and Steven Erlanger.  TERROR-RUSSIA-U.S. (Washington) _ The Russians and Americans appear to be coming together in the war against terrorism, a war that both say emanates from Afghanistan _ a country whose ruin, and path into Islamic extremism, was precipitated by the Cold War confrontation there in the 1980s. But the Russian military is balking _ at least publicly _ over opening Russian bases in Central Asia to America. By Jane Perlez.  TERROR-RETALIATE (Washington) _ On the diplomacy being pursued by countries that fear they might be attacked if the Bush administration pursues its vow to punish any government harboring terrorists. By Elaine Sciolino.  TERROR-MILITARY (Washington) _ Military commanders are drafting plans for the new kind of war declared by the Bush Administration. By Thom Shanker and others.  TALIBAN-BIN-LADEN (Jalalabad, Afghanistan) _ A profile of the Taliban and their relationship with Osama bin Laden. By Barry Bearak.  OTHER TERROR STORIES  TERROR-NY-ASBESTOS (New York) _ Looking at asbestos-related issues in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack. By James Glanz.  TERROR-PENTAGON (Washington) _ The scene at the Pentagon. By Elizabeth Becker.  TERROR-CIVIL-LIBERTIES (Washington) _ Civil libertarians worry that the attack will shift public sentiment toward restricting individual freedoms. By Robin Toner.  TERROR-POLITICS (Washington) _ The last time a President Bush, Powell and Cheney faced a formidable foreign enemy they slowly and deliberately formed a military and diplomatic coalition to do battle with Iraq. Now a different Bush, aided by Powell and Cheney, are again assembling a coalition and weighing military options, but they face an impatient public and something approaching war fever in Congress. How will the current team balance the pressures to act quickly with their instincts and experience, which tell them that a major military operation requires meticulous planning and overwhelming power? By Todd S. Purdum.  OVERSEAS-STUDENTS (Undated) _ Despite the indignation over the hijackers' training at U.S. flights schools, U.S. universities say they must provide education of all kinds to international students _ even if that means teaching subjects like nuclear engineering to Pakistani and Chinese students. By Diana Jean Schemo.  TERROR-TRANSPORT (Denver) _ On the resumption of travel after the attacks. By Michael Janofsky.  SUICIDE-BOMBERS (Undated) _ A portrait of the new type of suicide bomber, raised in comfort, not desperation. By Jodi Wilgoren.  TERROR-MEDIA (Undated) _ A bad night Thursday for ABC News. It makes serious reporting errors Thursday night _ about a plot to bomb Los Angeles and the discovery of 10 police officers alive in the World Trade Center. A look at other problems with TV news coverage. By Bill Carter.  GERMANY-MUSLIMS (Hamburg, Germany) _ The hangouts of Mohammad Atta, and the large Arab/Turkish community in Hamburg. By Steven Erlanger.  STRANDED-EUROPE (Paris) _ Americans are stranded in Paris, indeed all over Europe and the world. By Donald G. McNeil Jr.  STRANDED-CANADA (Toronto) _ Thousands of people are still stranded in Canada, particularly in tiny Gander. (Byline to come)  EU-AIR-TRANSPORT (Brussels, Belgium) _ European Union transportation ministers met on Friday to discuss increasing air safety and other measures. By Suzanne Daley.  TERROR-FORIEGN-VICTIMS () _ The toll of foreigners: Britons, Japanese, Germans, Koreans, Chinese, Canadians and many others have perished or are among the missing. Length TK.  TERROR-WORLD-RESPONSE () _ How the world is responding _ concrete actions. about 1.5 cols  WORLD-MARKETS (London) _ European markets tumble again in midday trading amid continued uncertainty about the impact of Tuesday's attacks and the reopening of the American stock market. By Alan Cowell.  TERROR-NY-KOMANSKY (New York) _ The week as experienced by David Komansky, chief executive of Merrill Lynch, Wall Street's largest firm. By Patrick McGeehan.  CARGO-IMPACT (Hong Kong) _ The suspension of cargo on passenger flights will halt shipments of electronic and computing parts and of medicine and other goods. The impact on the East Asian economy will be particularly severe, although there will be impact in America as well. By Mark Landler.  FEDEX-REOPEN (Memphis, Tenn.) _ Federal Express is beginning to return to business for the first time since Tuesday. By Emily Yellin.  TERROR-NY-GOLD (New York) _ The New York Mercantile Exchange says that $234 million of gold and silver was stored in a vault at the World Trade Center. By Jonathan Fuerbringer.  FINANCIAL-SERVICES (New York) _ How financial services firms are putting ``mirror'' sites into action. The view from an American Express site. By Saul Hansell.  DEAD-MEDIA-CONTACTS (New York) _ Financial journalists covering the outcome of the attacks are finding that many of their contacts are dead or missing. By David D. Kirkpatrick.  TERROR-ONLINE-FBI (Undated) _ Several Internet service providers are cooperating with the FBI to provide the ability to wiretap, while moves are beginning for more general monitoring of online transmissions. By John Schwartz.  TERROR-LIABILITY (Undated) _ On insurance liability issues. On Friday, GMAC Commercial Mortgage, a financing unit of General Motors, says insurance covers the $563 million mortgage loan it made for the purchase of the World Trade Center. By Joseph B. Treaster.  TERROR-NYC-COLUMN (New York) _ Clyde Haberman's column on the president's visit.  OTHER INTERNATINAL (``i'' code)  MIDEAST (Umm al Fahm, Israel) _ At the annual rally at Al-Aksa mosque by Arab-Israelis. Other developments, including the prospect of a Sunday meeting between Sharon and Arafat. By James Bennet.  AFGHAN-MASSOUD (Islamabad, Pakistan) _ Ahmed Shah Massoud, the Afghan opposition leader leader, is reportedly dead after an assassination attempt. By John F. Burns.  WORLD-BRIEFS (Undated) _ World news in brief.  OTHER NATIONAL GENERAL (``a'' code)  RELIGION-COLUMN (Undated) _ The weekly religion column. By Gustav Niebuhr.  OTHER FINANCIAL (``f'' code)  CHINA-WTO (Washington) _ Amid the chaos of the past few days, U.S. and Chinese negotiators have agreed on issues that will allow China's entry into the WTO. By Joseph Kahn.  CZECH-LAUDER (Prague, Czech Republic) _ Ron Lauder wins a huge $500 million judgement in the dispute over his TV station here, and this one, it appears, the Czech government will have to enforce. By Peter S. Green.  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Short items on business news from around the world.  COMMENTARY (``k'' code)  Frank Rich's ``Journal'' and Anthony Lewis' ``Abroad at Home.'' Bechetta Jackson, Brett Hoffman, Mitch Mitchell, Darren Barbee, others.  ATTACK-RALLY  DALLAS _ Covering a tolerance rally at Thanks Giving Square by North Dallas High School, the first school to be designated an international high school. Rally is in response to attacks against Muslims and those of Arab descent. Eva-Marie Ayala.  ATTACK-ISLAM  Monitoring for any further attacks on mosques in North Texas. Other hate incidents. Developing. Byline TK  ATTACK-MOSQUES  Covering today's prayer services at local mosques. Details TK  ATTACK-AIRPORT  Going to D/FW Airport for checks and color. Also check with Love Field. Work in national information about airports. National Airport may remain closed because of approaches over government buildings. New York airports reopening? Info from airlines on how many flights flown today. Mike Lee, Maria Recio, Dan Reed.  ATTACK-AIR  The terrorists apparently all boarded planes originally at small airports, so they did not have to go back out and through the security screening at the larger airports where they made connecting flights. We look at the security measures at small airports to see whether the new security rules will make certain that this isn't a loophole in the security system. Jeff Classen, Mike Lee.  ATTACK-AIR-SECURITY  Look at how the screening devices at airports work and about the new types of security systems now available to detect weapons. What kinds of weapons can be detected? Which ones can't be? Gordon Dickson, Jeff Classen.  ATTACK-EMPLOYEES  Veteran airline employees, including many pilots, say they want further security improvements, because the new steps don't allay their fears about attacks. Talking to airline employees about their fears and about what they want to see done. Byron Okada.  ATTACK-RESERVES  Story about the call-up of reserves. Going to Fort Hood and talking with reserve units in the Metroplex. Checking Naval bases along Texas coast. John Moritz, R.A. Dyer.  ATTACK-DALLAS  Chase reports that there was a planned fifth hijacking attempt from Dallas/Fort Worth airport. Following on the two men arrested at Amtrak station in FW. DEVELOPING. Gabrielle Crist, Ginger D. Richardson, Chris Vaughn  ATTACK-TEXAS  State government pauses to remember America's victims. Checking for more price gouging reports and the status of Texas Task Force 1 that is poised to deploy the state's search and rescue specialists. Byline TK  ATTACK-COLLAPSE  A look at why and how WTC towers collapsed. Structural engineers say collapse was inevitable because of fire. Some also say that the firefighters and police should have been pulled out earlier, because the timing of the collapse could have been predicted by a technical expert on the scene. May not make today. Rebeca Rodriguez  ATTACK-CHILDREN  Children's views and thinking about the attacks. Letters they have written, and other writing from them to show how this has affected young people. Byline TK  ATTACK-IMMIGRANTS  How are our littlest immigrants dealing with the pain and tragedy that comes with the terroristic acts against the World Trade Center and Pentagon? We talk to young immigrants from countries like Mexico and as far away as Congo. Many don't speak English. They have been talking about what it means to be an immigrant now in a country of immigrants, about patriotism and how to treat immigrants from the Middle East with respect.  ATTACK-SPEND  Will consumers stop spending as the nation remains focused on the terrorist attack? We talk with shoppers, restaurants, movie theaters, retailers, car dealers, etc. to find out. Some shoppers say they're not going to stop spending money. But experts expect consumer spending to slow. Movie theaters have been sparse this week and some restaurants have already felt the effects.  ATTACK-SOUTHWEST  Southwest Airlines resumes service today. Checking to see how operations are proceeding. Southwest, which has profited by its ability to quickly turn its planes around, faces a particular challenge with the new security procedures.  ATTACK-PAY  A number of employees aren't getting paid because their checks were to be flown in. One is Michael Benesik at Simplified Employment. One thousand people need paychecks, and they are being driven in from Detroit. , it seems,	 TERROR-US-ANALYSIS _ WASHINGTON _ As a youth, Chuck Butler came to Washington for the funeral of President Kennedy, and he returned five years later to protest the war in Vietnam. On Tuesday, he stood at the edge of the Potomac River and looked with sadness and anger upon the dark plume of smoke rising up from the smoldering rubble of the Pentagon. ``This city means freedom to me,'' he said. ``Now, I'm really worried for our country.'' The mightiest superpower in history, it seems, has suddenly been laid naked by terrorists willing to use commerical aircraft as weapons in a war that targets civilians. What sort of sacrifice can Americans expect to make in the weeks and months ahead, as the country and its institutions gird for this grim new war? And how much, after all, can the country change and still stay true to its core calling as a beacon of freedom for the rest of the world? (Deans, Cox News Service). MOVED. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 TERROR-SKYSCRAPERS _ ATLANTA _When Housh Rahimzadeh saw the second plane dive into the World Trade Center, he knew exactly what would happen next. But John Portman's chief engineer was in Atlanta, watching television, and could do nothing but watch the laws of physics do their fatal and inevitable work. The men and women who build and design skyscrapers and skylines say this most American style of architecture _ full of majesty and ego _ will survive the the NYC disaster. But it will be changed, and possibly be shorn of its braggadacio. This may be more of a pastiche of observations from Atlanta and NYC architects, including John Portman: one in Manhattan says speculation has already begun about what will take the WTC's place. Rahimzadeh explains why the WTC was the collision of a aberrant act of terrorism on the one building that would react as it did. Atlanta's skyscrapers are built differently, and would react differently. Hopefully, he said, they would survive longer. And one Atlanta architect says the bombing may have put the lid on ego trips that the trips that the Donald Trumps of the world are inclined toward. (G alloway, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

For information on stories, or for reruns, please call: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For information on NYT photos and graphics, please call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  Business Day Front Page of The New York Times, Saturday, Sept. 15.  (Top lede)  TERROR-SEC-PRECAUTIONS (Washington) _ Hoping to avoid a wave of panicked selling when the stock exchanges open next week, the government issued an order Friday waiving certain regulations to permit companies and executives to help prop up the prices of their shares. By Stephen Labaton.  (Story has moved.)  (Center display)  FEDEX-REOPEN (Memphis, Tenn.) _ FedEx Corp., which ships about 3.3 million packages every business day, has contingency plans to deal with slowdowns and delays all over the world, plans for coping with severe weather or various natural disasters. But resuming full-scale domestic operations from a complete grounding of its air fleet was new terrain. By Emily Yellin.  With photos.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  (Bottom right)  TERROR-LIABILITY (New York) _ The terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center will cause the cost of commercial coverage to rise by at least 20 percent as insurers struggle to recoup losses in the worst insurance disaster in history, insurers and analysts said Friday. Even then, they said, some insurance companies are certain to fail under the burden of claims that may run as high as $30 billion to $40 billion. By Joseph B. Treaster.  (Story has moved.)  (Bottom center)  FINANCIAL-SERVICES (New York) _ Madhaven Ramaswamy, a manager for international money transfer at the American Express Bank who worked at 7 World Trade Center, was a little late for a meeting there when he saw flames atop the twin towers. Jumping into a cab with three colleagues, he told the driver to head to the bank's backup center, never before used, just over the Hudson River in New Jersey. By late in the day, Ramaswamy and his colleagues were able to process about 19,000 transfers for a total of $14.3 billion, roughly 70 percent of the transactions its customers had entered. By Saul Hansell.  With photo.  (Story has moved.)  (Bottom left)  TERROR-NY-GOLD (New York) _ Buried under 4 World Trade Center, near Ground Zero of the terrorist attack, is 11.8 metric tons of gold. At current prices, the gold is worth $110.3 million. It belongs to people or firms trading futures contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange, although they rarely take actual possession of the metal. By Jonathan Fuerbringer.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  Here are tonight's columns and regular features:  WORLD-MARKETS (London) _ Europe's leading stock markets dropped sharply Friday amid uncertainty about the reopening of U.S. markets on Monday and the effect of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. By Alan Cowell.  (Eds: This story subs for the usual New York-datelined MARKET story.)  (Story has moved.)  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ World business news in brief.  (The briefs have moved.) , he says,	 Helen Cross Kittle was the one to ask her future husband out on their first date. Kittle, 34, a computer specialist who worked on the 103rd floor of 1 World Trade Center, was five months pregnant at the time of the attack. , he said,	 What Dan Hunt remembers best about his older brother William is that during Dan's senior year in high school, William, then a college senior, went to every basketball game he played. When Dan's team lost its final game, and Dan fell two free throws short of a milestone of 2,000 points, his brother was right there to protect him. ``Some newspeople wanted to come down and ask me how I felt, not to have made that,'' Dan Hunt remembered. His brother, he said, kept them away, approaching one of them and saying, ``Buddy, I really don't think it's a good idea right now, and if you wouldn't mind, I'd appreciate it if you wouldn't do this.'' Dan Hunt said of William, who worked at Euro Brokers in 2 World Trade Center and was 32, ``He's very protective of everyone that he loves.'' On Tuesday, he stood at the edge of the Potomac River and looked with sadness and anger upon the dark plume of smoke rising up from the smoldering rubble of the Pentagon. ``This city means freedom to me,'' he said. ``Now, I'm really worried for our country.'' , he said,	 For example, Malburg said, if the very best interest rate the lender can offer a borrower who is willing to pay his or her own refinancing costs is, say, 6.75 percent, the lender may charge that same borrower an interest rate of 7 percent for a no-cost refinance. So, he said, to determine whether it is wise to take out a no-cost refinance, the borrower must first determine whether a refinance makes sense in the first place, and then determine whether it makes more sense to pay one's own closing costs _ and thereby obtain a lower interest rate. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 As a result, he said, no-closing-cost refinances make more sense for borrowers who plan on selling their home _ or refinancing again _ within a relatively short period of time and are typically less appropriate for those who plan on keeping their house, and their mortgage, for the long haul. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he said,	 In fact, he said, anyone who is contemplating refinancing should check with both the current mortgage lender and the new lender to determine whether a prepayment penalty will be imposed if the mortgage is paid off early. If Wladimir Klitschko ends up in the ring Dec. 1 with Ray Mercer, no one will be more surprised than I, except perhaps Klitschko and Mercer. The WBO champion is far more likely to end up fighting Fres Oquendo, a far less dangeorus foe coming off back-to-back knockouts of Clifford Etienne and Obed Sullivan. Oquendo is unlikely to offer Klitschko much more than a good record to beat up on, while Mercer is a dangerous opponent despite his age. Fight cards around the country were postponed, including one pitting Arab-American super middleweight Omar Sheika vs. Thomas Tate scheduled for Friday night on ESPN2. Both are promoted by the Duvas, and the fight was to have been a big one for their fledgling company, which was staging the event it at JFK High School in Paterson, N.J. Earlier this year, a match was proposed between Sheika and Jewish super middleweight Dana Rosenblatt, but Rosenblatt declined, in part, he said, because of the likely political nature of the promotion. Sheika rebuked Rosenblatt publicly for making such a suggestion and said the fight was about sport, not politics. As we sadly learned last week, nothing, it seems, is without politics anymore . . . Only about 1,000 tickets were left for the Hopkins-Trinidad fight, according to reports. The Garden holds 18,500 and would have been jammed. It still will be when the night finally comes . . . Oscar De La Hoya is set to defend his World Boxing Council junior middleweight title vs. mandatory challenger Roman Karmazian Dec. 8 in his backyard, the Olympic Auditorium in Los Angeles. The De La Hoya's critics who say he is not popular may find their argument destroyed by a packed house at the Olympic, which was once the West Coast center of big-time boxing . . . If he gets into the ring with Jones, he will lose just as easily. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he said,	 ``In the spring,'' he said, ``the sap is rising, and you have from that time until the first part of July to do it.'' Any logs that require peeling later are much harder to strip. When the timing is right, he said, ``it comes off in one piece, like a banana.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, he will,	 Speaking of grievances, Terry Glenn won the right to return to the Patriots after serving his four-game league-imposed suspension, but arbitrator Richard Bloch was careful to rule on the thinnest of legal points, not answering the question of whether or not the ``five-day rule'' _ which is in the league bylaws but wasn't properly covered in the last collective bargaining extension _ remains valid. That was a break for ownership. All Bloch said was that the Patriots should have given Glenn a second notice to return and allowed him that opportunity when he said he was coming in for a meeting. However, the issue of the millions the Patriots have taken back from Glenn in bonus money remains undecided and will require further arbitration or a lawsuit. But what is Glenn to do in the meantime? He said repeatedly that he just wants to come back and play. Does he want to play for the $500,000 left in his contract? If football means what he says it means to him, he will, and worry about the other issues when they come up in legal proceedings. If he balks again, however, he could entrap himself . . . Patriots coach Bill Belichick was circumspect in his comments on Glenn after being fined by the league for previous remarks during trainng camp. ``Terry is suspended by the league and certain rules and restrictions apply,'' Belichick said when asked if he would reach out to Glenn. ``At all cost I want to abide by those restrictions.'' Then he laughed . . . However, it was telling that quarterback Drew Bledsoe seemed less sympathetic toward Glenn than he has so many times in the past when trouble brewed. Asked if Glenn would help the team when he returns, Bledsoe said, ``That depends on his attitude and his demeanor. If he decides to make a difference, he can.'' That's the closest Bledsoe has ever come to saying he's growing weary of waiting for Glenn . . . One guy who won't care whether he gets paid for Sunday's missed game or not is Tampa Bay receiver Keyshawn Johnson, who already has said he intends to donate a game check to the relief fund for the families. It's a sign of the times that he didn't even know how much he makes each week. It's $31,150 . . . San Diego Chargers rookie running back LaDainian Tomlinson became only the 20th player since 1970 to rush for 100 yards in his debut game, gaining 113 on 36 carries last weekend. Last to do it was the Colts' Edgerrin James, who had 112 against Buffalo in 1999 . . . Here's the Doug Flutie-vs.-Rob Johnson race after one week. Flutie's team wins, 30-3, to improve his record as an NFL starter to 31-10. Johnson's Bills lose, 24-6, dropping his record as an NFL starter to 6-9. Flutie threw two interceptions, was sacked once, and averaged 6.4 yards per completion. Johnson threw three picks, was sacked five times, and averaged 3.8 yards per completion. Keeping Johnson in Buffalo is looking better and better every day _ for the rest of the AFC East. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he said,	 ``The money wouldn't go to his family _ they've boycotted him,'' Alexander said. Even so, he said, large sums are not needed to pull off devastating attacks like a suicide bombing in a movement where much of its potency flows from the fervor of its followers. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, it seems,	 The prolific Oates sets her 29th novel (37th, if you count what she has written as Rosamond Smith) in Salthill-on-Hudson, a historic New York town populated by middle-aged rich people who are dreadfully unhappy. Marriages have grown stale, children have grown resentful and mean, and some of the men are reinventing themselves through the attentions of younger women. Their lives are stirred up when Adam Berendt, an enigmatic and seemingly impoverished sculptor who has lived in Salthill for 21 years, drowns during an outing on the Hudson River. Adam, it seems, had become important to many of the Salthill women, and his sudden death in the first chapter gives them lots to ponder for the rest of the book. Oates' characters are hilarious one minute, shallow and cruel the next, showing little finesse as they navigate the emotional transitions of midlife. This book is overlong but still poignant and funny as the people of Salthill make changes in their lives, inspired by a man whose past is a mystery to them all. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, it seems,	 The prolific Oates sets her 29th novel (37th, if you count what she has written as Rosamond Smith) in Salthill-on-Hudson, a historic New York town populated by middle-aged rich people who are dreadfully unhappy. Marriages have grown stale, children have grown resentful and mean, and some of the men are reinventing themselves through the attentions of younger women. Their lives are stirred up when Adam Berendt, an enigmatic and seemingly impoverished sculptor who has lived in Salthill for 21 years, drowns during an outing on the Hudson River. Adam, it seems, had become important to many of the Salthill women, and his sudden death in the first chapter gives them lots to ponder for the rest of the book. Oates' characters are hilarious one minute, shallow and cruel the next, showing little finesse as they navigate the emotional transitions of midlife. This book is overlong but still poignant and funny as the people of Salthill make changes in their lives, inspired by a man whose past is a mystery to them all. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, she says,	 Some market-watchers have more mundane concerns. Maureen Allyn, chief economist at Zurich-Scudder Investments in New York, notes that based on most traditional measures of value, stocks remain fairly expensive by historical standards. Allyn argues that investors and corporate executives have been too optimistic about corporate America's ability to boost profits over the next year. In effect, even though stock prices have fallen dramatically, they may not have fallen enough, says Allyn. As such, she says, the support provided by lower rates and increased government spending may not be sufficient to sustain a decent rally. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

(NYT105) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ART-LOSS-2 -- The disappearance of Michael Richards, a young sculptor working at the World Trade Center was the most wrenching reminder of the significant role that art plays in an area known as a center of finance, and of the countless ways a community is altered by calamity. ``World Trade Center Tapestry'' (1974), a tapestry by artist Joan Miro that was on display in the mezzanine of 2 World Trade Center. (''Art for the Public''/The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey/The New York Times)ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY ENTITLED ``TERROR-ART-LOSS'' by Peter Marks and Carol Vogel. MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT104) DUPUYER, Mont. -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- COW-KILLINGS -- Eight cow killings have been reported in Montana since June 12, the most recent on Aug. 31. And they all appear similar to the ones that occurred in the 1970s. Mark Taliaferro, right, at his ranch in Dupuyer, Mont., with his wife, left, and daughter. One of his cows recently died what he insists was ``not a natural death.'' (Jim Robbins/The New York Times)  (NYT103) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ART-LOSS -- ``Double Check,'' a sculpture of a businessman by J. Seward Johnson Jr. in Liberty Plaza Park near the World Trade Center is now a makeshift memorial. (Alan Chin/The New York Times)  (NYT102) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-MUSEUMS -- On Wednesday, when most were indoors, some people ventured out to museums to find comfort, replenishment and beauty. The Islamic Gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where stranded travelers went to look and reflect. (Carol Halebian/The New York Times)  (NYT101) BUENOS AIRES, Argentina -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- ARGENTINA-WEALTHY-2 -- Only a few years ago, no respectable upper middle class Argentine would have dared show up in public carrying a shopping bag marked ``Coto.'' Now, Coto - traditionally the supermarket chain of the lower classes - has suddenly become a store for everybody. A shopper recently in Coto. (Horacio Paone/The New York Times)  (NYT100) BUENOS AIRES -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- ARGENTINA -- Only a few years ago, no respectable upper middle class Argentine would have dared show up in public carrying a shopping bag marked ``Coto.'' Now, Coto - traditionally the supermarket chain of the lower classes - has suddenly become a store for everybody. Shoppers recently in Coto. (Alan Chin/The New York Times)  (NYT102) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-MUSEUMS -- On Wednesday, when most were indoors, some people ventured out to museums to find comfort, replenishment and beauty. The Islamic Gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where stranded travelers went to look and reflect. (Carol Halebian/The New York Times)  (NYT101) BUENOS AIRES, Argentina -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- ARGENTINA-WEALTHY-2 -- Only a few years ago, no respectable upper middle class Argentine would have dared show up in public carrying a shopping bag marked ``Coto.'' Now, Coto - traditionally the supermarket chain of the lower classes - has suddenly become a store for everybody. A shopper recently in Coto. (Horacio Paone/The New York Times)  (NYT100) BUENOS AIRES -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- ARGENTINA -- Only a few years ago, no respectable upper middle class Argentine would have dared show up in public carrying a shopping bag marked ``Coto.'' (NYT105) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ART-LOSS-2 -- The disappearance of Michael Richards, a young sculptor working at the World Trade Center was the most wrenching reminder of the significant role that art plays in an area known as a center of finance, and of the countless ways a community is altered by calamity. ``World Trade Center Tapestry'' (1974), a tapestry by artist Joan Miro that was on display in the mezzanine of 2 World Trade Center. (''Art for the Public''/The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey/The New York Times)ONLY FOR USE WITH STORY ENTITLED ``TERROR-ART-LOSS'' by Peter Marks and Carol Vogel. MAGS OUT -- NO SALES  (NYT104) DUPUYER, Mont. -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- COW-KILLINGS -- Eight cow killings have been reported in Montana since June 12, the most recent on Aug. 31. And they all appear similar to the ones that occurred in the 1970s. Mark Taliaferro, right, at his ranch in Dupuyer, Mont., with his wife, left, and daughter. One of his cows recently died what he insists was ``not a natural death.'' (Jim Robbins/The New York Times)  (NYT103) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ART-LOSS -- ``Double Check,'' a sculpture of a businessman by J. (NYT42) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-29 -- On Sunday, residents of Battery Park City in lower Manhattan leave the area after retrieving belongings. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT41) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-28 -- In lower Manhattan, vocal and heartfelt public support for the city's overworked corps of rank-and-file police officers has lifted morale during the crisis. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT40) UNDATED -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-27 -- The search for people who worked at the trade center's margins has been modestly successful. From top to bottom: Sal Gjonbalaj, left, and his brother Selim hold a picture of their missing father, Mon, who was a window washer at the World Trade Center. Roko Camaj is searching for his father, Vincent, who worked on the World Trade Center's roof, maneuvering window washers' scaffolds. Sonia Ortiz's children, Alexa, left, and Victor, said she loved working at the trade center, where she ran the Windows on the World freight elevator. (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)  (NYT39) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-26 -- In a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral that mixed poignancy and moments of newly stirred patriotism, Cardinal Edward M. Egan, left, on Sunday deplored the ``faceless criminals'' who attacked the World Trade Center on Tuesday. Hundreds of people lined Fifth Avenue Sunday morning to hear Egan speak. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT38) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-25 -- In a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral that mixed poignancy and moments of newly stirred patriotism, Cardinal Edward M. Egan, left, on Sunday deplored the ``faceless criminals'' who attacked the World Trade Center on Tuesday. In attendance were Mayor Giuliani, far left, police commisioner Bernard Kerik, center, and fire commissioner Thomas Von Essen, far right. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)  (NYT37) ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-24 -- Pakistani demonstrators gathered in Islamabad, Pakistan Sunday to denounce their government's cooperation with American anti-terrorism efforts. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)  (NYT36) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-23 -- Trinity Church, which was blocks away from the World Trade Center, remained after the collapse of the towers and other nearby buildings. Over 150 parishioners gathered here on Sunday for Mass. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)  (NYT35) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-22 -- On Saturday, a policeman takes a break inside St. Charlie's, a bar and restaurant which was damaged by the collapse of the World Trade Center on Tuesday. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT34) UNDATED -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-NY-MISSING -- From left to right: Shreyas Ranganath, John F. Iskyan, Katie Marie McCloskey and L. Russell Keene III are among the missing. (The New York Times)  (NYT33) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-21 -- In order to fill the ranks that were devastated following Tuesday's attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Giuliani of New York swore in new fire department officials, Sunday. Giuliani likened their losses to those of sailors at Pearl Harbor and recalled how the Navy regrouped and prevailed. (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)  (NYT32) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-20 -- On Sunday, supporters of the victims of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center hold a candlelight vigil at the Brooklyn Heights Promenade for Arab-Americans, Jews and Christians. The gathering was sponsored by Arab-American Family Support Center, Sakhi for South Asian Women and Women for Afghan Women. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)  (NYT31) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- GRASSO-PROFILE -- Asked if he had sought any psychological help since his world collapsed on Tuesday, Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, seemed startled. ``No, I don't need it,'' he replied sharply. He added, ``My counseling is this -- that Monday morning 9:30 bell.'' Grasso plans to open the NYSE on Monday. Grasso on the NYSE trading floor on Sunday. (Krista Niles/The New York Times)  (NYT30) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ECON -- Faced with a major test of the U.S. economy's ability to withstand the blow from the terrorist attack, an informal coalition of government and business leaders urged investors in public and private on Sunday to do what they could to keep the stock markets from tumbling when they reopen Monday morning. On Sunday in Times Square, the Nasdaq Market Site ticker announces it's reopening on Monday. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)  (NYT29) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-INVEST-2 -- As the stock market prepared to reopen on Monday, after a terrorist strike to the heart of Wall Street last Tuesday, investors faced an unavoidable question: What should I do now? Many professional investors and money managers are retreating to the most basic kind of guidance -- hold tight. NYSE Chairman Richard Grasso, in yellow sweater, speaks with employees on Saturday as they prepare a dry run. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT28) UNDATED -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ONLINE-MEDIA -- Whether it is Web sites supporting terrorism, or anti-Islamic messages posted on Internet bulletin boards, some material has forced the Internet access providers to step up their screening efforts and rethink their standards of what sort of material is acceptable. On one Web site, under the heading ``The Road to Jihad,'' right, an urban skyline was shown in flames with burning flags of the United States and Israel. (The New York Times)  (NYT27) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-INVEST -- As the stock market prepared to reopen on Monday, after a terrorist strike to the heart of Wall Street last Tuesday, investors faced an unavoidable question: What should I do now? Many professional investors and money managers are retreating to the most basic kind of guidance -- hold tight. On Saturday, the NYSE does a dry run while employees wait for rehearsal at their stations. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT26) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-INFO-MEDIA -- Television's efforts to keep its audience connected also left it vulnerable to conveying undeveloped, sometimes erroneous reports. On Thursday, a Port Authority police officer helped evacuate La Guardia Airport in New York after a bomb threat. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)  (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-19 -- In order to fill the ranks that were devastated following Tuesday's attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Giuliani of New York swore in new fire department officials, Sunday. Giuliani during the ceremony Sunday in Brooklyn. Hundreds of firefighters are missing following Tuesday's terrorist attack. The chief of the department as well as the department's chaplain were killed in the attack. (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)  (NYT24) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-18 -- A rescuer acknowledges applause from New Yorkers lining a route used to access the World Trade Center area, Sunday. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT23) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- NYC-OPERA-REVIEW -- Responding to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's request for a return to normalcy, the New York City Opera opened a delayed season Saturday with two premiere productions which brought complex and conflicting feelings among audience and cast members. The cast and crew of the ``Flying Dutchman,'' sang the National Anthem before the opening performance at the New York State Theater. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)  (NYT22) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-17 -- An elevated view of rescue efforts looking north towards uptown, Sunday, on the site where the World Trade Center once stood. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT21) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-16 -- A makeshift memorial outside the home of Engine 54, Ladder 4 Battalion 9 in midtown Manhattan, Sunday. Fifteen firefighters with the station disappeared after the World Trade Center collapsed following a terrorist attack, Tuesday. (Steve Berman/The New York Times)  (NYT20) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-15 -- People gather in Jersey City, just across the Hudson River from downtown Manhattan to see the skyline, Sunday. Smoke billows from where the World Trade Center once stood. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)  (NYT19) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-14 -- President Bush speaks to reporters upon his return to the White House on Sunday from Camp David where he met with national security team. Bush urged Americans to return to work on Monday and put the U.S. economy back on track even as they remain alert to the possibility of more terrorist acts. The helicopter used to transport Bush was a Black Hawk version of Marine One. Looking on at left is first lady Laura Bush. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT18) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-MAYOR-WEDDING -- Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York, left, during the wedding of Diane Gorumba and Michael Ferrito, right, in Brooklyn, Sunday. Giuliani walked Gorumba down the aisle in place of her brother, a firefighter, who disappeared in the collapse of the World Trade Center. (Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)  (NYT17) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-13 -- Rescuers and cranes at the scene Sunday where the World Trade Center once stood. Rescuers continue to try and find survivors following last Tuesday's terrorist attack which destroyed the twin towers. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT16) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-12 -- Construction workers try to tie a cable from a crane to a large piece of debris, Sunday where the World Trade Center once stood. Rescuers continue to try and find survivors following last Tuesday's terrorist attack which destroyed the twin towers. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT15) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-LIBERTY-REVIEW -- The balance between security and liberty, throughout American history a reliable barometer of the public's mood and collective self-confidence, will now be recalibrated to reflect both new realities and new perceptions. A naitonal guardsman atop a HUMVEE on the corner of Walker and Broadway in downtown Manhattan, Wednesday. Students at the University of Florida watch the news of the attack on the World Trade Center on television, Tuesday. (Michael C. (The New York Times)  (NYT4) ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-4 -- Protesters during a rally Sunday against their government's cooperation with the United States in tracking down Osama Bin Laden, suspected of organizing Tuesday's terrorist attack in the U.S. A delegation of senior Pakistani officials will go to neighboring Afghanistan on Monday to demand that the ruling Taliban militia hand over bin Laden to the United States, a top Pakistani official said in Islamabad. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)  (NYT3) ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-3 -- A young Pakistani joins protesters Sunday during a rally against their government's cooperation with the United States in tracking down Osama Bin Laden, suspected of organizing Tuesday's terrorist attack in the U.S. A delegation of senior Pakistani officials will go to neighboring Afghanistan on Monday to demand that the ruling Taliban militia hand over bin Laden to the United States, a top Pakistani official said in Islamabad. (David L. Ryan/The Bosotn Globe)  (NYT1) BOSTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-1 -- A Massachusetts special operations trooper stands watch with an assault rifle in terminal C at Logan International airport, Saturday. Boston's Logan Airport, where hijackers boarded the planes that destroyed the World Trade Center last Tuesday, reopened to tightened security. (John Bohn/The Boston Globe)  The New York Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010917.0022 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-AZR-BUDGET-ADD-AZR) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Wire budget for Monday, Sept. 17.BC-AZR-BUDGET -ADD-AZR  c.2001 Arizona Republic  The Arizona Republic plans add the following stories for use Monday, Sept. 17, 2001. For questions on News, Business or Commentary, call The Republic News Desk, (602) 444-8286; Sports, (602) 444-8107; Features (602) 444-4273; Photo, (602) 444-8282, Graphics, (602) 444-4934.  NATIONAL - GENERAL (Moving in ``a'' category)  ATTACKS-HATE (Phoenix) -- Hundreds of people across the Phoenix area Sunday mourned the slaying in Mesa of a Sikh gas station owner whose only crime, his loved ones say, was that he looked Arabic and wore a turban. Balbir Singh Sodhi's death may be the first homicide in the country related to the backlash against Arab Americans after Tuesday's terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center in New York and the Pentagon in Washington, D.C. And if classified as a hate crime, it could be the first homicide in Arizona history prosecuted as such, officials said. Within a 30-minute time span Saturday afternoon, police believe Frank Roque, a 42-year-old Mesa resident, fired shots in three separate incidents. First, they say, he drove a black Chevy S-10 pickup to a Chevron gas station and opened fire, killing Sodhi, 49, the owner. Roque then headed to a Mobile gas station, where police say he fired at a Lebanese-American clerk, but missed. Ten minutes later, Roque arrived at a home he used to own and fired multiple rounds, police said. A family of Afghani descent now lives there, and nobody was injured.  By KELLY ETTENBOROUGH, ADAM KLAWONN and CHRISTINA LEONARD. Story will move in the ``A'' category.  BUSINESS - (Moving in ``f'' category)  SPORTS (Moving in ``s'' category)  ENTERTAINMENT (Moving in ``e'' category)  NEW&AMP;NOTABLE (undated) -- Anne Stephenson reviews four new books. By ANNE STEPHENSON, Special for The Arizona Republic.  MAGS-REVIEWS (undate) {ndash} Dan Kincaid reviews current magazines. By DAN KINCAID.  COMMENTARY (moving in ``k'' category)  ROBB-COLUMN (Phoenix) -- Powell stands tall as warrior in time of crisis.. By ROBERT ROBB.  TERROR-EDIT (Phoenix) -- By insisting on limitations on the President's power to act, the Senate has done the nation no great favor. The Arizona Republic editorial. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010917.0023 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-TERROR-PHOTO-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS:  The following photos on the aftermathmath of the terrorist attack on New York and Washington have been sent as part of tonight's New York Times Photo Package, moving Sunday, 09/16/01.
