(James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT21) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-16 -- A makeshift memorial outside the home of Engine 54, Ladder 4 Battalion 9 in midtown Manhattan, Sunday. Fifteen firefighters with the station disappeared after the World Trade Center collapsed following a terrorist attack, Tuesday. (Steve Berman/The New York Times)  (NYT20) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-15 -- People gather in Jersey City, just across the Hudson River from downtown Manhattan to see the skyline, Sunday. Smoke billows from where the World Trade Center once stood. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)  (NYT19) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-14 -- President Bush speaks to reporters upon his return to the White House on Sunday from Camp David where he met with national security team. Bush urged Americans to return to work on Monday and put the U.S. economy back on track even as they remain alert to the possibility of more terrorist acts. The helicopter used to transport Bush was a Black Hawk version of Marine One. Looking on at left is first lady Laura Bush. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT18) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-MAYOR-WEDDING -- Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York, left, during the wedding of Diane Gorumba and Michael Ferrito, right, in Brooklyn, Sunday. Giuliani walked Gorumba down the aisle in place of her brother, a firefighter, who disappeared in the collapse of the World Trade Center. (Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)  (NYT17) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-13 -- Rescuers and cranes at the scene Sunday where the World Trade Center once stood. Rescuers continue to try and find survivors following last Tuesday's terrorist attack which destroyed the twin towers. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT16) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-12 -- Construction workers try to tie a cable from a crane to a large piece of debris, Sunday where the World Trade Center once stood. Rescuers continue to try and find survivors following last Tuesday's terrorist attack which destroyed the twin towers. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT15) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-LIBERTY-REVIEW -- The balance between security and liberty, throughout American history a reliable barometer of the public's mood and collective self-confidence, will now be recalibrated to reflect both new realities and new perceptions. A naitonal guardsman atop a HUMVEE on the corner of Walker and Broadway in downtown Manhattan, Wednesday. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)  (NYT14) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-11 -- President Bush speaks to reporters upon his return to the White House on Sunday from Camp David where he met with national security team. Bush urged Americans to return to work on Monday and put the U.S. economy back on track even as they remain alert to the possibility of more terrorist acts. The helicopter used to transport Bush was a Black Hawk version of Marine One. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)  (NYT13) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-10 -- Judy Coryell, center, of Westminister, Md., signs for her deaf daughters Lili, 15, left, and Vela, 12, right, as they joined in the singing of a hymn Sunday during services at Washington National Cathedral in Washington, D.C. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-9-- Rubble is emptied onto a dump truck on Sunday as rescuers continue to try and find survivors in what is left of the World Trade Center, Tuesday. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT11) GAINESVILLE, Fla. -- Sept. 11, 2001 -- TERROR-COMMUNICATIONS -- A panoply of communications networks kept Americans connected to the events of the day and each other during and after the terrorist assault on the twin towers last week. Students at the University of Florida watch the news of the attack on the World Trade Center on television, Tuesday. (Michael C. Weimar/The Ganesville Sun)  (NYT10) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-8-- A firefighter holds his helmet and a flag during a prayer service in downtown Manhattan, Sunday. (Earl Wilson/The New York Times)  (NYT9) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-7 -- The scene where the World Trade Center towers once stood as seen Sunday. The area is commonly being called ``ground zero.'' (Chris Chivers/The New York Times)  (NYT8) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-6 -- The scene where the World Trade Center towers once stood as seen Sunday. The area is commonly being called ``ground zero.'' (Charlie LeDuff/The New York Times)  (NYT7) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-5 -- The scene where the World Trade Center towers once stood as seen Sunday. The area is commonly being called ``ground zero.'' (Charlie LeDuff/The New York Times)  (NYT6) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-VICTIMS-2 -- People missing following last Tuesday's collapse of the World Trade Center, from left: Francisco Liriano, Sharon Christina Millan, Vanavah Thompson, Millie Hromada. (The New York Times) (The New York Times)  (NYT5) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-VICTIMS-1 -- People missing following last Tuesday's collapse of the World Trade Center, from left: Doug Jason Irgang, Mary Boffa, Neil Shastri. (The New York Times)  (NYT4) ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-4 -- Protesters during a rally Sunday against their government's cooperation with the United States in tracking down Osama Bin Laden, suspected of organizing Tuesday's terrorist attack in the U.S. A delegation of senior Pakistani officials will go to neighboring Afghanistan on Monday to demand that the ruling Taliban militia hand over bin Laden to the United States, a top Pakistani official said in Islamabad. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)  (NYT3) ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-3 -- A young Pakistani joins protesters Sunday during a rally against their government's cooperation with the United States in tracking down Osama Bin Laden, suspected of organizing Tuesday's terrorist attack in the U.S. A delegation of senior Pakistani officials will go to neighboring Afghanistan on Monday to demand that the ruling Taliban militia hand over bin Laden to the United States, a top Pakistani official said in Islamabad. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)  (NYT2) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-2 -- Five days after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center which has left nearly 5,000 people missing, smoke still rises from where the twin towers once stood as seen silhouetted against the dawn sky over lower Manhattan, Sunday. (David L. Ryan/The Bosotn Globe)  (NYT1) BOSTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-1 -- A Massachusetts special operations trooper stands watch with an assault rifle in terminal C at Logan International airport, Saturday. Boston's Logan Airport, where hijackers boarded the planes that destroyed the World Trade Center last Tuesday, reopened to tightened security. (John Bohn/The Boston Globe)  The New York Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010917.0024 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-TERROR-PHOTO-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS:  The following photos on the aftermathmath of the terrorist attack on New York and Washington have been sent as part of tonight's New York Times Photo Package, moving Sunday, 09/16/01.  All photos and graphics from the New York Times News Service are available at nytimages.com. Clients who have a photo account with the Wieck Database can use the same username and password to access the images.  There is no charge for browsing. But if you would like more information on establishing an account to download art from nytimages.com at a special rate, please call us at (212) 556-4204.  Our report has also moved to Newscom and via AP PhotoExpress.  (NYT42) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-29 -- On Sunday, residents of Battery Park City in lower Manhattan leave the area after retrieving belongings. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT41) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-28 -- In lower Manhattan, vocal and heartfelt public support for the city's overworked corps of rank-and-file police officers has lifted morale during the crisis. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT40) UNDATED -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-27 -- The search for people who worked at the trade center's margins has been modestly successful. From top to bottom: Sal Gjonbalaj, left, and his brother Selim hold a picture of their missing father, Mon, who was a window washer at the World Trade Center. Roko Camaj is searching for his father, Vincent, who worked on the World Trade Center's roof, maneuvering window washers' scaffolds. Sonia Ortiz's children, Alexa, left, and Victor, said she loved working at the trade center, where she ran the Windows on the World freight elevator. (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)  (NYT39) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-26 -- In a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral that mixed poignancy and moments of newly stirred patriotism, Cardinal Edward M. Egan, left, on Sunday deplored the ``faceless criminals'' who attacked the World Trade Center on Tuesday. Hundreds of people lined Fifth Avenue Sunday morning to hear Egan speak. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT38) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-25 -- In a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral that mixed poignancy and moments of newly stirred patriotism, Cardinal Edward M. Egan, left, on Sunday deplored the ``faceless criminals'' who attacked the World Trade Center on Tuesday. In attendance were Mayor Giuliani, far left, police commisioner Bernard Kerik, center, and fire commissioner Thomas Von Essen, far right. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)  (NYT37) ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-24 -- Pakistani demonstrators gathered in Islamabad, Pakistan Sunday to denounce their government's cooperation with American anti-terrorism efforts. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)  (NYT36) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-23 -- Trinity Church, which was blocks away from the World Trade Center, remained after the collapse of the towers and other nearby buildings. Over 150 parishioners gathered here on Sunday for Mass. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)  (NYT35) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-22 -- On Saturday, a policeman takes a break inside St. Charlie's, a bar and restaurant which was damaged by the collapse of the World Trade Center on Tuesday. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT34) UNDATED -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-NY-MISSING -- From left to right: Shreyas Ranganath, John F. Iskyan, Katie Marie McCloskey and L. Russell Keene III are among the missing. (The New York Times)  (NYT33) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-21 -- In order to fill the ranks that were devastated following Tuesday's attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Giuliani of New York swore in new fire department officials, Sunday. Giuliani likened their losses to those of sailors at Pearl Harbor and recalled how the Navy regrouped and prevailed. (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)  (NYT32) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-20 -- On Sunday, supporters of the victims of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center hold a candlelight vigil at the Brooklyn Heights Promenade for Arab-Americans, Jews and Christians. The gathering was sponsored by Arab-American Family Support Center, Sakhi for South Asian Women and Women for Afghan Women. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)  (NYT31) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- GRASSO-PROFILE -- Asked if he had sought any psychological help since his world collapsed on Tuesday, Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, seemed startled. ``No, I don't need it,'' he replied sharply. He added, ``My counseling is this -- that Monday morning 9:30 bell.'' Grasso plans to open the NYSE on Monday. Grasso on the NYSE trading floor on Sunday. (Krista Niles/The New York Times)  (NYT30) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ECON -- Faced with a major test of the U.S. economy's ability to withstand the blow from the terrorist attack, an informal coalition of government and business leaders urged investors in public and private on Sunday to do what they could to keep the stock markets from tumbling when they reopen Monday morning. On Sunday in Times Square, the Nasdaq Market Site ticker announces it's reopening on Monday. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)  (NYT29) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-INVEST-2 -- As the stock market prepared to reopen on Monday, after a terrorist strike to the heart of Wall Street last Tuesday, investors faced an unavoidable question: What should I do now? Many professional investors and money managers are retreating to the most basic kind of guidance -- hold tight. NYSE Chairman Richard Grasso, in yellow sweater, speaks with employees on Saturday as they prepare a dry run. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT28) UNDATED -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-ONLINE-MEDIA -- Whether it is Web sites supporting terrorism, or anti-Islamic messages posted on Internet bulletin boards, some material has forced the Internet access providers to step up their screening efforts and rethink their standards of what sort of material is acceptable. On one Web site, under the heading ``The Road to Jihad,'' right, an urban skyline was shown in flames with burning flags of the United States and Israel. (The New York Times)  (NYT27) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-INVEST -- As the stock market prepared to reopen on Monday, after a terrorist strike to the heart of Wall Street last Tuesday, investors faced an unavoidable question: What should I do now? Many professional investors and money managers are retreating to the most basic kind of guidance -- hold tight. On Saturday, the NYSE does a dry run while employees wait for rehearsal at their stations. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)  (NYT26) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-INFO-MEDIA -- Television's efforts to keep its audience connected also left it vulnerable to conveying undeveloped, sometimes erroneous reports. On Thursday, a Port Authority police officer helped evacuate La Guardia Airport in New York after a bomb threat. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)  (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-19 -- In order to fill the ranks that were devastated following Tuesday's attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Giuliani of New York swore in new fire department officials, Sunday. Giuliani during the ceremony Sunday in Brooklyn. Hundreds of firefighters are missing following Tuesday's terrorist attack. The chief of the department as well as the department's chaplain were killed in the attack. (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)  (NYT24) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-18 -- A rescuer acknowledges applause from New Yorkers lining a route used to access the World Trade Center area, Sunday. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT23) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- NYC-OPERA-REVIEW -- Responding to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's request for a return to normalcy, the New York City Opera opened a delayed season Saturday with two premiere productions which brought complex and conflicting feelings among audience and cast members. The cast and crew of the ``Flying Dutchman,'' sang the National Anthem before the opening performance at the New York State Theater. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)  (NYT22) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-17 -- An elevated view of rescue efforts looking north towards uptown, Sunday, on the site where the World Trade Center once stood. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT21) NEW YORK -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-16 -- A makeshift memorial outside the home of Engine 54, Ladder 4 Battalion 9 in midtown Manhattan, Sunday. Fifteen firefighters with the station disappeared after the World Trade Center collapsed following a terrorist attack, Tuesday. (Steve Berman/The New York Times)  (NYT20) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 16, 2001 -- TERROR-DAY6-15 -- People gather in Jersey City, just across the Hudson River from downtown Manhattan to see the skyline, Sunday. By John F. Burns.  (An early version of this story will move by 3 p.m. EDT.)  AFGHAN-U.S.-TARGETS (Washington) _ On the difficulty of find targets in Afghanistan that could carve away at a shadowy network like Osama bin Laden's and also hit hard at a country that barely functions as a state. By Michael R. Gordon.  With  AFGHAN-SCENE (Jalalabad, Afghanistan) _ The scene in Jalalabad. By Barry Bearak. With  AFGHAN-TALIBAN-U.S. (Washington) _ As recently as a few months ago, the United States was preparing to aid the Taliban (as well as uniting with Russia on sanctions against them). By Patrick E. IRAN-TALIBAN-U.S. (Washington) _ How Iran, a declared foe of the Taliban, might help in the fight against terrorism, and how Iranian-U.S. relations could be affected. By Elaine Sciolino.  ARABS-U.S. (Washington) _ The response of Arab nations to the U.S. appeal to join the war on terrorism. By Jane Perlez.  LATAM-U.S. (Rio de Janeiro) _ The Organization of American States will meet Wednesday, and Brazil is proposing to invoke the Rio Treaty _ dismissed just two weeks ago as a Cold War relic by President Vicente Fox of Mexico. By Larry Rohter.  NIRELAND-POLITICS (London) _ John Hume resigned as leader of the moderate nationalist SDLP, leaving Gerry Adams the unquestioned leader of the nationalist faction in Ulster ahead of what is very likely the indefinite suspension of home rule next weekend. By Warren Hoge.  SKOREA-NKOREA (Seoul, South Korea) _ North and South Korea ended their first ministerial talks in six months with few signs of progress. By Don Kirk.  WORLD-BRIEFS (Undated) _ World news in brief.  UNITED STATES _ General  (Will move in `a' category or as noted)  TERROR-INQUIRY (Washington) _ Developments in the inquiry into the terrorist attacks. By David Johnston.  TERROR-CLERIC (Washington) _ The role of Moataz Al-Hallak, a Muslim cleric who is a U.S. citizen and may have ties to some of the people connected with the terror attacks. By Douglas Jehl.  TERROR-NY-RDP (New York) _ The lede-all, including the numbers of dead and missing and scenes from the site. By Eric Lipton.  TERROR-PA-MEMORIAL (Indian Lake, Pa.) _ Laura Bush will attend a memorial service for the victims of the Pennsylvania crash. By Sara Rimer.  TERROR-SURVIVOR-TRAUMA (Undated) _ For some survivors of last week's terror attacks, the trauma will be long-lasting. Its severity and extent depend on individual differences in mental health, brain chemistry and circumstances. By Erica Goode.  OVERSEAS-STUDENTS (Washington) _ After the terror attack by hijackers who apparently received some training at U.S. flight schools, university officials said they expect to be under more pressure to adopt stricter limits on foreign students. By Diana Jean Schemo.  TERROR-U.S.-MOOD (Undated) _ National ledeall on the reaction and national mood in the aftermath of the terror attacks. By Timothy Egan.  ANTIMUSLIM-HATE-CRIMES (Undated) _ On incidents of anti-Muslim hate crimes nationwide. By Tamar Lewin.  AFGHANS-IN-U.S. (Fremont, Calif.) _ The largest Afghan community in the United States is split between the anti-Taliban middle-class and the poor pro-Taliban community. By Evelyn Nieves.  CONGRESS-AID (Washington) _ Hard on the heels of the airline lobbyists' appeals to lawmakers are representatives of every other industry who are asking for their own bailouts from the federal treasury. By Lizette Alvarez and Philip Shenon.  NY-WORK-RETURN (New York) _ The first day back at work for a blue-collar worker. By Charlie LeDuff.  ARABS-IN-NY (New York) _ On what it is like to be Arab in New York right now. By Somini Sengupta.  TERROR-NY-TOURISTS (New York) _ The site of the World Trade Center disaster has become a huge tourist attraction. By Dean E. Murphy.  NY-CRIME (New York) _ Did crime throughout the city fall while the police focused on the tragedy at the World Trade Center? By Michael Cooper.  BUSINESS  (Will move in ``f'' news category)  ECON-RDP (New York) _ A ledeall on the opening of markets, Fed action, et alia: Stocks plunged on Monday despite a cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve aimed at stabilizing the market, as Wall Street began trading for the first time since last Tuesday's terrorist attacks. By Gretchen Morgenson.  (An early version of this story by Jack Lynch, slugged MARKET, has moved.)  MARKET-JAPAN (Tokyo) _ Japanese stocks and the dollar fell sharply in Tokyo on Monday as investors braced for a sell-off in the U.S. stock market. By Ken Belson.  (An early version of this story has moved.)  MARKET-LATAM (Sao Paulo, Brazil) _ Brazil and Argentina, already on shaky economic ground before last Tuesday, are worsening by the day, and their markets are falling steeply. By Jennifer L. Rich.  FED-RATES (Washington) _ The Federal Reserve on Monday lowered interest rates a half point before the stock market opened, its eighth rate cut this year. The Fed lowered its target on the federal funds rate to 3 percent, the lowest it has been in nine years. By Richard W. Stevenson.  MARKET-SCENE (New York) _ The scene as Wall Street begins again, and voices from financial sites, investment sites and investors around the world. By Alessandra Stanley.  (An early version of this story by Sherri Day will move by 4 p.m. EDT.)  BIZ-MOOD (Undated) _ How business across America is different now. By Greg Winter.  AIRLINES (Undated) _ Developments in the airline industry. (Staff byline to come)  TERROR-BIZ (Undated) _ Some companies have been opportunistic or have simply displayed poor taste in the wake of the terrorist attacks. By John Schwartz.  VODAFONE-JAPAN (London) _ Vodafone Group said it plans to take control of Japan Telecom by buying an additional 21.7 percent of the company. The additional stake, worth about $1.8 billion, would advance Vodafone's pursuit of a global presence. By Suzanne Kapner.  DAEWOO-GM (Seoul, South Korea) _ Details of the acquisition terms between General Motors and Daewoo's creditors. By Don Kirk.  CHINA-WTO (Geneva) _ China and the WTO working group are making it official that China will gain membership. By Elizabeth Olson.  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Short items on business news from around the world.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS  (Will move in ``e'' news category or as indicated)  TERROR-ARTS (Undated) _ The effects of the terrorist attacks on the national arts scene. By Stephen Kinzer.  MOVIE-VIOLENCE (Undated) _ Critic's Notebook: How attitudes toward violence in the movies may change in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on the United States. By Elvis Mitchell.  READERS-NEW-CHOICES (Undated) _ How the attacks have changed readers' preferences. By Emily Eakin.  BROTHER-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ The Brother, by Sam Roberts, takes a fresh look at atomic bomb spies Julius and Ethel Rosenberg from the perspective of the man who stole the secrets, and then gave up the Rosenbergs to the FBI: David Greenglass. , you know,	 Yet if Cassavetes (1929-1989) was the first independent, he could just as well be called the last. He made movies before ``independent film'' became a lower-case brand name: before Sundance and IFC and video rights and a Miramax or Fine Line wanting to sign the latest 20-something festival winner to a two-picture deal. Not that he would necessarily have had it any other way. There was a self-destructive quality to Cassavetes, born of equal parts pridefulness and naivete. As he once admitted, ``I'm sort of my own Mafia, you know, breaking my own knees.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

, he wrote,	 To some, this was another symptom of what Dr. Elisabeth Kubler-Ross has called the denial of death in America, taking what was once an intimate part of family life and turning it into a distant spectacle. Others had a darker view. In 1996, the cultural historian Neal Gabler lamented television's fascination with tragedy and reporters' pursuit of grief-stricken relatives, whose televised pain, he wrote, effectively made viewers ``voyeurs in suffering.'' The poet Thomas Lynch, who for years has held a day job as a funeral director, voiced similar complaints in 1999, arguing that ``Grief TV'' provided little but ``user-friendly'' catharsis, a ``virtual substitution'' for the sort of real mourning one experiences firsthand when a loved one _ not a celebrity-stranger _ dies. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

Now it is living a third-millennium fairy tale with the return of King Simeon II to Bulgaria's political life. By Corinne La Balme.  TRAVEL- NORTHWEST-RAILS (Undated) _ Michael Upchurch took two different types of trains on the Northwest rail corridor from Eugene, Ore., to Vancouver: the Coast Starlight, which continues to Los Angeles, and the newer Amtrak Cascades, with its tilt-train technology that offers a smoother and speedier journey. There are points where he wanted to shout ``Stop the train, I want to get off!'' Every pier and sand spit looked like the gateway to an island life. By Michael Upchurch.  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) _ An estimated 5 to 8 percent of children under 3, and up to 3 percent of school-age children, have true food allergies. For millions of families, vacations are a daunting prospect. Kevin Flynn writes about traveling with a six-year-old, who is severely allergic to milk, eggs and peanuts.  TRAVEL-RIO-CORCOVADO (Undated) _ This city's most renowned landmark, the 98-foot-high statue of Christ the Redeemer that stands atop Corcovado Mountain, celebrates its 70th anniversary next month. In conjunction with the event, the municipal government has begun building a new system of elevators and escalators to make it easier to reach the 2,308-foot summit. By Larry Rohter. , I followed,	 When I first started to travel frequently, I followed, more or less, the packing advice offered in all the articles I'd ever read on the subject: I stocked up on wrinkle-free fabric separates in black and neutral colors. Following the received wisdom that a travel wardrobe hinges on accessories, I collected a few little scarves and pieces of costume jewelry. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
, I think,	 Good-quality linen and raw silk are, I think, a far classier alternative to synthetics in the wrinkle-free department. They also hold up better over time. My perfect travel dress, acquired on sale for $85 in Italy two years ago, is made of light, tightly woven linen. Packed, it folds up flat into a freezer-sized Ziploc bag. I arrive at my hotel, shake it out and put it on a hanger; the next day the wrinkles have fallen out and the dress is good to go. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

(ATTENTION EDITORS: This article is for use by clients of The New York Times Syndicate's DISCOVER NEWS SERVICE. For more information about purchasing this article as a ``separate-buy'' or becoming a client of DISCOVER NEWS SERVICE, contact one of the New York Times Syndicate sales representatives listed at the end of the text.) (ART ADV: Color art is available on Wieck, Newscom or by calling William Gonzalez at 212-499-3355.) c.2001 Discover magazine Compiled by THE EDITORS OF DISCOVER MAGAZINE (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  NO MORE TAP, TAP, TAPPING AWAY AT THE OLD COMPUTER  A flat touch pad called the FingerBoard could someday make conventional keyboards look as quaint as manual typewriters. To tap out a word, lightly touch a series of letters on the FingerBoard's flat surface. To perform a click of the mouse, slide two fingers together anywhere on the surface of the board; to zoom in on an image, splay your fingers.  Designed by electrical engineers Wayne Westerman and John Elias of the University of Delaware, the FingerBoard detects distortions in the electrostatic field near the surface of the board and uses that data to determine the commands.  Preliminary tests indicate the FingerBoard is easier on the hands than other keyboards, because it requires virtually no force to touch keys and no awkward movements to reach for a mouse. For more information: www.fingerworks.com.  DON'T CATCH A DIRTY WAVE  When you go into the water, the water goes into you too _ into your eyes, nose, ears, mouth and open wounds. Many state laws require beaches to close if tests show dangerous levels of bacteria. But Joan Rose, professor of water pollution microbiology at the University of South Florida College of Marine Sciences, studies another threat _ viral infection _ that usually goes unmentioned.  Recreational waters off California, Florida and other coastal states show surprising concentrations of viruses that can cause maladies ranging from gastrointestinal distress to possibly fatal myocarditis.  Here, Rose talks about the danger in the waves.  Q: How do viruses get into the oceans near our beaches?  A: In California, mostly as runoff from storm drains. In the Florida Keys, infected water leaches from septic tanks and sewer lines, or is washed into the ocean by thundershowers. There's an amazing interchange between groundwater and adjacent surface water, such as a canal or lake. In Key Largo, we flushed virus tracers down toilets and found them 24 hours later in canals 10 to 20 yards away. Then the tides washed them out toward the reef.  Q: How widespread is the problem?  A: We don't know how prevalent virus infections are, but someone in the community is always infected and excreting these viruses because we can always find them in sewage. We find more viruses in winter when the water is cooler _ that's probably related to their survival _ and when it rains. Overall we've detected human viruses at more than 60 percent of the coastal sites we've tested.  Q: Is this a serious public health risk?  A: Key West had an event where people would swim around the island. They canceled it last year because of water quality. Two years ago, 30 percent of the participants reported gastric, skin, eye or respiratory symptoms. So there's definitely a risk. We've stressed our coastal environment around the world.  Q: Does wastewater pose a threat to aquatic wildlife as well?  A: Fish can get infected with Aeromonas and other bacteria. Upsets in the ecosystem may lead to toxic algae that could also be a problem for fish. We need to know much more about the ecology of water _ estuarine, ocean, groundwater, even water in pipes.  Q: What's the next step for your research?  A: We'd like to learn when and where we're at risk by understanding land-use and transport patterns and by tracking virus sources. We'd also like to take a beach or two, create circulation models and see if we can get some kind of predictability. We want to be able to tell the public what we think is going on so they can make the judgment for themselves. In the long run, we need better storm-water management.  Q: Do you take any precautions when you go to the beach?  A: I pay attention to state evaluations of beaches. I don't like to swim in natural waters in certain countries. I don't swim in canals next to areas with septic tanks. I try to avoid very crowded beaches, because they can have greater pollution.  Q: Do you ever feel grim working with sewage and germs?  A: Actually, I love it.  THEY INVENTED IT WHEN? THE VACUUM CLEANER  In 1869, Chicago inventor Ives W. McGaffey created a sweeping machine that used a fan to create suction, but the device had to be cranked by hand. In 1901 British engineer Hubert C. Booth devised a motorized method, and other designs followed.  These first true vacuum cleaners were huge gasoline-powered contraptions drawn by horse from door to door by professional housecleaners.  In 1907, Ohio janitor James Murray Spangler invented a portable 40-pound electric vacuum, which he sold to entrepreneur William H. Hoover. Manufacturers soon added attachments for crevices and upholstery _ the 1913 Eureka even doubled as a hair dryer.  In 1926, Hoover introduced a model with beater bars and brushes, which greatly increased its dirt-fighting power. Lighter, more efficient motors and better batteries allowed for the introduction of handheld vacuums, led by Black &AMP; Decker's Dustbuster in 1980.  Next up: Electrolux engineers are working on a sonar-guided robotic vacuum. For more information: www.fingerworks.com.  DON'T CATCH A DIRTY WAVE  When you go into the water, the water goes into you too _ into your eyes, nose, ears, mouth and open wounds. Many state laws require beaches to close if tests show dangerous levels of bacteria. But Joan Rose, professor of water pollution microbiology at the University of South Florida College of Marine Sciences, studies another threat _ viral infection _ that usually goes unmentioned.  Recreational waters off California, Florida and other coastal states show surprising concentrations of viruses that can cause maladies ranging from gastrointestinal distress to possibly fatal myocarditis.  Here, Rose talks about the danger in the waves.  Q: How do viruses get into the oceans near our beaches?  A: In California, mostly as runoff from storm drains. In the Florida Keys, infected water leaches from septic tanks and sewer lines, or is washed into the ocean by thundershowers. There's an amazing interchange between groundwater and adjacent surface water, such as a canal or lake. In Key Largo, we flushed virus tracers down toilets and found them 24 hours later in canals 10 to 20 yards away. Then the tides washed them out toward the reef.  Q: How widespread is the problem?  A: We don't know how prevalent virus infections are, but someone in the community is always infected and excreting these viruses because we can always find them in sewage. We find more viruses in winter when the water is cooler _ that's probably related to their survival _ and when it rains. Overall we've detected human viruses at more than 60 percent of the coastal sites we've tested.  Q: Is this a serious public health risk?  A: Key West had an event where people would swim around the island. They canceled it last year because of water quality. Two years ago, 30 percent of the participants reported gastric, skin, eye or respiratory symptoms. So there's definitely a risk. We've stressed our coastal environment around the world.  Q: Does wastewater pose a threat to aquatic wildlife as well?  A: Fish can get infected with Aeromonas and other bacteria. Upsets in the ecosystem may lead to toxic algae that could also be a problem for fish. We need to know much more about the ecology of water _ estuarine, ocean, groundwater, even water in pipes.  Q: What's the next step for your research?  A: We'd like to learn when and where we're at risk by understanding land-use and transport patterns and by tracking virus sources. We'd also like to take a beach or two, create circulation models and see if we can get some kind of predictability. We want to be able to tell the public what we think is going on so they can make the judgment for themselves. In the long run, we need better storm-water management.  Q: Do you take any precautions when you go to the beach?  A: I pay attention to state evaluations of beaches. I don't like to swim in natural waters in certain countries. I don't swim in canals next to areas with septic tanks. I try to avoid very crowded beaches, because they can have greater pollution.  Q: Do you ever feel grim working with sewage and germs?  A: Actually, I love it.  THEY INVENTED IT WHEN? THE VACUUM CLEANER  In 1869, Chicago inventor Ives W. McGaffey created a sweeping machine that used a fan to create suction, but the device had to be cranked by hand. In 1901 British engineer Hubert C. Booth devised a motorized method, and other designs followed.  These first true vacuum cleaners were huge gasoline-powered contraptions drawn by horse from door to door by professional housecleaners.  In 1907, Ohio janitor James Murray Spangler invented a portable 40-pound electric vacuum, which he sold to entrepreneur William H. Hoover. Manufacturers soon added attachments for crevices and upholstery _ the 1913 Eureka even doubled as a hair dryer.  In 1926, Hoover introduced a model with beater bars and brushes, which greatly increased its dirt-fighting power. Lighter, more efficient motors and better batteries allowed for the introduction of handheld vacuums, led by Black &AMP; Decker's Dustbuster in 1980.  Next up: Electrolux engineers are working on a sonar-guided robotic vacuum. , I say,	 Writing about life and work means flirting with hypocrisy. Every other week in this newspaper, I chronicle the fight to keep an eye on what's important. In the choice between life and work, I say, choose life. Yet, getting those 800 words onto the page often means losing sight of all I preach. It means putting off my children or feeding my ulcer because, for the moments I am writing, the writing is the all-enveloping thing. I work because I love it and because I like the goodies it brings me and because it layers order over my life. But last week I watched live on my office television as the world's most visible workplace disintegrated into rubble. Work can not bring order in a world of chaos. </P> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz

The plummeting number of hotel visitors is part of a bigger picture that includes restaurants, Broadway shows and other entertainment, and the general hospitality and entertainment industry. A procession of world leaders is either on the way or on the phone to Washington seeking to convince the White House that only a multilateral approach and U.N. support would justify the use of military power. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``a'' news file.)  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010918.0318 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WORLD-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WORLD NEWS IN BRIEF  c.2001 New York Times News Service  EUROPE  RUSSIA: CHECHEN GUERRILLAS ROUNDED UP  Troops have rounded up scores of suspected guerrillas in Chechnya after a surprise assault by rebels killed 10 soldiers in Gudermes, the province's second-largest city, and killed 13 more in a missile attack on a helicopter in Grozny, the capital. The attacks, the largest in recent months, belied Russian claims that two years of war had left the Islamic-led separatists incapable of mounting a serious offensive. Military spokesmen said Russian troops had killed 17 guerrillas in Gudermes and taken 13 more into custody. Twenty-two suspects were held Tsotsin-Yurt, including several accused of carrying out the attack on the helicopter, the Interfax news service said.  ITALY: RIGHTIST DENIES IMMIGRANT SLUR  Umberto Bossi, leader of the Northern League, denied responsibility for an anti-immigrant flier that was distributed Sunday at the party's annual gathering in Venice. The flier bore an image of Osama bin Laden and the words ``Illegal Immigrants (EQ) Islamic Terrorists.'' Italy has become an important point of entry for immigrants from Albania and points east, and nearly 1,000 landed in the south over the weekend. On Friday, the center-right Cabinet approved a draft law introducing tougher immigration regulations, including prison terms for illegal immigrants who return after being expelled.  ITALY: ANARCHISTS ROUNDED UP  A hundred sites were searched across northern Italy and 60 people were questioned as part of an investigation by the Milan prosecutor into possible terrorist activities by Italian anarchists. The groups are suspected of being involved in plans to attack targets like the Milan cathedral, but the prosecutor said the searches were not linked to the attacks in the United States.  SWEDEN: NUCLEAR PLANT TO CLOSE  Sweden will close a second nuclear reactor by 2003 as part of its plan to phase out nuclear energy by 2010, Prime Minister Goran Persson said as he opened the autumn session of Parliament. He said the government expects the conditions laid down by Parliament for closing Barseback 2, in southwestern Sweden, to be met ``by 2003 at the latest.'' Sweden voted in a referendum in 1980 to shut its 12 nuclear reactors by 2010. So far, only the smallest reactor, Barseback 1's 600-megawatt plant, has been closed, in 1999. Nuclear energy provides about half the national electricity supply, and Parliament has stipulated that Barseback 2 can be shut only after its output has been replaced by renewable energy or conservation.  TURKEY: HOTEL-BUILDER SENTENCED  Sevan Nisanyan, owner of several small hotels in Sirince, a historic village, has been sentenced to a year in prison for making illegal improvements to one property and having artifacts from an old mosque in another, said his wife, Mujde Nisanyan. Nisanyan is in jail near Sirince, in the southwest.  IRELAND: A SENSE OF RACISM  More than 80 percent of the members of ethnic minorities in Ireland feel that racism is a serious problem and that the government is not doing enough to combat it, according to a survey of 600 people by Amnesty International. Women reported more racism and discrimination than men; just over half of those surveyed do not feel confident reporting racist incidents to the police.  IRELAND: BLOWIN' IN THE WIND  Environment Minister Noel Dempsey decreed a 14-cent fee for each plastic bag used to carry groceries. The Irish use 1.2 billion bags every year, or 325 per person, he said, and they are the most visible form of litter in the countryside, where they get caught in trees and hedges and along riverbanks. Starting in February, stores will be required to charge customers for each bag.  AFRICA  RWANDA: TRIAL OPENS FOR PASTOR  A pastor extradited from the United States last year went on trial on Tuesday with his son at a U.N. tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania, on charges of involvement in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. The pastor, Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, a Seventh-day Adventist, is the first church leader to come to trial. He and his son Gerard, a medical doctor, have pleaded not guilty to charges of genocide and crimes against humanity during 1994, when Hutu extremists massacred more than half a million Tutsis and moderate Hutus. A prosecutor said the pastor encouraged Tutsi men, women and children to seek refuge in a church and hospital in Kibuye, then called Hutus to come kill them.  MIDDLE EAST  EGYPT: 15-YEAR-OLD IS SENTENCED FOR HOMOSEXUALITY  A court found a 15-year-old youth guilty of ``practicing sexual immorality,'' a local phrase for homosexuality, and sentenced him to three years in juvenile detention. The youth and 52 men were arrested in May in a raid on a nightclub. The youth was tried separately because he is a minor. Three years was the maximum sentence he could receive. The men are being tried in an emergency state security court, which denies any chance of appeal. They are accused of sexual immorality and forming a group that insulted Islam. Homosexuality is taboo in Egypt, but not prohibited by law.  NIGERIA: ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE  Poor management of the environment costs Nigeria $5 billion a year in ruined land and lost forests, said Muhtari Aminu-Kano, executive director of the Nigerian Conservation Foundation. Much of the damage results from oil and gas extraction in the Niger Delta, he added. Illegal logging is speeding deforestation and the southward advance of the Sahara, which threatens to destroy rare plant and animal species in northern parts of the country.  ASIA  MYANMAR: INVESTIGATION INTO FORCED LABOR  Four officials from the International Labor Organization met with diplomats and members of the democratic opposition one day after meeting with the interior minister of the military government. The team is trying to verify the government's claim that it is working to end forced labor. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010918.0319 type=story > <HEADLINE> MARATHONS WON'T LET ATTACKS STOP THEM </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> NEW YORK (BC-RUN-MARATHON-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200109.gz
